text:
Asian Taste Inn in the Huntingdon Valley Marketplace on County Line Road, is a primarily Chinese house owned by a Guangdong Province family, that has been turning out pretty good semi-authentic dishes for a while.  The space is well maintained with many booths and tables, and an amiable server corps dressed in tan and green that actually seems to enjoy interacting with their customers.  

True to its cultural roots, the cuisine tends toward sweetness, and even their spicy dishes maintain a hint of sugar just behind the chili flavors.  Our Orange Beef and General Tso Shrimp came either drowned in heavy sweet amber, or had it on the side.  Both were framed in Broccoli Florets, the much overused non-Chinese veggie. Their tastes were fine, but we all commented on the unexpected sugariness of the platters.  The Spicy Shrimp, Scallop & Squid with Pepper Corn Salt, was a relief from the cane, and would have been completely on target had it all been crisper.  Finally, my sushi sample of an Eel & Avocado Roll was average, with much more Avo than Eel, and artificially colored Wasabe and Ginger.  

Bottom Line - The suburbs has taken the edge off the kitchen here.  Everything was accommodating to the local market.  Too much broccoli, and not enough real heat. Not bad if this is what you are looking for.

Came down to 40th Street to meet a good friend, and parked right in front of Tandoor India.  When he arrived, I asked where he wanted to go, and he pointed to the doorway right behind me.  Auspicious beginnings...
First impression was of an old establishment somewhat in need of refurbishment, but with inviting scents of curry and coriander drawing us in.  I checked the buffet as we walked past to our table and saw an extensive collection of yellow, red, brown and rusty sauces, all looking fresh and inviting on a cold Sunday night.  The place was not crowded.  Settling in, I decided to take a look at the menu because I was not in the mood for a cascade of flavors and tastes, but wanted to relax with only a few.  We were given copies of the take out menu, which somewhat surprised me.  On the cover it said: "We believe that the joy of eating lies in the art of fine cooking."
I'll drink to that.
We ordered Tikka Masala (with Chicken), which came out in a fine pink sauce of tomato and ginger, and was quite good. The Baigan Bharta was tasty, but was chopped fine rather than with the chunky eggplant I expected.  They cheated a bit on the Garlic Naan by bringing us regular Naan painted with garlic butter.  It didn't work, as it was not integrated into the bread, but sat on the surface, and lacked the baked garlic pieces I love in true Garlic Naan.  A disappointing way to pay an extra buck. The Mango Lassi was pretty good,  but a little thin from using milk rather than yogurt.  A nice plate of rice came with the meal.  
This was a meal in which we were more engrossed in the conversation than attentive to our food.  The strong brotherhood carried the day, and the meal became background.  For the overall experience, I was quite satisfied.
We didn't solve any world problems, but agreed we would get together soon, and try again.

Tough crowd!

Coffee depends on the quality of the water.  Here, you might want to have it tested. Definitely has an unusual aftertaste.  Still, it was potable and left no lingering aftereffects.  

Can't speak to the sweets, but the bathroom was tidy.

While the Shops At Liberty Place offer an architecturally interesting structure in a modern urban environment, and attracts people for both shopping and sightseeing the latest in city planning, it also likely represents a business model that will not succeed in the long run.  

The suburban mall made its presence felt as a post World War II phenomenon that mirrored the rapid growth of the automobile industry and the closely aligned migration of a generation of city dwellers into the countryside, a/k/a Suburbia.  They were the successful way to provide the "stuff" of life away from the urban core.  They worked well for almost 50 years.  But, as with most things, they were overdone, and failed to adapt to the changing demographics and cultural evolution that they spawned.  Walk through most malls today and you see lots of empty space, failing stores, and a subculture of youth versus elderly hangouts.  

First the malls disrupted Main Street.  Then the Walmarts and Costco's of the world, disrupted the malls.  But, the disassociation from the communities where the consumer lived ultimately started to alienate them.  People wanted to return to their Main Street where possible.  More began to appreciate the quality of city life, and returned to the urban centers to once again live and work in the same place.  The suburbs began to lose its charm for many, especially those without young children.  

These reurbanified folk did not want to shop in malls along an inhuman highway, and certainly did not want to spend much time in a suburban style mall transplanted in the city.  The developers who thought otherwise, are wishing they had been smarter.  The retail franchisers and chain expanders were the last to catch on, but the growing list of failing stores and malls bear witness to this truth.  

So it is with the Shops of Freedom Place.  Fundamentally, a suburban marketplace miscast as a modern upscale urban experience that it turned out not enough people really wanted.  A J. Crew in a Center City suburban style mall just does not attract enough customers.  Never will. 

It is not that such a public space could never work.  It can, but it requires a total reconfiguration that demonstrates an understanding of what people really want.  What is that?  A return to the village life, or that of the old neighborhood, where people knew each other, and felt like part of a community - in the city.  More impersonal and monotonous shopping is not where we are headed.  

How accomplish that?  Start by thinking in human scale.  Change part of the Liberty Place skyscrapers into condos and apartments for people to live.  Add a supermarket, cinema, child care, medical facility, and more greenery throughout the buildings.  Create a vertical village or neighborhood.  Where are the green grocer, the deli, the bakery, the corner tavern? 

The central rotunda can still work as a gathering place for activities, but it should feel more like the gazebo in the middle of the public commons.  

People want their cities to be state of the art, cutting edge, and full of energy and opportunity.  But, they also want to feel like it can take care of their needs and make them feel part of it, not overcome by it.  There are examples of this being done successful around the country and the planet.  Visit some of the new cities in Asia, and even some of the new age projects in New York, Seattle(JB) and San Francisco.  

Bring it down to human scale, and they will come and thrive.

I am just getting into BBQ in a bigger way, so when I saw Christopher D's review of Oink Johnson's Southern BBQ along with the few others, I had a strong impulse to drive up county and find out for myself what this place had to offer. It was a gorgeous early September afternoon special made for a open window stereo blazing cruise in the rolling Bucks countryside. I was in a good mood.

Driving up 611 north of Doylestown with the GPS alerting me that I was at my destination, I still did not recognize it at first.  There is a small cabin on wheels sitting in the middle of the rocky parking lot, with a fruit stand on one side, and a puppy barn on the other.  That trailered shack was Oink's.  The front porch of the structure has two large BBQ grills, a large menu nailed to the wall.  Took a few seconds to get oriented, especially when this big fella with a white apron and big white mustache came over and looked down at me and said:

"What'll it be, young feller?"

"Well, sir. I can't decide 'tween the Pulled Pork and the Brisket. What do ya think?"

"They're both lip smackin' good, my man.  Can't go wrong with either." 

Ok. I was hooked by ol' Oink's charm even before I made a choice.  This guy and the whole set up was right out of a Michener novel.  I was game to play my role. 

Two of his buddies sat to the side of the shack under an old beer company umbrella watching this transaction.  I looked over to greet them with a reference to the weather, and they chawed back that maybe I should get one of both the pork and brisket. Nice upsell, gents. 

I ordered the Pulled Pork Sandwich, BBQ Beans and Corn Bread.  Oink disappeared into the enclosed portion of the hut on wheels to make his magic.  He appeared a few minutes later with a large white paper wrapped package that seemed too big to be a Sammy.  I couldn't see what was in it, which was just slightly troubling, but this man had such an aura of confidence that I let it slide thinking I was probably missing the point of just knowing it would be great without a need for a visual. 

This place is strictly take out, so although I would have preferred to enjoy my BBQ on site, I had to take with and drive back home to eat it.  No biggie.

Upon unwrapping the creation I found it was indeed a huge quantity of meat, but the roll had been saturated with pork and BBQ juices, and was too wet to eat. I ate the pork with a fork.  It was tender and juicy, yet the BBQ flavor was not very strong, and it was a bit salty for my palate. The Beans were richly dark brown, heavy with molasses and chunks of fat back bacon. Excellent. The Corn Bread in the form of a muffin was good, but not overly sweet nor moist. 

If I could give a grade just for personality and appearance, Oink Johnson would be a 5 Star experience. But, as the Pulled Pork was not as good as others I have eaten, and the roll was a total loss, the food comes in at 2 Stars for me.

I will get back there eventually to try the ribs and brisket, but I am disappointed by the lack of "Zing" in the Pulled Pork.

Still, I recommend stopping in as the characters are wonderful, the locale very pretty farmland, and the food worth a sampling.

I found myself hungry around noon in Doylestown today, and decided to check out Hickory Kitchen for an early lunch. 

First impression was that this was an efficient, sunny, Main Street bistrot serving everything from soups to burgers to BBQ, with a large vegetarian option.  I almost went for the Special Bison Burger after having just had a Yelp discussion about buffalo burgers, but had eaten enough meat yesterday, and just didn't want more.  So, I went for the Grilled Veggie Quesadilla and home brewed Sweet Peach Iced Tea.  The chef and server got busy at the grill, and produced my meal in about 10 minutes. It came out on a small aluminum baking tray (clever), with Sour Cream, Salsa, and a bag of chips (?). 

The Quesadilla was very good, and I could not finish it. It was full of chunky veggies and cheese.  The Iced Tea was fine, just lightly sweetened. Each table had three bottle rockets with three varieties of BBQ sauce - mustard, maple, and tomato based. I tried each of them on the quesadilla in place of the jar based salsa.  I liked them more than the salsa, and think HK is onto something as an alternative to the traditional accompaniment for Mexican dishes.  The mix of Mexi - BBQ could be a big hit (but, it is not Tex-Mex).

This review will likely be updated when I return to taste the BBQ options here. Most of the raves seem to be for the ribs, so I will get back for them. 

All in all, a good first bite, but I can't say that I am drawn enough to return promptly that being a fan suggests.  A nice effort with potential.

Kelly's Kitchen is the actual name of this breakfast/lunch café sitting at the bottom of Bristol Road in Bensalem.  It has a nice counter with about a dozen spinners, and an equal number of tables, but the kitchen is in the back of the house so you can't see the meals being prepared, nor smell of the bacon on the grill. 

The service is good with prompt offers of coffee refills and light banter to make you feel at home.  My Kelly's Irish Omelet was a three egger with Onions, Peppers and Cheddar alongside a huge pile of crispy Home Fries, and Rye Toast.  I thought the eggs could have been lighter in texture if mixed with a little water before cooking, and there wasn't a whole lot of the veggies inside the eggs.  It was a bit underwhelming for a House Special.  The potatoes and toast were both fine.

The absence of credit card acceptance is annoying in today's world, and retailers who choose not to make their customer's lives easier in this regard should be called to account.  

While the room and service were fine, the food was not consistently exceptional, and the Cash Only policy shows a lack of true concern for its customers. Hard to get past A-OK.

Comfortable Star$$$ in the Acme Shopping Center just south of Bordentown off Route 130.  

Not a fan of their burnt approach to java, but sometimes it is the only option in the vicinity.  The Flat White was fine, but the prices are designed to make the stockholders happier than the customers.  

This shop was well laid out with ample table and comfortable seating around.  No problem with the staff.  Everyone was in a good mood this mid-week late morning.  Several quiet conversations and solitary students around and about.

Grand Opening of Chinese take out joint on South Broad Street, Trenton.  

It has a postage stamp size dining area with only 2 tables for eating in, and 3 chairs for waiting on take away.  The space is still clean and the kitchen shiny, as it has been open little more than a week.  

The menu is extensive and basically a traditional Chinese/American emporium.  Nothing authentic, but if you wanted really good Chinois you would not be parking your wheels on S. Broad in the first place.  My Orange Flavored Chicken was a load in the styro container they give to even those who eat in.  The chicken was fresh enough, and had not been deeply frozen.  The sauce was gloopy orange colored, although the taste of the citrus was weak, despite the orange peel in the mix.  The Fried Rice was a bright yellow from the dye used in the bullion stock that morning.  It had plenty of roast pork and veggies in it, but I did not see much (if any) egg scrambled into it.  

The people here are Fuzhounese, the province just north of old Canton, and across the straits from Taiwan.  Their cuisine is similar to Cantonese, but has some other influences.  It tends toward less sweetness, but close enough to allow for success in the Chinese take out wars.  

If you are interested, go soon while everything is new and clean.  The owners are there and take an interest in getting things right.  Just remember what you are dealing with, and you will not be disappointed.

PRO TIP - They don't serve hot tea!

Solid Chinese/American house in Lalor Plaza. 20 years at this nearly invisible location. Owners are friendly and hard working.  The shop could be cleaner and the supplies stored out of sight, but the grub is reliable, if not exceptional.  
While it will not become a standby option, it is worth remembering it is there for that time when the yen for Egg Foo Young or Sweet & Sour Pork overcomes you.

Some specifics - My Wonton Soup with the lunch combo was low average.  While the broth was standard, the wontons had exceptionally thick skin which detracted from the overall enjoyment of the bowl.  The Egg Foo Young was better, with fresh veggies and a decent brown sauce.  I don't know if they make their own wontons, but these had a very familiar feel to them, suggesting mass production from an outside vendor.  

While a dive, once accepted as such, the experience was fine.

I don't know why this Rite Aid was so difficult to find on Yelp*, but it finally showed up.

Drug stores today have morphed from the corner mom and pop shop into a semi - big box convenience store that also sells prescription medications along with food, drink, and photo services.  It must be working as these modern day behemoths are spreading like a bad cold (poor pun).  

This one does a decent job getting my prescriptions out quickly, and the drive thru option is a nice touch for those unable to park a car or walk into the store.  The crew is friendly and helpful.  Too, I have been known to pick up a chocolate bar in the candy isle, and a birthday card in the excessively large greeting card isle.  

I bow to modernity, although I miss the personal touch of the old fashioned Rexall (now a cool Starbucks here in Newtown).

Apple Cleaners is located in Goodnoe Corner on Sycamore Street, Newtown.  In a previous incarnation an office supply store occupied this space very close to The Green Parrot. 
I don't claim any special expertise when it comes to professional cleaners.  I just want my shirts and pants done well and ready when I come to claim them.  Apple has been keeping me satisfied for the time they have been here.  The customer service is friendly, and they can remove spots that are pointed out to them. 
Oh, and they seldom return my dress shirts with broken buttons; one of my serious peeves. 
I offer three stars because although I am quite happy with Apple, I am not sure that being a "Fan" or having an orgasm (Woohoo!) really expresses the more moderate emotional response I have to a clean shirt.

Empress Garden is a small shop on N. 10th Street in Chinatown, Philly, that changed hands about a year ago.  The original owner (the "Empress"), was a sterling hostess and stunning beauty who ran her house efficiently and with admirable warmth.  The food had a Taiwanese and Indonesian orientation, but also had the standard American/Chinese dishes for those who preferred them.  Their fruit drinks were freshly squeezed, and it had a strong following. 

I returned after an absence of a few years, and my first run with the new operation.  While the menu was basically the same as before, the actual plates coming from the kitchen seemed to have lost a bit of their edge.  We ordered Scallion Pancakes, Curry Chicken with Onions, Salt & Pepper Pork Chops, Orange Beef and Sautéed String Beans.  A lot for the three of us to consume, but we were looking forward to bring the balance home.  

While the Scallion Pancakes were good, they are certainly returned to the norm, and were not as exceptional as remembered.  The Chicken dish had the right taste and fresh chicken, but the Onions were harder than desired, and thus tended to dominate the dish.  The S & P Pork Chops had been a wonderful platter in the past, but this day the breading and meat was over-deep fried, making it tougher in the bite, and less enjoyable in the chew.  Disappointing.  The Orange Beef was the best thing on our table, with a nice spicy, not overly gloopy, sauce.  It was fun to eat even with the orange peel in its soft non-burnt condition.  Finally, the Veggies were fine with a light Garlic finish.  

The meal was satisfactory, but not what I hoped for based on recollection.  Empress Garden was now just another Chinatown restaurant with a fair kitchen and price, but nothing to make it outstanding.

232 Corner Café (formerly Hogeland's) is a pleasant surprise. 

When the former luncheonette closed last year due to the landlord's expectation that this space would be taken over by a medical provider outpatient clinic at substantially higher rents, those of us who knew and loved the old gal were sad and disappointed.  It appeared to be the end of an iconic local institution that had been around, while changing hands, for nearly half a century.  Progress to some.  Loss of culture to others. 

The "best laid plans...sometimes go astray...", and when the plans for the medical facility shrunk to a smaller piece of the strip mall, this corner was not included.  All the fixtures remained intact, and a new business bloomed out of the ashes of the old. Ron now runs the operation, and at first blush, the new order of things feels much like the former enterprise.  The counter and tables are the same.  The grill and coffee brew where they sat before.  The menu has been updated, but the kitchen still puts out very good breakfasts (and lunches).  

My French Toast was done right.  The standard two slices were dipped in an egg/vanilla/cinnamon mix, and grilled expertly with caramelized edges.  The taste was what I wanted, and I appreciated that the "small stack" was now the main size for the plate.  A melt of butter; and splash of syrup, and I was a happy man.  The New England Roast Bunn drip java was hot, fresh and repeatedly refilled by Ron as he entertained the troops.  

232 Corner Café is a victory for the community.  Come on down and join in the celebration.

UPDATE - JULY 13, 2018: There are signs of change since the last time I was here for breakfast in 2016. They now use a generic food purveyor coffee rather than New England beans. Too, the quality of their Kaiser roll has declined to a soft unibread that lacks a crusty texture and is basically white bread stamped into the form of a roll. 
Considering a downgrade to 3 stars.

Thirty years ago when I first moved to Bucks County from Trenton, Aldo's was only All Star Pizza in the Village Shires Shopping Center.  A generation later it has expanded into a nice size full fledged Italian restaurant named after its founder.  This all happened gradually, and it seemed to reflect the overall growth of this area. Farms began to grow suburban housing developments. Those new folks needed local places to eat. Etc. The dinners were good, and we could walk there from home.  

Stopped in for lunch the other day with my bud, Phil.  I guess I was in a rediscovery mood, as I had just visited Not Just Wings in the same center the weekend before.  We opted for a couple of plain slices for Phil, and an Eggplant Parmiagana Sandwich on a torpedo roll for me.  

Phil knows from pizza (tomato pie) as he is from the Burg in Trenton.  I watched him hold each slice up to test their rigidity, and satisfied, devour them.  He smiled and said they were very good, but not like Papa used to make, or even his uncles DeLorenzo. 

 The Parm was large, crusty and sealed in melted Mozza.  It, too, was decent, especially the toasted roll which was a joy to eat.  The Eggplant itself was cut into long, thick pieces, and were still a bit firm to the bite.  I prefer them to be completely soft from being sautéed in light breading and olive oil before being torched in the pizza oven.  The Sauce was ok, but lacked a distinctive flavor.  I go for Eggplant Parm Sandys often, and this one passed the acceptable test, but did not stand out.  I would not rush back to have it again.  

I may return for dinner in the near future, as they still evoke fond memories.  When I do, I will update this review.  But, for now, Aldo's for lunch is simply Okay. However, I may take a cue from Phil and stick with slices.

This is a franchised large format Japanese Hibachi house that also offers sushi and a few "fusion" offerings from China and Thailand.  This style restaurant seems to be coming into fashion on the East Coast, although it is more played out on the Left Coast. 

This one is apparently under new management, and they are attempting to make the facility more comfortable and attractive.  They have done a good job on the creature comforts, and the service is also attentive, except for the minor language difficulties in understanding each other through the Korean and South Jerzee accents.  

I was the guest this night, and my hostess did all the ordering.  I opted for the sushi side of the joint, although the Hibachi room was more active and colorful, especially when they performed their volcano show with the ball of fire shooting into the air.  Luckily, we could see that from the safe distance on the far side of the room.  

The Clear Soup was quite good as part of the dinner package.  The Sashimi platter (Deluxe?) was ample with a nice variety of well sliced fresh fish.  They all had good taste, but I would have preferred them slightly cooler.  I tasted all the offerings, but was not feeling compelled to finish them.  The Rolls (Sorry. The names were not disclosed to me) were okay, but not exciting.  Typical sushi rolls, but why the chef put cream cheese in it is beyond me.  Do they even have that in Japan?  This is not something I would consider ordering on my own.  Maybe this is what is popular in this part of South Jersey, or because it is close to Philly, cream cheese is a concession to local culture. Fish and cream cheese? No. Thank you!

I was happy to have dinner with a friend, and content to let her treat in return for something I handled for her.  Still, something more authentically Japanese would tempt me more than this Korean version of an Americanized Japanese Hibachi/Sushi store.  It just didn't hang together for me.

Miami Beach has its Big Pink diner-esque food forum. Furlong has its Back to the 50's; a pink edifice loaded with nostalgia for days gone by when the Victrola and AM radio were the only ways to listen to contemporary music.  This place is replete with black and whites of Elvis and Marilyn, and the lesser lights of the mid-20th Century.

It is a breakfast/lunch emporium with a dozen or so booths and the same number of tables.  The coffee comes fast and furious, delivered by black clad waitresses calling everybody, "honey," "doll," or "sugarcakes."  Ya' gotta' luv it!

The breakfasts are pretty good, with many fresh fruit specials added to pancakes, waffles and French toast. Still, nothing that makes me want to rush back for more. 

Yu wan meat wid dat?

Big Q BBQ sits out in front of H Mart and looks like a weird Sonic Drive In. 

I've only sampled their wares once; buying a St. Louis Ribs dinner and Fried Chicken platter with sides of Chak & Meez and Baked Beans with Ends.  Waiting in the antechamber felt a bit odd because while there were plenty of people in gray shirts in the kitchen, I did not see anyone working with the food.  Too, as someone else mentioned, there was no odor of smoked meats, nor BBQ sauces, nor even of frying chicken.  It was almost as if the food was prepared elsewhere and shipped here for sale.  No smoker outside, either. 

The food is really just okay. The Chicken was the better of the main offerings.  The breasts were large and juicy, although the breading would have shone off with more spice.  The Ribs were dense and coated in a thick ruddy sauce, but it seemed that there was insufficient liquidity to really impact the meat.  It made for a dry texture with underwhelming flavor.  Knife and fork were helpful in separating meat from bone, and when gnawing at them with dirty fingers they were not particularly tender, but good enough to be worth the effort.  I prefer a looser presentation with more gravy, but that is a matter of taste.  

The sides were actually pretty good.  The Mac & Cheese was pretty much standard creamy fare, but the Beans were surprisingly hearty and well spiced.  

No rush to go back to Big Q, as there are better fried chicken places close by, and while a bit of up country driving is needed to find more authentic homespun Q, I would sooner cruise the countryside in search of that holy grail (or rack).

TJ Smith's on Easton Road near the border between Doylestown and Warrington gives the feel of a western mountain lodge - all exposed wood and stone, high vaulted ceilings and beams.  The bar room where we ate was spacious on a weekday afternoon, and the service was friendly and informative.  

We opted for their 4 beer sampler to go with their self-proclaimed famous burgers and a cheesesteak.  At $8.50 for the 3 oz. glasses, the price was about right, and the offerings of national brew was tasty and interesting, although 2 of them had a pumpkin component in honor of the season.  They were fine.  

The burgers were large (8 oz.) with the appropriate fixings, although both of them came out beyond the medium finish requested, which, with an empty house was hard to understand other than inattentiveness at the grill. Their tastes were good, and the beef had not been frozen.  The cheesesteak was average and clearly not their forte. 

Plenty of HDTVs everywhere for those who want sports stimulation while eating or drinking (this is a sports bar), but not so overwhelming as to be a distraction to conversation.  

Attractive house.  With more attention to detail, it could be an exceptional stop in an otherwise nondescript strip of Bucks County.

A convenient Star$$$$ for this part of the world, with access from both Street Road and Second Street Pike.  Its proximity to some of my favorite restaurants - Aroi Thai, Blue Sage and House of Pho - make it a perfect quick après dinner stop for hot brew on the way to the movies or home.  

It is not the most attractive franchise unit in the area, but it serves a functional purpose. 

Unlike a box of chocolates, you always know what you are going to get.

1911 Smoke House Barbeque sits on the red cobblestones that remains of Front Street, Trenton, NJ.  It is very close to the historic Trenton Barracks, where Washington surprised the Hessians on Christmas Day, and began the turn around in the fortunes of the American Revolution that ended with the United States of America.  As such, if you stop in for a drink and/or a meal, be sure to tip your glass to the memory of those heroes.

The bar/dining room is right as you walk in the door. It is small and cozy. In good weather there is a back patio that is a nice space to hang. We sat is a half booth close to the bar. Service was very friendly and informative. 

We ordered brisket, pulled pork sandwich and a third of a rack of ribs dinner with baked beans and mixed veggies. Each was pretty good, but none outstanding. They all needed help from the table rockets of sauces. Of those, the Hickory and 1911 were the best. When squirted up, the meats were more tasty and entertaining. The ribs were partially over grilled so that half of the three were charred and carbonized to a hard shell. Gave my molars a crunchy workout. The beans had been sitting around too long and lacked moisture. The veggies we're ample, but bland. 

While we liked the place, and that it is close to my office, we agreed that the Q was less than hoped for, and that we have had better recently at several places.

Maybe it was just an off night.

Some say it is better to look good than to taste good. For those few, Brown's Bakery in Dublin, PA, is for you. 

A small shop with one community table, two deuces, and a tiny display case, there were beautiful pastries, donuts and cakes to see, but their tastiness was very much hit or miss. I was excited to finally visit, and although I was there shortly after noon, there was still ample choices available. I selected a half dozen donuts (old fashioned sour cream, glazed), coffeecake mini, brownie and sugar/cinnamon stick. The ten pieces came to $10 and change. Not unreasonable. 

I was 30 minutes from home, and I drove expectantly delaying gratification until I could brew fresh coffee and relax over my sweet score. Upon opening the taped box I beheld the beauties until deciding which to eat first. The sour cream cake donut with the cracks coated in glaze came first. I bent and broke it in half to better fit into my mouth. 

First bite was nice as the flavor of the icing and texture of the cake unveiled. Immediately thereafter I noticed that the foundational base was not completely fresh, but somewhat dry and becoming stale. Too, the flavor of the glaze was not what I anticipated, but a strange tone of sweetness unlike anything I had tasted. It wasn't bad, but it was less enjoyable than traditional dip. The same was true of the standard glaze siblings. Not completely at their peak, and the same weird flavor. 

On the other hand, both the brownie and coffeecake were very good. The chocolate moist, rich semisweet and nicely chewy. The coffeecake chunky brown sugar, cinnamon and powdered sugar on top of a small rectangular pound cake base. Liked them alot.

What to make of this mixed box? Hard to timestamp a pastry or donut. But, it is necessary to inquire about the age of their wares in order to avoid the suboptimal components. I have never done that, still if aging products are for sale it is necessary to be alert to this and do your due diligence.

I am slowly warming up to Newtown Bagel Company.  Over the past year I have stopped in a few times due to its proximity to my office, and find that the continuously gracious management is winning me over. 

The bagels have not changed, and I wish they would find out how to make the crust a little crunchy, but as I have eaten several I find them more acceptable.  They are always fresh and have a good chew once the crust is penetrated.  The coffee is still good.  Now, if they offered hot oatmeal on cold winter morning, I could become a real fan. 

For now, the reality that I visit here about once a month indicates that I am satisfied with the overall experience, and should reflect my changing opinion with a third star.

Rosemary's Grill is deceptively large inside, but gives the impression of a traditional diner in a non-traditional structure.  It lacks a counter and stools, which would provide a whole lot more charm than the current environment, which although clean, is all earth tones and lavender and has a dreary feel to it. 

I had to inquire about the Greek/Middle Eastern menu, as it was not provided with the main handout.  Too, said menu did not list the Gyro Pita, but required that it be asked for in order to know it was available.  I found that odd, except when I realized that most other things on the menu were more expensive that the gyro.  As I was there at lunchtime, the absence of the most popular dish in the reviews was dubious.  Oversight, or intentional subtle upsell? 

The service was very good.  The Lamb Gyro was excellent with well grilled lamb slivers mixed with lettuce, onion, cucumber and yogurt dill sauce.  The pita was hot and the entire presentation attractive.  Even the frozen fries were okay.  

While I will keep Rosemary's in mind when in the vicinity and in need of sustenance, it will not be a primary source for a Mediterranean style meal.  I have too many questions about the above issues, and there is too much strong competition nearby to put Rosemary on my speed dating list.

Many years since I last visited this IHOP at the intersection of North Olden Avenue Extension and Parkway Avenue, Ewing, NJ.  It looks about the same on the outside, but there has been a modest makeover within making the space appear brighter and renewed.  The greeting by the staff was legit friendly, and the care provided throughout breakfast was very good. One of the servers actually came over to me to compliment me on my watch.  That is a very rare occurrence. 

I ordered the brioche French toast from the griddle menu.  At $6.99 is seemed reasonable.  The carafe of coffee was another $2.49 for a bottomless mug.  Still, getting out from a full breakfast for under $10, was appreciated.  Yet, there must have been a little communication problem with I did not catch until my food was served.  My very pleasant server came back to me after ordering to ask if I wanted blueberries or peaches with my breakfast.  I hadn't originally asked for that. Nothing was said about an up charge, and I thought it was something everyone was offered with this meal.  In fact, it wasn't.  The extra canned peaches, caramel-like syrup and dollop of whipped cream was another buck fifty.  No biggie, but I would have preferred to be told the complete deal.  

The food itself was good, but too sweet with the syrup they drowned the bread with.  I have a lighter touch on breakfast syrup.  

I would return, but be sure to be prepared for the attempt to upcharge for extras I really did not need.

Gibby's is another of the 1950's style ice cream houses that dot lower Bucks County.  It is all glass, stainless and jutting ascending red roofline, staffed by high school cuties that bring the innocence necessary for a complete summer childhood reverie.  It sits at the bottom of Veterans Highway, just south of New Falls Road in Levittown, PA., across from a long row of old strip commercial drive ups that help complete the sense that you are more than just an ice cream licker, but also a time traveler.  

The Store carries mostly hard 'scream, with a nod to vanilla and chocolate soft serve. Given the lack of choice compared to its siblings in the area that offer at least a few more soft flavors, I went with Black Raspberry and Butter Pecan in a medium paper cup.  At $3.50, it was a steal, or more accurately, confirmation that I had entered 1976.  

The only real issue here is that the creme glace was not as good as the other joints in the area.  Not sure who makes their brand, but it had a flat taste; nor was it as creamy and sweet as expected.  The Butter Pecan had fewer nutty implants, and lacked the mild saltiness of the pecan that so well offsets the usual sugar rush on the tongue.  The Black Raspberry had a mildly tart afterbite. Not bad, but had me wondering why it was there.  

After the individual scoops melted and merged into each other, it was more enjoyable.  Still, not the heavy smooth happy zazz found in Jo-Jo's, nor the amazing cool creaminess of Dairy Delight.

Royal Chef is much bigger inside than it appears from outside. There are actually ten tables for dining in, so it is more than just a takeout joint. I stopped in for a late lunch and ordered from the lunch menu (General Tso's Chicken, Fried Rice, Broccoli with a bowl of Wonton Soup).

The soup was actually the strongest part of the lunch. The chicken consume base was tasty, and the wontons, although somewhat thick skinned, actually had a decent flavor, too. The general's chicken was a large mound of amber glossed bird nuggets. About half of them were the right texture and taste, while the others were either too thickly skinned, or too crunchy to enjoy. Could not always taste the meat within. The fried rice was a large helping with adequate veggies to keep it interesting. Of course, the broccoli florets were there for decoration more than consumption. 

The meal was just okay overall.  I appreciated that there was a dining room where I could sit and eat lunch.  It would have been even better if they used real plates and flatware, rather than styro and plastic, and a take out container for the soup.  Service was provided by the cashier who was attractive and pleasant to all customers.  

The sign out front is worn and faded, and could use a little TLC to keep the shop from looking worse than it is. A little fresh paint and relettering would make China Chef a more upbeat place to chow down (no pun intended).

Ray's Sub Shop on Pennington Road in Ewing, NJ mainly serves the college crowd from the College of New Jersey up the street from there. It is a small store with six tables and a substantial menu of sandwiches, wraps, subs, burgers, etc. There are several lunch specials available daily which make for an economical meal.  They use Dietz & Watson delicatessen smoked meats and cheeses, and pretty good hoagie rolls. 

My honey turkey and swiss submarine was large and tasty, with plenty of meat, cheese, lettuce and tomato. I nixed the onions. I couldn't finish it.  No complaints. With a bottle of Stewart's, it came to about $8.  Good price.  

The only downside happened when I went to the cashier in the rear of the store, and looked over at the small grill used to prepare the hot sandwiches and burgers.  It was very dirty, and actually left an unpleasant odor in that part of the joint. I would not be ordering anything that required time on that hot iron.  Too, the sole garbage container was overfull when I tried to put my trash in it.  Someone should be watching for that and replace the trash bags before this happens.  

More attention to detail would go a long way. 

2.5 Stars, because cleanliness is important.

This is a first time for me visiting a take out only Pizza Hut.  Walking in, there was a counter for ordering, and the long conveyor belt oven for baking the pies.  The three workers there seem primarily involved in the preparation of the food, although someone came out to either take a walk up  order, or to hand over the boxed food if ordered online.  

We had ordered through the internet from the not totally user friendly Pizza Hut app.  I finally figured out how to get it done, and requested the large Traditional Pan Pizza with half Mushroom and half Italian Sausage be ready for us by 6:00.  

When we arrived at 5:55, the pizza was busy baking and we were told it would be ready shortly.  It was.  We saw it emerge from the oven (see pic).  I had ordered the Fire Spice finish for the crust, so we watched as one of the assembly dudes painted on some oil around the circumference of the wheel and then sprinkled on crushed red pepper.  He then cut it up with a semi-circular blade, and slid it into its box.  The internet price was $7.99, which is very hard to beat.  

How was it?  The deep dish values of a thicker crust were obvious, although it could have used more baking on the under carriage to make it more well done.  The topside was loaded with our requested shrooms and sausage, and well baked to a nice melt.  It would seem that a small oven adjustment to increase the heat on the bottom and reduce it on top would result in a better finished product, if that is possible.  Taste was decent, but due to the above heat distribution, its texture was a bit off, and the bottom crust not crisp enough.  

Health code wise, it was apparent that no one was using latex gloves for the food prep.  That was a violation and a turn off.  There is plenty of better pizza in the area, not to mention across the mighty Delaware River.  This place will do in a pinch.

I totally get the cult of Federal Donuts; the lovechild of Zahav and Percy Street BBQ.  

The old corner shop is in a warren of narrow old streets in Pennsport, and the space itself has a tiny charm that could easily be a time warp to the 18th Century.  Standing in line or waiting for an order creates a sense that time has slowed down, and even the dust in the sunbeams may have danced for our forefathers. The combination of Korean style double fried chicken and deep dive dough balls is a natural fit for preparation, but I am not yet comfortable eating both at the same seating. The double dose of fats challenges my guilt. 

When we arrived mid-Saturday afternoon, all of the fancies were gone, but the 3 daily offerings were available.  Folks were gnawing on their chicken bones at the counter, blissful in their enjoyment.  We ordered a half doz mix of Vanilla Spice, Maple Brown Sugar and Strawberry Lavender to take with us on the drive home.  They were individually bagged while hot, and placed in a larger paper bag, and ultimately triple bagged in a plastic take out carrier.  

Opening the package, the heat and moisture has made the paper sacks damp, but still held in plenty of the essence of the dough wheels. We tried a Vanilla Spice.  It was covered in sugar and cinnamon, cake-like, and uber sweet. The bite and chew was pleasant, but there was no crispness due to the water vapors.  Very tasty.  A very good donut.  Over the next day, the rest were devoured, and although the taste varied with content, the general experience was the same.  A nice round piece of cake with a hole in the middle. 

Federal Donuts deserves another house call earlier in the day when the fancies are in stock, and again for a unique fried chicken experience, which seems as varied as the sweet fat tires. 
After those ingestions, an update will be in order. 

Until then, the consumed donuts themselves were not life altering, but were certain A-Okay!

The Golden Eagle Diner at the intersection of Route 13 and Bath Road, Bristol, PA, is an attractive renovated traditional roadside food emporium with extensive menu. On this Saturday morning it was bustling, and I sat at the small counter that serves as both a place to eat and their bar for drinks. As I supped on a morning omelette, the folks next to me sipped on Bloody Marys.  

I ordered the Old Country Omelette (onion, green pepper, tomato, bacon, ham & sausage), side of home fries, rye toast) and Lacas perked coffee. It took a while for a server to notice me and begin service, but I was in no hurry. When she finally stopped by to help, she didn't hear me ask her to hold the ham. No biggie. But, it took her until I was almost completely finished with my meal to inquire how I was doing. I had already asked the floor manager for a caffeine refill, which he provided after bartending the first Bloody Mary.

Gratitude, my good man. 

The only things missing on this weekend before Christmas were smiles on any of the faces working there. No one seemed happily employed, and they seemed incapable of offering even a glimpse of happiness to their customers for being there. They felt oppressed by something or someone. Though I deal with people's problems professionally, I didn't want to make theirs mine on my day off. 

So, I ate quietly, sipped my coffee when it arrived and left when the mug was half full.

When the sign on the front door says, "DO NOT ENTER WITH HOODIE OR MASK...IF SO YOU ARE NOW TRESPASSING," you know there is a fundamental problem being expressed by management.  This isn't the best neighborhood in the Capital City, in fact, it is one of the worst. I wouldn't be found here at night, but for a quick lunch with parking right out front, and Trenton's finest stopping in for take out, I felt pretty safe as I dined on my Eggplant Parm Sandwich.  

The loaf was fresh, mildly crunchy and had a good mild yeasty flavor.  The Eggplant had been sautéed in a frying pan with extra virgin olive oil before being finished in the pizza oven to melt the cheese and seal the final product.  It was a good sandwich, even if not the lunch of the gods. 

Service was friendly, if a little jumpy.  Only four booths for eating in.  Same ownership for 23 years.  

I guess they have seen the hood change during that time.  How many holdups before the sign went up?  

No doubt, one was enough.

I have been on a fried chicken binge lately, and when in that frame of mind any source of crispy skinned plump breasted chicken can capture my attention. Popeye's is no exception. 

So it was, as I drove over to Prince's to give it another try, that I saw the bright orange sign and building for the Popeye's on North Olden.  Impulse got the better of me and I made the hard left into their drive thru line.  I had difficulty deciphering the menu, so I just ordered a few pieces breasts and wings. Seems I had to order a side and a drink or they couldn't handle my order. It turned out to be cheaper if I did one of their combos rather than just individual pieces. 

When I arrived home and opened the box I beheld a large breast and wing that were bigger than I had seen on most chickens. It had me wondering what they feed those birds. The coating was as bright orange as the box it came in, and deeply textured.  Perhaps, the cumin and chili in the Spicy option affected the presentation. 

The meat was still moist and very tasty.  Each piece was much larger than what I had sampled at the other place the week before.  The chicken easily parted from the bone and my fingers pulled off most of what was edible.  The rest I worked over with a fork to get into all the bone crannies. 

The side dish (coleslaw) was pedestrian, and the biscuit was fairly deflated by the time I  got to it.  So, the thing to do is order the combo, throw away the sides and biscuit and go to town on the chicken itself.  

It may not be the same as what is available in those little chicken shacks on the side of the road in Virginia or North Carolina, but it will do nicely up in Jersey on a wintery night.

Visiting this McDonald franchise on S. Oxford Valley Road in Fairless Hills, Pa., was the first time that the drive up experience took me by surprise.  

First, the voice taking orders was amazingly pleasant.  She seemed to be into her job and sincerely asked how I was doing, and how she could help.  The repartee was longer than expected, and warm throughout.  She didn't seem fazed that I was ordering a small meal off the Cheapo menu, and that the items cost less than $4.  

Second, this was the first fast food interaction where I was handed a separate plastic bag with napkins and straw.  Someone realized that cleanliness and ease of transfer were important.  So much better than finding those things stuffed into the bag, or worse, not provided at all.  

These made for a positive impression of this Mickey D's, and would have led to a higher star rank had the actual Double Cheese Burger been hot off the grill.  Not even close.  Barely lukewarm.  McDonald's burgers are not good enough to be enjoyed at low temp.  Their components start separating and the taste/texture is disjointed.

But, if they ever get that part right, this shop would really stand out.

Mario's sits on East State Street Extension, west of the I-95 underpass; an area of Hamilton where I rarely go because it feels a bit isolated. Glad I put on my big boy pants and drove out there for lunch Friday afternoon, because it is a nice shop with everything made in house, and friendly folks. 

I sat at one of the few booths, in sight of the HDTV showing Trump's inauguration with commentary. Ordered the eggplant parmesan sandwich, and pulled a Coke Zero from the cooler. Even got to read the complementary Trentonian rag that was on my table. 

The hot sandwich was a foot long, cut in half, and loaded with thin slices of breadcrumb coated, olive oil pan sauteed, deep purple nightshade. It was topped with a layer of mozza and finally a thick chunky red gravy. It was so big, I decided to use knife and fork rather than attempt direct oral assault. It was delicious and filling. I should have asked for extra sauce on the side, because the eggplant overwhelmed the top dressing, and more dipping would have made the lunch even better. Not complaining. It was excellent. I chose to leave most of the roll aside so I could concentrate on the prize. 

Will return for their pizza and tomato pie and revisit Mario's star power, without the political commentary.

The layout is the mirror image of The Home Depot I visit most often, but it only required a second to figure that out.  The orange aprons were friendly and helpful.  We found what we needed, and after reading a few of the labels, made a choice in remote garage openers (serious shit, I know!). After we got it home and read the fine print inside the packaging, I realized that my machines are antiques and several generations behind contemporary technology.  Seems 1993 was the cut off date for the latest radio frequency devices, while mine are a few years older.  How can such things that still work well be obsolete? 

So, had to return it today to my local THD, and go with the Genie brand, which, after all, were the ones I installed originally.  Only they make the expensive key to maintain their own stuff. 

Should have the code mastered soon, and have two functioning remote door openers to allow for ease of access and egress for both old and new(er) vehicles. 

Now I know more than I ever wanted to know about remote garage door openers. 

 Ah, wisdom!

It seems that Pho Tan, the first and only Vietnamese pho house in Trenton, NJ, has been sold, and is now under new management.  "Pho Friendly," is a catchy name, and hopefully its positive personality carries with it both the good will of the old shop, and the high expectations of the new.  

I stopped in yesterday on my way to visit a client at his home.  They are in the same neighborhood.  Driving by, I saw the new sign hanging over the storefront and was immediate both sad and curious.  Street parking can be a problem, but I found space right around the corner, walked back and went in.  Looked exactly the same as before (it was a Mexican resto before it went Asian).  The menu was identical.  There were new handwritten signs on the walls saying, " We Have Hoagies. $5."  I love the traditional Banh Mi sandwich, so I asked the woman who greeted me if they made them.  She pointed to the sign and nodded her head.  

A keener mind might have thought to confirm that their hoagie was in fact the same as the Banh Mi.  I did not ask for clarification, and ordered a chicken version with the vision that it would be all dressed up in a French Baguette, with daikon, cilantro, jalapeno, etc. 

Not exactly. 

Rather, it was more of a chicken steak sandwich with a twist.  Plenty of sliced bird bathed in Hoisin Sauce, with medallions of cucumber, sautéed onions & green pepper, with some Sriracha mayo, in a poor quality hoagie roll that lacked any crispness or good texture.  No daikon, cilantro, jalapeno to be found.  

Disappointing. It wasn't bad, but not what I was looking forward to. 

I did not try the namesake pho, so it is possible they do that well enough to redeem themselves.  In truth, I should have been more alert to the fact that they now advertise themselves as offering Thai and Chinese food in addition to Viet.  I would venture a guess that the lovely proprietress who served me (and her husband) are Chinese, and are attempting a "fusion" house, but with Chinese culinary sensibilities.  That is not necessarily a bad thing, but it does require the customer to find out what they really do best. Obviously, it isn't Banh Mi.

2.5 Stars with a dose of disappointment.

Hing Wah is a Chinese take out house on New Falls Road, Levittown, PA, that also has a couple of tables for those who prefer to eat in while the food is optimal. It is fairly representative of the genre, with a menu that you could have memorized from most others you have tried in life. Only significant difference was the friendliness of the owners, both of whom engaged in small talk with me both before and after the meal. Nice folks.

My lunch special consisted of wonton soup, pork fried rice and general tso's chicken. The consommé was standard chicken stock with two thick skinned wontons and fresh cut scallion greens. No pork or other floaties to be found. Still, it was unobjectionable, even if unimaginative. The fried rice was dyed dark yellow, but had enough veggies mixed in to keep it interesting. The general would have been satisfied as I was, with the quantity of the chicken morsels breaded and deep fried with a dark red amber goop slathered on top.  There were actual Szechuan red chili peppers within adding to the pleasurable heat encountered with each bite. The breading was reasonable and did not overwhelm the bird beneath. 

For around $7 plus tax, lunch was decent and a reasonable value proposition. It fulfilled my weekly yen for typical Chinese/American grub.

New King Wok is a pretty much average Chinois restaurant on Bensalem Road right next door to Bagelocity/Soup Kitchen. Nice to have the convenience of grabbing the necessities of life (bagels & fried rice) in one stop. 

There are only four tables in the house, so it is primarily a takeaway joint, but I prefer to sit and eat while the wok burn is paramount. Folks are a husband wife team, with the old man at the stove and frau tickling the register keys. She is friendly and bilingual. As a first timer, I ordered the General Tso's Chicken lunch special, which came with choice of rice and egg roll or cold drink bottle. I asked for it extra spicy. 

It arrived in take out regalia on a plastic tray; thin white fork on the side. The tso sauce was a beautiful red amber color that matched well with the hyper yellow of the fried rice. There were a few Szechuan peppers thrown in in answer to my request. It was thick, but had decent flavor. The chicken was over-breaded, making for unnecessary heaviness. Had it been thinner, it could have been a contender for a surprisingly good rendition. As it was, it was about average for the genre. I left most of the rice behind as it made too long before my arrival. 

This wasn't a bad meal, but it could have been alot better given the apparent skill level in the kitchen.

Solid new Casa Mexicana on Markley Street, right in front of El Primo Mercado and Cafe. Limited parking in front, with much more behind. Bright and colorful with a limited menu of their greatest hits. Friendly, efficient service from the lovely woman working the floor. 

I ordered their Cemita Poblano Torta, a supersized fresh sesame seeded roll full of spicy ground beef, queso fresca, lettuce, red salsa, al pastor style. It was a huge work of edible art. Hot bites and I could only manage to consume half while sitting at a high top table. Took the rest home. 

They did bring two bowls of red/green salsa to me, but the chips never arrived. On the other hand their horchata was a chill, refreshing and cinnamon flavored liter of strong slurp. At $2 for the "small" size, it was the bargain of the day.  

Given a choice between this "Mexico City Woman" restaurant and El Primo about 100 feet away, I would go with El Primo based on more choices and stronger kitchen talent, although the former rice drink was more flavorful than the later. 

Norristown and environs continues to impress with its broad array of comidas Latina Americanas.

This newest Trenton McDonald's is located on Chambers Street, catty corner from St. Francis Medical Center and across the street from Trenton Central High School.  Pretty good location. 

It is one of the newer designed, small footprint stores, with wrap around, two lane, drive thru.  They really expect most of their business to stay outside.  They are friendly and efficient at what they do. But, if you are a pedestrian, be careful approaching the front door as there will be traffic bearing down on you, with drivers not necessarily paying attention to your presence.  

The food is standard Mickey fare.  I am more fond of their breakfast sandwiches than the burgers.  I grabbed a sausage, egg & cheese biscuit and large coffee on my way to the office.  Priced at just over $5., it was a reasonable deal.  The meal was freshly made, with tender, buttery biscuit and still hot patty.  The coffee has been pretty good lately, and the one price of any size is a clever marketing tool.  

Breakfast @ desk is not my favorite way to eat, but some days it can be like that.  

Everything was satisfactory.

Franco's Tomato Pies on Main Street, Yardley, PA, has been around for a long while doing mostly take out pizzas from their small shop right next door to Bagel Train. There are only two booths in house, so they don't get much dine in business. Still, I was there around 2:30 in the afternoon earlier this week, and wanted carbs to help finish my long day into night schedule. 

I asked if I could eat there, and they were totally accommodating. I ordered penne aglio olio with sautéed spinach in a lunch portion, and they knew what to do. After about 5 minutes I was called to the counter to pick up a side salad and bread basket. The greens were plentiful, with tomato wedges, iceberg, red onion, cukes and sliced carrots. Actually, took me by surprise. The four slices of Italian loaf were fresh and ready for dipping into balsamic vinaigrette and the garlicy broth to come at the bottom of the pasta bowl. 

A few minutes later, the white soup bowl of pasta was on the counter calling my name. I walked over to get it, and enjoyed the hot garlic breath of the dish wafting into my face. Smelled so good. The taste was about right, too. Plenty of pencil points under a nice load of soft spinach. The garlic could have been more golden, but no biggie.

The only difficulty I confronted was the large pond of garlic water under the pasta. No matter how long I waited to allow the water to drain from each forkful, it was still dripping onto my shirt, pants and tie. I was careful, but all will be visiting the cleaners to get the stains out. My bad for not bringing a long bib. 

The store needed a strong cleaning, too. The floor looked grimy from lack of care, and the kitchen area visible from the counter failed the visual inspection test. Looks like the boss doesn't stop in often enough.

Kasdon's Restaurant & Tavern on New Falls Road, Levittown, is one of many such places in this area of Lower Bucks County.  It has been around since the 1950's, and maintains the feel of a dark, knotty pine hall, with decent kitchen and fair prices on drinks.  There are HDTVs on every wall in the bar and dining room, so it is definitely a sports bar, too.  

On a weeknight the rectangular bar has several couples sitting around having dinner and  drinks.  The dining area was lightly populated with a few families in booths or tables.  It was both a young and old crowd, but as it seemed to be smoke free, it wasn't conducive to the rowdy bunch often found across the street.  

The beer on tap is limited to basic American suds, but that is not a problem for the folks here.  Yuengling Lager was about as exotic as it got.  Still, at a couple of bucks for a pint I wasn't complaining.  The same holds for the kitchen offerings.  Several pages of standard American fare, including pizza, burgers, sandwiches and a long list of diner-esque dishes.  My Patty Melt was decent, but served naked on the plate, without even chips or pickle.  At a price shy of $7., I certainly received what I paid for.  

Kasdon's has been around for a while, and it shows in the décor and long term servers/tenders.  It is a relatively safe place for a few drinks, chow and conversation with the people at and within the bar.  Families are also welcome.  

After a few stops at the lanes nearby, where the crowd can be loud and obnoxious (although with better grub), Kasdon's feels to be a safe harbor.

There are two entries for this supermarket, the other being, "McCaffery's Supermarket." 

Same store. Same experience. 

Slightly upscale compared to the nearest competition, Acme and Giant, but not up to the quality and gestalt of the Wegman's, Whole Foods, and Trader Joe's of the world. Have to wonder what would happen if one of those retailers came to Ntown, which has been discussed, but not yet evolved into a real plan.  
 
This shop has the mandatory Starbucks, and a pretty good produce department.  The rest is the same as everyone else. Close your eyes and open them again, and you could be in any generic supermarket in the USA.  No better. No worse. At least you know where everything is. 

Definitely, middle of the road grocery experience.

When you live in or near Washington Crossing, and it is not permitted to build a commercial area that would be large enough to contain a supermarket, what you are left with is Colonial Farms, a convenience store sized, high end deli.  

Here, you pay for the convenience of not having to drive up to Newtown to shop.  And, it fits into the atmosphere in Wash X that it is a bedroom community for high wage earners who prefer their town just as it is.  To each his/her own.  Colonial Farms caters to this community and does a fairly good job of it.  

The bakery usually has very good muffins and other sweet goodies.  The deli makes really good sandwiches and salads, and the rest of the store is stocked with the basics needed to prepare your next meal.  But, don't make the mistake of thinking this store is all you need on an every day basis.  It is too small and select for that.  For large shopping excursions you still need to find an Acme, or Whole Foods or Wegmans, etc., to get broader choice and better price.   

Still, for that morning coffee and breakfast sandwich, or a quick stop for a much better than Wawa customized lunch, or just to buzz in for a European chocolate bar, Colonial Farms be the place.

I have returned to McC's a few times since my last review in January, 2013, and have noticed a general improvement in the offerings, marketing, and prices.  While still tending to the more expensive side compared to the competition, it is now possible to find items on sale of more than a nickel off the normal retail price, and the staff seems to have grown into their new surroundings in Newtown, and are more friendly, courteous and knowledgeable.  

It is still not my first choice for groceries (have to go to Trader Joe's and Wegman's in Lawrenceville, New Jersey for that), but I am willing to visit here for the things the family needs without gritting my teeth with self loathing.

Still wish they carried Finlandia Swiss and a few other non-Boars Head deli products, but I am learning to live with that, as it seems the others supermarkets in Newtown have cut the same deal with that company.  

Time for a raise.  Three Stars.

Old Style pizza joint with a broader menu to attract more diners into their cozy dining room.  

Problem is that while the Tomato Pie and the other spinning disks are very good, the same cannot be said for the rest of the in house cuisine.  This was my first visit to Palermo's III after visiting the others in Hamilton and Bordentown.  

The Tomato Pie is thin, crisp and nicely spiced here, but if forced to compare with its former siblings, it would come behind the Bordentown establishment for quality pies.  We also ordered a family sized Caesar Salad and Sautéed Spinach as a side dish to get in our veggies for the day.  

The Salad was just okay with nice Romaine, Shaved Carrots, Onion and Croutons.  However, the dressing came in a small plastic container and was mass produced and lacking in true Caesar flavor (no anchovy taste).  The Spinach was definitely from the freezer and was a watery tasteless waste to eat.  Very disappointing, and not worth the $6, by half. 

Lesson learned. Stick to the pizza and tomato pies, and leave the rest to those who don't know better.

Haley's Homemade Sandwiches sits way up Parkway Avenue on the way to Trenton-Mercer Airport.  It is a quick jump stop off Rt. 95.  I stopped in last week to check it out and pick up a sandwich to take to the office.  

Walking in, the first impression is of many tables in front of a large kitchen work area.  People were enjoying their meals, and there was a busy take out trade.  Large refrigeration units were around for a "take your own drink" approach to service. The staff seemed mostly college folk.  They were friendly and attentive, if a bit sloppily garbed for the customer service end of the business.  

I ordered a Chicken Salad with Swiss Sub on a Sesame Seed Torpedo.  It was prepared quickly and presented to me already wrapped in white paper and sealed with tape.  When I reached the office, I opened it up to see a nice sized hoagie with plenty of chicken salad, cheese, sweet hot peppers and lettuce.  This was two meals.  I immediately appreciated the cost factor.  The first bite told me the roll was good quality and fresh.  The chicken was also of very recent vintage with large chunks in light mayo.  The Swiss had a pleasing tart nuttiness, and the peppers added an element of caliente zest. All in all, a pretty good sandy.  Compared to an alternative like Primo's, Haley's was better to my taste.  

Haley's won't be part of my regular lunch rotation due to location and comparatives.  However, I will have no hesitancy returning there when the mood strikes, and sample other savories from his menu.  The Cheesesteaks seemed to be popular when I was there, and the people eating there, quite comfortable.

Pleasant environment for a first lunch at Vietnam Restaurant on 11th Street. 
Dark wood tones, extensive menu, and apparently, a good bar.  

My lunch was simple; Pho Tai.  The bowl was smaller than at other VN locales, but tasty and well presented with a full plate of accessories (spouts, lime, jalapenos,basil leaves).  The flank steak was thin and lean.  The broth as doctored at the table, spicy and engaging.  The noodles, soft and of adequate volume.  At $6.95, it was exactly what I wanted for a light lunch.

The Vietnamese coffee was also very satisfying.  

I need to visit a few more times and try more on the menu before coming to a final opinion on this pleasant fixture on the edge of Chinatown.

Morrisville has a surprising number of luncheonette and deli places that turn out a broad variety of primarily breakfast and lunch dishes.  Always on the lookout for an easier way to get into Trenton on a weekday, the Morrisville-Trenton crossings are often the least trafficked.  On my way, I like to stop for breakfast when time permits, and hit the bridges around 8:45 when the flow of cars improves. 

So, I recently found Ben's Delicatessen on Bridge Street just a hop, skip and jump from the Trenton Makes Bridge.  Parking is fairly easy with a side parking lot, and once inside the ordering/paying/take away system is very efficient.  They def have it down to a tight discipline.  The crowd is primarily dudes in work boots and company logo shirts, with a few local office or retail folks thrown in.  I was the only suit. 

I ordered their 4 piece French Toast, thinking it would be two halved slices of bread at the ridic price of $3.95.  Wrong.  It was four full slices.  Pleasant surprise.  I stood near the short order grill and watched the spatula man work at hyper speed to get the orders out and moved down the conveyor line to the packer and cashier.  Luckily, I was not overly concerned with the fact that a large coil of pork sausage was its neighbor on the grill, sharing its oozing juices with my egg soaked bread.  

When I finally took possession of my meal, it was tossed on a styro plate, and placed on a plastic tray for me to carry to a table.  Plastic utensils completed the composition.  The bottom of the plate was not flat, and as I tried to cut the toast with fork and knife, it would spin on the tray, making surgical precision impossible.  The cook clearly did not have a concern for creating a quality dish, as the toast had an eggy top with dry center, suggesting insufficient time in pre-grill soak and absorption.   It was low average at best.  The coffee was fine.  

Given what I saw of the operation as I waited, I realized that breakfast sandwiches were the way to go here, and I will return to give one a try.  Clearly, Ben's is a beehive of activity in the morning, and has a loyal following.  For now, it deserves the benefit of the doubt that most of what they do is decent or better

NOVEMBER 12, 2014 - Returned today for another breakfast, and went with one of my favorites, Sausage, Egg & Cheese on a Kaiser Roll.  That and a large Coffee set me back only $3.99!  Amazing prices. 

The sandwich was very good.  The Sausage Patty was at least 4" in diameter, the Egg Fried, and Cheese American, and the Roll fresh and nicely chewy.  I enjoyed every bite and finished with a satisfied stomach.  The Coffee was hot and pleasant tasting and I appreciated the milk option as opposed to only half & half or those mini moos flavor alternatives. I sat and enjoyed my early repast with several other guys preparing to start their days.  

Although not intentionally so, Ben's does have a men's club feel to it, as the only women I see aside from those who work there, order take out and don't hang out with us fellas watching the news or ESPN. 

I'll stop back again and try something else, and if as good as my sandwich today, be in the mood to move up the ranking to a brighter star.

Young man wanted a haircut that was long in front and crew in back.  He is old enough to make such momentous decisions on his own, but needed a ride and paymaster. You get what I mean? 

Great Clips in The Village of Newtown Shopping Center was open on Friday night and wasn't busy. They took him right away. I stood back and permitted the stylista and Young Man to negotiate alone. They reached accord and the clippers started buzzing and scissors started cutting. 

Ten minutes later the job was done. YM was satisfied with the rad results, and I was pleased with the $15 prix. 

He didn't look bad, and I can get used to the blond streaks (I hope). 

The shop is in the midst of major renovation. Be careful where you step. It should look great when completed.

It really is Nutts to come so close to being great, but fall short due to small details that are so easily corrected. 

Consider the circumstances. 
~ Great location on Rt. 29, Titusville, NJ; right along the old canal and the mighty Delware. 
~ Cozy countrified space, with the inside a Pocono cabin and the outside a Frenchtown café. 
~ Real pizza oven with a solid rep. 
~ Creamy ice cream way station for tow path riders and walkers. 
~ Diverse menu for 3 meals a day. 
~ Hot, black T-shirted staff. 

So, when I went in this morning for an early 8 am breakfast, had my choice of tables, and my first mug of good coffee, ordering a Spanish Omelet with Home Fries and Rye Toast, this was the result:
~ Very good 3 egg omelet and La Chalula Hot Sauce to spice it up.
~ Yet, two salt shakers and no pepper on the table.
~ Wide cut wholesome toasted Rye Toast that was at best room temperature the moment it 
    reached the table. 
~ A large pile of Home Fries, nicely darkened from their time being grilled, that were now at
   best soft and cool, rather than hot and crisp.  
~ $2.95 for bottomless coffee. $9.95 for the omelet.  Nearly $16.00 for this missed opportunity
   for perfection. 

It is Nutts to have all these self inflicted wounds detract from a near perfect setting, and a kitchen that comes so close to getting it right....

But, doesn't.

Love the location in the heart of Newtown, and very happy they appear to be doing well.

However, this variably topped flatbread is just not pizza. Many love it and are fans or more. I have eaten there a dozen or more times and find it curious, interesting, and mostly satisfying as a healthy alternative meal. Still, when I want real pizza I do not think of Jules.  It does not satisfy me the way a true tomato pie does.  It lacks the cultural affect, the aroma, the bite and crunch, and finally, the taste of traditional Italian pizza.  Too, no one speaks Italian behind the counter.  

These are part of the pizza experience that are every bit as important as the actual slice, folded and ready for the big first bite. 

Cent Anni!

Brooklyn Bagels is an open and spacious shop just off County Line Road at the intersection with 2nd Street Pike at the border between Southampton and Huntingdon Valley. It offers a wide variety of traditional and more modern twists on the bagel genre.  

The bagels are large.  They have the right mildly crunchy exterior, but an interior that is a little too dense for me. That just means that it is kneaded too long before boiling, removing the air pockets that create a lighter product.  Sometimes the only way to know if the density is wrong is to wait to see what happens in its digestion.  When I get indigestion and a lingering aftertaste, I know it was not quite right. 

Still, they use extra large baked onion chips on their bagels, and apply them evenly on both sides. All good.  

I am sure that these rounders hold up very well clamping down on a heavy sandwich, and they certainly have their fans.  But for me, a lighter chew is preferable.  In my bagel quest throughout Bucks County, Bagel Train in Yardley comes closest to my desired Golden Fleece.

Taormina's is a newish facility built in the parking area of the Mallard Shopping Center, Richboro.  First impression is very favorable, as it feels cozy and modern with comfortable table and chairs in a medium sized dining room.  The staff is friendly, attentive, and knowledgeable about the menu and specials. 
 
This was our first visit, and came before basketball practice, so we had to eat light.  We limited ourselves to a Cheese Steak and Chicken Parm sandwiches.  The Cheese Steak was the better of the two.  Very tasty on a good Italian Roll.  The Chicken Parm was OK, but falling into the average range of similar fare in the area.  A really nice touch was the plate of Red Pepper and Onion in Olive Oil offered with the bread basket. The former fit perfectly on the later, and the taste was very pleasant, a vastly superior approach to the more traditional pats of butter (also in the basket), or herbed olive oil.  

We agreed that we enjoyed our repast, and wanted to return to sample some of the dinners (Francaise, Marsala, aglio olio), pizza, and pizza rolls (never had these before, but have great reviews).  

Look for updated review in the next few weeks.

I was cruising down Maple Avenue, Langhorne, in need for a caffeine break.  Up ahead was what looked to be a fairly new Dunkin Donuts. I parked, went in, and ordered hot java. 

To my surprise, the coffee was above average for a DD, and the staff friendly and efficient. They must be hooked up to a good water company for the coffee to be that smooth.

First visit to Cantina Dos Segundos, and the impression was overall positive. Small tables line the sidewalk on a hot night in very late May. People engaged in talk and drink. Lots of smiles and glances. 
Stepping inside, hit with a wave of sound from the multitude of conversations at the bar to the right, and dining area to the left.  The bar looks interesting and worth a sit when less crowded. A wall of tequila looks like an arcade game where balls are thrown to knock them down. That would be a shameful waste of great glass. 
We were led to a deuce in the very back without a wait at 7:15. As recommended, I had a Blood Orange Margarita (rocks, no salt). The bartender in me marveled at its prompt delivery on a busy night, and the good taste slipping past my lips from the chilled glass. Chips and 2 salsas (Verde slightly better than the Rojo) arrived before we pushed in our chairs.  Generally, I prefer a chunkier salsa with some tropical fruit in it, but this wasn't bad. The chips were not all that tasty, nor textured, but went well with the thinness of the salsa. 
The Poblano Chicken Chimichanga was very good, and surprisingly had thin sliced apples inside along with the expected pulled chicken, beans, rice and cheese. I tried the Yuca(sic) Fries, and they were quite good with a Chipotle Mayo dipping sauce rather than ketchup.  
The Tilapia Tacos were also pretty good, but the fish could have been more flavorful to compete with the stronger accompaniment in the tortillas. Still, this is not a serious complaint, just a realization that Tilapia may be too mild to handle the heavy chilliness of the spices. Generally, Mexican style seafood is my favorite. (Reminds me of the time in Ensenada...)
The waitstaff was friendly, helpful and efficient on a busy Friday night. 

Only downside - Poor acoustics and way too noisy for talking. 

Certainly come for happy hour and a zillion tequila options. Think twice if you want a romantic evening in a quiet corner.  This is not that place.

Chiarello's Food Market is an old-time Italian deli in a stand alone building on Hamilton Avenue in Hamilton, NJ.  The Trenton designation is more a product of historic postal zones, than a geopolitical demarcation. 

It is very small inside, but has a surprisingly well provisioned deli area that takes up at least half the space.  The public area is crammed with pastas and bottled/canned goods to assist in preparing a complete meal.  

While it seems certain that their lunch and catering efforts are the primary focus of the business, they are also open early in the morning and advertising breakfast options.  When I inquired about early day sandwiches (ie., Sausage, Egg & Cheese), I was advised that such nourishment was not available.  They did have a few bagels, muffins and pour-your-own java for my crowd.  

I opted for a Bagel, Butter and Cheese with a small cuppa joe to go.  The bagel was clearly not from their oven and was not exactly fresh.
