The taste was okay, but required extra chewing to get it down.  The coffee was that Law brand; clearly offered merely as a convenience without an attempt at truly good café.  

Overall, Chiarello's is not a morning place, but I might return for one of their more auspicious sandwich creations.

Can't speak to the rest of the menu this cold and rainy Friday morning, but this place certainly has hot decent coffee at a great price ($1. for any size joe). 

Service for the drive thru was fine.

Jack's Cold Cuts & Catering (aka Jack's Deli) on Street Road in Bensalem, Pa., has been around for a while making fat sandwiches and catering local parties.  When we walked in around 8:30 one morning last week, they were busy stocking up on the provisions that had just been delivered by the bakery.  We were looking for breakfast, and Jack waved us to a booth with a smile as he carried a large tray of breads to their bin.  

The coffee wasn't made yet, so we knew it would be fresh.  We ordered a couple of sandwiches (Sausage, Egg & Cheese on Kaiser, Pepper, Egg & Cheese on Croissant), and settled in to the sound of the staff getting ready for the day.  The place is old enough to need a little TLC, but it is bright and airy.  

Our meals arrived in plastic baskets a few minutes later.  They were hot and melty, but not best of breed.  Run of the mill roll and croissant, and average innards.  Adequate, but not calculated to win any awards.  The coffee was on the same level.  Okay.  

Jack's advertises that it is a "Jewish Style Deli."  Maybe.  It does have the smoked meats and East European breads and soups that identify that cuisine.  But, it has ample pork products for the rest of the customers.  

Jack's seems like a place that is loved by people who have grown up on their dishes, but more objectively is happy to be quite average.

Zen Den Coffee Shop is sort of an alley operation, running out of a back door on the narrow Donaldson Street, between Oakland and State Streets, in Doylestown.  I first discovered it a few months ago when visiting my attorney who also has a rear entrance backing onto the semi-hidden shops in between the main streets and small pocket parking lots.  Finally stopped in yesterday to grab some Joe and have a look.  

First impression was that the space is much larger than anticipated.  The floor plan is spread out in two rooms, with many comfortable spots to settle in on a sofa, or work at a table.  There is even room for a piano in the middle of the main room.  The work space is in a corner by the entrance, which might be a problem if crowded, but when I arrived shortly after 11, there was only one person ahead of me on line.  I liked the vibe with all the natural colors and clubby furniture.  The southern orientation allowed sunlight to filter in softly in winter, creating a warm glowing ambiance.  I got the "Zen" reference, but doubted there would be much opportunity to meditate or chant there.  Caffeine takes people in another direction.  

I went with a Café Au Lait and Blueberry Muffin for my first try.  The price was under $5, so I immediately thought it compared favorably to the Star$$$ of the world, where the same would have been a few bucks more.  The taste of the coffee was okay, but nothing special.  Likewise, the muffin while fresh, had a commercial bakery quality to it. Certainly edible, but lacking a spark of organic energy.  

I will return to obtain a more representative sampling of the goods @ ZD, but at first blush, it seems a nice place for coffee and conversation, but not necessarily the first place I would think of for outstanding coffee.  

Nonna's is the place to go for that.

Sometimes the best part of the retail shopping experience is not what you buy, but the advice that you get.  

This was born out last weekend when visiting the Jo-Ann Fabric and Craft Store that is located next to the Best Buy on Commerce Blvd in Fairless Hills, across the Oxford Valley Road from the shopping mall that bears that name.  

In need of new drapes, but without a clue about how or where to buy them (excuse me for lacking domestication), my idea was to buy fabric and somehow make drapes.  Simple, right? How wrong I was.  Take that approach and you end up at Jo-Ann walking up and down aisles full of bolts of fabric, trying to decide what would look good in that room.  I just got a headache. 
Before walking out, I made the smart move of asking the woman behind the fabric counter how to deal with the "drape thing."  She was wise in the ways of the world.  Smiling, she whispered so no one but me could hear her; "You don't buy them here unless you want to spend a lot and then hire someone to cut and sew them for you.  I suggest you go to another store not so far from here that specializes in premade window dressings of all types.  They have a large collection and have good prices."  

Confirming the spelling of the other place, I thanked her for the exact assistance I needed, and walked back to my car to see if I could find it on Yelp.  I did. That review to come. 

Solid advice for the uninitiated.  True customer service.

Christine's Restaurant is difficult to figure. 

First blush, the space is warm and cozy in a clubby kind of way, with lots of dark wood tones, white tablecloths, and plenty of windows.  All good.  Then, the menu says it is an Italian shop, which is something of a surprise as it gives no hint of its ethnic orientation.  So what? If the food is good Italian I don't care if it looks like a rib joint. 

Next, checking the menu, it offers breakfast until 1:00. The prime item is Eggs Benedict - not exactly created in Palermo.  The breakdown is in Sandwiches/Wraps; Burgers; Pasta; Salads, and Entrees.  The pasta is the only strong hint that maybe this is where their specialty resides, but I am thinking, "Pasta in this place?" I still didn't get that this was home base for the kitchen.  So, I had the Florentine Chicken Sandwich and a side of Classic Caesar Salad.  

The wedgie was grilled chicken, garlic sauteed spinach, with a melted cheese over the top.  I think the menu said the cheese was pepper jack, which would have been better than the too mild provolone that dressed the other main ingredients.  Too, the roll it came out on was fresh, but not Italian crusty.  It was a little non-descript, and although it carried the sandwich, failed to really pull its weight.  I left most of it on the plate to concentrate on the spinach and chicken.  It was not worth the calories.  

On the other hand, the Caesar was quite good, with crisp romaine, homecrunched croutons, and a decent creamy dressing.  It actually saved the day, as it more than complements the sandwich.  If anything, it was the other way around.  

The whole experience was a little topsy turvy. The side became the star of the show, and the supposedly dominant aspect of the plate was left in partial obscurity.  

The staff was friendly, informed and timely.  

There seems to be an identity crisis at Christine's.  Once it finishes therapy I will gladly return to see what they decided to become.

Mr. China in the Pennington Road Shopping Center, Trenton, NJ, actually surprised me with its cleanliness and decent lunch offerings. The space while primarily for takeout, also has eight booths for people like me who prefer to eat in in relative comfort when the food is hot. 

Service was friendly and smiling.  The house mother took orders, worked the cash register and delivered my General Tso's Chicken to me.  It was actually on a ceramic plate, not a takeout container, a big plus. The meal was pretty good for a generic well known dish. There was ample chicken. The breading was not overly thick, and the sauce was freshly made with chili flakes noticeable in the dark amber covering. The fried rice was a weak point, as it was mass produced with a yellow dye and few veggies, meat or egg.  

With a bottle of Snapple, it was a $7 deal. 

It was A-OK!

DeLorenzo's Pizza sits in the corner of the old strip Fairview Shopping Center on Trenton Road, Fairless Hills, Pa.  As the saying goes, "...Nothing is less fair than living in the Hills..." The oldest part of the establishment where the cashier is, is tiny with 2 tables.  It has its old Bucks charm, but is certainly gritty round the edges.  Only one table was available for this solitary traveler, as the other was being used as the office by the owner/manager (who spoke with a pronounced Russian accent).  

The staff was friendly and the young cooks seemed to know what they were doing.  The most unusual aspect for this pizza joint was that it lacked the display of all their pizza option, so prevalent in most shops these days.  No. They had only one regular pie behind the counter, and they were willing to put anything you wanted on top of it.  (Well, maybe not ANYTHING...) That was refreshingly old school. At least I knew they weren't in the habit of making a multitude of pizzas with various toppings just so customers could pick from among them, even if they had been sitting there all day.  I ordered one plain slice and a sweet Italian Sausage triangle.  

They arrived well done as I wished.  The regular slice had a good crunch, but leaked a bit of oil when tilted.  The taste was good.  The Sausage slice had been thickly spread with crumbled meat, yet it held up well.  The taste was even better.  This snack with a small Coke came in under $5. I threw the change into the tip jar.  

The other side of the house had a dim, but pleasant appearing dining room.  The patrons all had large plates of food before them.  Looked interesting. 

If I return, I will sit over there so I can join the other diners, rather than watch the boss train the servers and pay his bills.

FireGirl Mexican Kitchen sits in a less than state of the art strip mall on Street Road in Bensalem, Pa.  Word is that in a past life it was also a Mexican joint called Tortilla Flats.  Someone has a talent for interesting names. 

We stopped in on Sunday for a late lunch in the midst of shopping in the vicinity. The large room was brightly painted with unusual lighting fixtures and plenty of tables, low and high, for dining.  Ordered were taken at the back cashier stand by a friendly native who was happy to explain how their system worked, and to quickly agree that their Flautas were a good way to go.  

They arrived at our high top about 10 minutes later.  Rather than the normal flute-like crunchy tubes stuffed with Chicken, Cheese, and Peppers, this version was more of a roll up or wrap. The three filled tortillas had been sliced amidship after deep fryin, and were still soft rather than rigid.  In the middle of the plastic basket were small containers of Guacomole, Salsa, Cheese Sauce and Sour Cream.  While we were waiting we located the Hot Sauce Bar against the rear side wall, and brought back several small cups of various blasters to try with our meal.  All were good, but the Spicy Peach Sauce was far and away our favorite due to its sweet/heat quotient.  Tasted great poured onto each Flauta and immediately consumed.  

The order was enough for both of us.  The taste was fine, if not completely authentic.  It was definitely designed for the American palette, which is not a bad thing.  They know their audience.  

I don't get to this part of Street Road often, but will be returning in a few weeks to pick up something ordered at the curtain shop next door.  If hungry when I arrive, I would not mind returning to FireGirl to see what else they have in the kitchen.

Apparently, China Express has been at the corner of S. Olden Avenue and Liberty Street in Hamilton, NJ, for several years, but managed to eluded Yelp detection.  Those hidden days are over now, and it is time for this small primarily take out joint to come out of the shadows.  

The house has a couple of booths and tables for those who prefer to dine in, but even the house sitters get their General Tso's in styro and plastic.  No concession to customers who actually eat what they cooked in front of them.  

My lunch special was pretty much down the middle of what is generally offered in these places.  Massive amounts of pre-dyed yellow pork fried rice with small pieces of meat and veggies, along with heavily glooped chicken pieces; breaded, fried and doused in mostly sweet amber jacket.  Nothing new under this sun. 

It was neither better nor worse than most of the others of this genre.  Edible, if not inspiring.  At under $6., plus the cost of a drink, it was what was expected.  

Ownership is friendly and efficient, and they keep the house bright and clean.  Best part is the small parking lot right next door.

When a comfort food restaurant is empty at 7:30 pm on a Sunday night, there is reason to think that perhaps that is saying something about the operation there. That was what we faced on a damp March night, but we were already inside, and as the old saying goes: "What the hey?!" 

Turns out that with the smoker out front, and a good chef in the kitchen, the food was pretty good.  Only problem was the slightly weird attitude of management that wanted our business, but at the same time had a series of rules they felt compelled to enforce while we ordered. First, they were closing in 30 minutes, which meant we had to order quickly.  We could eat inside while they cleaned up.  Second, our sandwiches came with fries, but any other side order was an extra buck. I wanted baked beans. Okay, bud, but fork over the sawback. Third, a medium burger wasn't possible because the health code required everything be grilled to well done.  What if I didn't like an over cooked burger?  They couldn't help me officially, but they did ask the chef to take it off the heat while still pink.  He said he would with a wink. 

Ultimately, the brisket sandwich was quite tasty, with a nice rub making a flavorful bark.  It might have benefited from another hour in the smoker to make the beef more tender, but it was decent as it was.  My Firehouse Burger was very good, with nicely sautéed/grilled onions and peppers.  Half pound of ground beef was truly pink at its core, and proved a challenge to consume despite its excellent juicy profile.  The baked beans were also solidly flavorful, but could have used a few chunks of burnt ends or pulled pork in the mix to max out the texture and provide more twang. 

The dining room was small, but comfortable, with Texas collectibles hanging for ceiling and wall. I would return to try the ribs or another burger, but not before I visited other nearby grillmasters to check out their goods.  I wasn't blown away by Fat Jack's, but neither was I repelled by their chuck wagon grub.

Number One Chinese Restaurant sits in the 700 block of South Broad Street, Trenton, NJ.  To be kind, it is not exactly the sweetest spot in the capital city to find an eating house, let alone one that had been there for 26 years under the same ownership.  Still, there is a reason it has survived, and maybe even prospered over time.  

There is room for eating in, even though the vast majority of customers order to take out. The man in charge is warm and humorous, and his very ancient looking Confucian beard has turned white. When I asked for his recommendation for lunch, he promptly said the Chicken in Garlic Sauce was the way to go.  Who was I to disagree? 

The plate arrived about 10 minutes later.  It was styro, but at least it wasn't served in a to go box.  It was accompanied with brown rice, and an egg roll, and too thin napkins.  There were ample strips of chicken and plenty of pepper, onion, carrot, pea pod, mushroom, water chestnut and baby corn.  The garlic sauce was noticeable, but not overpowering.  I liked the dish.  Even the egg roll was tasty, without oily aftertaste.  

While this was far from the best Chinese food I'd ever eaten, it was also far from the worst.  At $5.35 for the who shebang, plus another buck for a bottle of water, I thought it was a good deal.  It was also obvious that they don't feel the need to keep the joint sparkling.  It was pretty gritty. 

  As I paid and walked out, I understood how Number One had survived so long.  A smile and low price still goes a long way.

El Barrio Cantina y Tequila Bar is a 5 Star facility with a 3 Star kitchen. 

It was a very pleasant surprise to walk into a large warehouse space with corrugated iron ceiling, long bar with attractively bottled backbar, and Dia Del Muerte personality.  Skulls everywhere.  Plenty of booths in the three dining areas to feel comfortable.  Acoustics were trouble, as every sound was amplified by all the hard and harmonic surfaces.  Pleasant service. 

We ordered pretty standard fare.  A beef burrito for son. Chicken flautas for the old man.  Shrimp Molcajete for stepson.  Chips & salsa as forespice. Everything was okay, but not memorable.  The burrito was stuffed with mildly spiced shredded cow, cheese and peppers.  My son drowned it in the available salsa to bring up the burn.  He ate every last shred, but announced it wasn't very different than what he had recently at Taco Belch.  My fried chicken, cheese and spice stuffed flutes were fine. It was an appetizer, but enough for me last night. Crisp shell. Decent bird mix. The molcajete was basically their version of fajitas - served in a hot volcanic rock, with only six medium sized shrimp and a load of sautéed colorful peppers and onions.  Small sides of black beans, rice, guacamole and sour cream.  He wolfed down the crustaceans and played with the veggies before declaring himself full (bored).  At $15., it was more floor show, than gut filling meal. 

We left agreeing that the joint had potential, but that the food wasn't its strength.  Too young to partake of the bar offerings, we suspected that all the tequila on display might offer a clue to where the magic lies in El Barrio Cantina & Tequila Bar.  

Next time I'll come with grownups and sample their tequila flight and margaritas.

La Hacienda (Home), is a very colorful Mexican restaurant on Neshaminy Boulevard behind Neshaminy Mall.  As with similar spots, the furnishings are wood carved tables and chairs that are brightly painted to suggest an eating establishment South of the Border.  It is successful in creating that atmosphere, and the servers are friendly and attentive, while speaking in heavily accented (but totally understandable) English.  While quite stimulating, I admit to seldom eating in such loudly decorated places in Mexico, where even the high end places tend to be more sedate.  Still, it does make for an unusual and stimulating environment.

Ultimately, it all comes down to the food.  Eating solo, I could only taste what I ordered, and my fork had no place to wander into a companion's plate.  The ubiquitous Chips and Salsa were fine, although the Chips did not have an in house made taste.  The Salsa was of the thin variety, but sufficiently spicy to catch my enjoyable attention.  
 
My main course was Chicken Adobe - a grilled pounded thin Chicken Breast covered with Grilled Japapenos, Onions, Mushrooms, and Melted White Cheese.  The rest of the large plate was covered in Refried Beans and Yellow Rice (see photo).  I rather liked the Chicken and savory toppings.  The grilling was flavorful and texturally pronounced, and the accompaniment was translucent and very complementary in spice tones.  The Refried Beans were loose enough to spread across the plate lowlands, and could have either been reduced in quantity or given more body.  The Rice was just okay, and a rather large portion.  

This is certainly a decent place for a Mexican style meal, and I would return if hankering for Mexicano when in that part of the County.  Yet, given several of the other awesomely authentic and delicious meals I have had the pleasure to encounter recently in my travels nearby, where the joint was fairly plain, but the comidas outstanding, I would not choose La Hacienda when I want an exceptional 4 or 5 Star Mexican experience.

This is another underheated, undercleaned, primarily takeout Chinese/American shop in the Capitol Plaza Center in Ewing, NJ. It is very cheap for those lunch combos with fried rice, and a buck more for an egg roll. 

My General Tso's Chicken was okay, cut into smaller pieces and not too heavily breaded, with a decent amber sauce. On the other hand, the fried rice was a dark brown from the beef consommé in which it was made, and served hard and clumpy, with a minimum of veggies/sprouts. Had the taste of being prepared too long ago, and left sitting in the pot all day. 

The woman working the counter was friendly, and brought lunch to me at the table with a smile. She trusted me enough to wait until I was finished to accept payment. 

A mixed bag. 

2.5 STARS.

In order to apply for a Pennsylvania Driver Permit, not only do you need to show a social security card, but the form also has a portion for a doctor's physical and certification that the applicant is healthy enough to drive.  This is probably a good idea, but it does add to the time and expense of driving in the Commonwealth.  My family doctor was willing, but the available appointment was a week away and the office visit charge was not insignificant.  

So, I decided to call Premier Urgent Care in Newtown to see if they could handle this type of service.  They could and they did.  We could walk in any time during business hours and the cost would be $45 (apparently, there are sometimes special discounts to $25).  We went in the following morning.  The facility was bright and clean.  The employees were all dressed in high end med uniforms, and efficient.  We registered after filling out a 2 page form, and were seen by a medical assistant promptly.  She took us into an examination room, did the basis BP, pulse, height, weight, and eyesight measurements and tests, and then left us to wait for the doctor to finish the exam.  

It took about 20 minutes for Dr. Ferguson to arrive.  She was friendly and communicated well.  We went over the pertinent details of why we were there, and she completed he portion of the physical with quick looks at eyes, ears and throat.  She was quite professional.  

Apparently, my young driving applicant was deemed healthy enough to get behind the wheel of a motorized vehicle, and we were sent on our way.  

Overall, the experience was satisfactory for this type of medical function.  No emergency to deal with.  Just routine physical examination.  While lacking the sense of confidence I have with my personal physician, such "hand holding" wasn't necessary for this job.  We were out in about 40 minutes and had what we needed.  

I would certainly use Premier Urgent Care again for simple medical needs.  It is sort of like going to Wawa when you want coffee and a sandwich, and don't have time for the bigger deli/restaurant experience.

Family run grocery that grew with the population and moved out of Trenton to this location in the burbs to keep up with their customers.  

A good idea before the hypermarkets began to dominate the landscape and put immense pressure on the little guys to match either price (impossible) or performance (customer service and specialty items).  This it could do for a while, but ultimately it was not a long term solution.  Today, it struggles along as a convenience stop for those in the area.  

The selection is limited, and the prices are higher than most of the competition.  The family is older and the next generation has not picked up the baton.  

At least it is clean and the staff friendly for the most part. 

In time, it too will pass into history.

SweetBriar Ice Cream & Cafe in Ambler, PA, has been around for a while. Fourth generation, so they say in the menu. Farm to table, too. Cute county feel with fewer than a dozen tables within and an equal number out on the patio in front. Warm, friendly service with genuine willingness to refill your coffee mug as often as you like. 

I had an hour to kill before my next appointment, and a hunger for breakfast that needed attention. The specials board had a few interesting possibilities, but fresh fruit on a battered waffle with whipped cream seemed a bit over the top. Simple well grilled french toast was what I wanted, and the server said was excellent there. Visions began to dance. 

Java came hot and strong. Real milk in a small stainless pitcher hit the mark. All I needed was a great short stack to make my day. 

Looked perfect on the white ceramic. Darkly golden with yellow bread between the burn marks. An olive oil bottle with long spout full of syrup to address the sweetening. Nice touch. Unfortunately, the inside of the slices was dry as if it had not been conjoined with the egg bowl for long enough before touching hot steel. No eggy vanilla taste. Okay, but with more TLC it could have been a real contender, rather than the dry toast it became. 

I think this place can do it better when it tries harder.

If I went into Dulce Pizza with a blindfold on and only tasted their food without sight of its surroundings, it would definitely have another star after its name. Yet, blessed with sight, the worn and crumby surfaces and poor condition of the shopping center where it is located, impact my overall impression negatively and detract from what would otherwise be a surprisingly good meal. 

My first choice for dinner was the place next door, but its kitchen closed at 3 and they were locking up shortly. I saw Dulce and headed over. It looked like any other pizzeria, with pies in the oven and a small dining room with tubular chairs with holes in the seats and crumbs from earlier meals still laying around. This joint would never be mistaken for clean. It somehow reflected the poorly maintained condition of the shopping center, which had some of the largest parking lot potholes imaginable. A few customers were sitting around manging, so I took a chance and asked for an eggplant parmesan dinner with side salad and pasta. I ordered and paid at the cashier and took a seat near the front window to await it's arrival. I wasn't feeling too enthused about what might be coming my way, but I had already paid, so I was committed. 

The salad came first with balsamic, romaine, tomato, red onion, black olives, cukes and that little plastic tub of dark brown viniagrette. It was cool and fresh. Not great, but not bad. The main platter arrived next with a red sauce covered load of very thin sliced, breaded and sauteed melanzone. The gravy was chunky and seemed to shine in the natural light from the window. I lowered my head to get a wiff of the steaming sauce. Its crushed tomato, garlic and basil aroma forced me back in my chair from its powerful scent. 

What?! Wait a second. Was there someone in the kitchen who knew from red sauce? Must have been because when I forked that first bite into my mouth, it completely took charge of my taste buds, squeezed them hard, and forced me to involuntarily mutter, "Damn!" It was that exceptional. The eggplant was soft and totally baked, without a hard spot to be found. It tasted like it might have been sauteed twice before reaching the oven. 

Then I tried the penne aglio olio I had requested rather than spaghetti with more red. It was also very good with a surfeit of sliced garlic throughout and a pool of extra virgin in the bottom of the bowl keeping it hot and dripping. A dusting of black pepper, romano and dried parsley on top provided the finishing note. Also, way better than expected. 

Of course they forgot the bread to complete my total confounding. 

What to do when the grub is better than good, but the facility and surroundings cry out for some TLC?

 Wear a blindfold and eat.

First impressions of Trentini's Restaurant off South Clinton Avenue in Trenton, NJ, are very positive.  The dining room reminds of an adobe bright colored house in New Mexico, with semi-exposed timbers and ersatz red tile roof extending from the inner walls. 

The staff is friendly and attractive and provide a solid table service.  

A couple of the office guys went there for a pizza lunch the other day.  We ordered a 12 inch pie with sausage and eggplant for two of us.  It was prepared fresh for us, and took about 15 minutes to reach our table.  It looked quite good with the steam rising from the bubbling volcanic cheese surface.  The aroma was exquisite. 

We knew that this was a Spanish (Ecuadorian) Italian shop, but the menu remained heavy oriented toward Italiano.  This may explain the over-reliance on cheese, rather than tomato sauce and spices to define the pie.  The abundance of melted mozza made the pizza top heavy, and impossible to pick up manually, without fold and spillage.  This is often the mistake of pizza makers unschooled in the ways of the tomato pie, where proper proportion among the main ingredients is critical to the success of the creation.  

The taste was still good, but we both resorted to fork and knife in order to keep the various layers together.  It was one of those circumstances when less (cheese) is more satisfying. 

While I likely will not order pizza again from Trentini's, the rest of their menu, and the quality of service will lead me back there eventually to sample their other offerings, both in pasta and almuertzo Americano del Sur.

John's Barber Shop is a place where only men need apply for a haircut. 

It is hidden in the back basement behind State Street in Newtown Borough, and is best approached by driving into the State Store lot, circling that building, and when 3/4s of the way around the liquor store, hang a sharp right into a smaller lot.  The side door next to the lot is John's.  

Knock three times and whisper you were sent by Joe, to get in.  

Want a cigar or beer with your trim?  This is the place for you.  Want your hair styled a little?  Maybe not. 

Perhaps, it is because I went to the old fashioned barber shops as a kid, where the barber dressed in a white coat, and had a thick leather strap attached to the riser chairs, and I was intimidated by the straight edge razor blades, buzzing electric shears, and sharp scissors; but watching my son get his haircut there makes me nervous.  Going to the barber was second only to going to the dentist in striking fear deep into my psyche.  As a result of that youthful stress, only women touch my head now (you know what I mean).  I don't mind paying to have my limited crop look as good as possible, not like I just went to the barber. I still remember the smell of the Trol Hair Pomenade, or Brylcream "little dab 'il do 'ya." 

Yes. I did enjoy the payoff of a lollipop. Not sure if John offers that along with the whiskey.

Opened this place Saturday morning @ 9.  It was nice to have a head start on what was to be a full house at Full Moon.  

Clayton, our host and server had his act together and brought all of us coffee as we perused the breakfast menu.  Various omelets for my family and friend, and French Toast for me.  While the conversation gathered momentum, the plates were brought out and laid before us.  Everything looked very good, although I only tasted the homemade Potato Chips, which were good.

My French Toast was off the mark, however. I had asked for it "crunchy," and was told it would be left on the grill longer to make it all well done.  What came out with the real Maple Syrup were a half dozen pieces of French Demi Loaf that were actually lukewarm at best, and far from the cauterized ends I requested.  I was surprised given the repartee at the ordering.  They had not been on the grill long enough, and had been off the grill too long before serving. Wrong on both sides.  Disappointing, but not wanting to poop on the party I ate everything and enjoyed the real Maple Syrup. 

My mates were satisfied, and the gestalt of the room was pleasing. 

Three out of four ain't bad.

Pat's Pizza & Bistro on New Falls Road, Levittown, PA, is part of a family run Italian chain in Jersey, Delaware and Pennsylvania. This facility is fairly new with lots of stone, high ceilings and wooden tables and chairs. Small parking lot is a challenge. The menu is primarily pizza parlor style - pies, steak sandwiches, wraps, salads. There are only a few actual dinner options. Chicken parmesan and a few pastas with meatballs or sausage. 

We went with the chicken parmesan, which came with a nice size salad and bowl of pasta, "Rustic" chicken cheesesteak, and their BBQ burger. Of the three dishes, the burger was actually the best. Juicy, substantial and tasting without freezer burn. The rustic roll was a good alternative to the standard torpedo, but the makings were a bit dry and needed more flavor from the onions and peppers. The chicken parmesan was okay, but heavily breaded. The salad was bigger than expected and enough to share. The homemade fettuccine aglio olio was was real al dente delight. 

Pat's provides nice atmosphere, but the kitchen could be more consistent. It has its highs and lows. It is certainly worth a stop to check out when in the mood to be in the mood for Italian food.

Dolce Carini Pizzeria hasn't been reviewed since 2008!?

Wonder why?

I have gone in for a late lunch pizza a couple of times in recent months just to see how the tomato pie was faring around Ntown. Someone has to keep watch of the state of slice around here. It may as well be me. N'cest pas?

No one there when I arrived around 2.  The shop was clean and orderly.  The crew in back was friendly and accommodating to my request for 2 slices and cold drink (lemonade). They came out of the reheat oven in about 3 minutes and I sprinkled on the crushed hot pepper as I walked to my table.  The price was right @ under $6. A full two bucks less than Marco's for the same deal. 

How were the slices?  I forgot my scale, but they did seem smaller than a similar cut in the other places I often go, perhaps offsetting the economy of slice noted above.  Still, the crust was thin and crisp, and held the weight of the sauce and cheese well.  No folding nor dripping. Big plus. The taste is where the rubber meets the road, and to my buds the oral sensations were not quite right.  The sauce was a little salty, when I prefer a mild sweetness and basil-esque retort. The cheese had little flavor and did not play well with the sauce. 

I am not saying that the pizza was bad, just that it wasn't a complete pleasure, nor did it stand tall next to the local competition.

 It was just A - OK.

I had not been inside Giuseppe's Pizza since before my twelve year old was born.  That is a life time in pizza years. 
After today's basketball game in Churchville, we stopped in for a few slices and drinks to assuage the pain of another close loss.  
The pizza was as good as I remembered it.  Strong enough dough to hold its point proudly without folding like a dog's ear; minimal drip of oil from the face of the pie; and a serenely enjoyable first bite experience.  My son's first impression was equally positive.  His comment to the effect that it was not quite as good as Marco's in Newtown was well taken and subject to debate.  Regardless, Giuseppe's is in good company.
We will need to explore the menu further by venturing into cheese steaks, parms, and pasta to consider moving up the star ranks.

Modern Shanghai dumpling and soup house on Cottman Avenue just off the Roosevelt Expressway in Northeast (Dong Bei) Philly. This is a growing Asian neighborhood that is slowly becoming a legitimate alternative to Chinatown (Center City) and Washington Avenue (South Philly) for your dining and shopping pleasure. 

Clientele is primarily Chinese, as is the staff. Cantonese is understood more readily than Mandarin. The menu is bilingual, with major focus on the beef/pork soup food group. Plenty of dumpling options, too, from Xiao Long Bao to wok fried pork gaozi. I was there for the XLB, so ordered two steam baskets (12) of them and a large bowl of Magic Noodles 101 (beef and bones in savory broth with mix of mushrooms and black fungus). 

The Shanghai created XLB were steamy and quite tasty with a touch of vinegar dropped in through the opened top knot for added flavor. Only downside was that the skin was so friable that the act of lifting them gently onto my spoon with the metal tongs cause them to tear, leaving a leaking dough sack to contend with. Every one of them tore open. Nimble handling to place them quickly into the spoon was the only way to salvage the contents. I managed to do that, but still had to suck some soup from the spoon each time. 

The Magic Noodle bowl was okay, but I found gnawing  the beef bones to be messy and less than fun. The mushrooms were flavorful and I knew the fungus was good for health. 

This was a very tactile meal. It was definitely a change of pace cultural experience that was as entertaining as it was nourishing.

COVID-19 TAKE OUT REVIEW

Spice Garden is a take away only Indian kitchen that focuses on Kerala style South Indian cuisine. It didn't have to change much of its operation to adjust to the pandemic. On the end of an old commercial strip near the bottom of Bustleton Avenue just a few blocks before Grant Avenue, it is designed to accept your phone order for pick up 30 - 40 minutes later. That was our plan after grocery shopping at the large Asian supermarket on St. Vincent's Street @ Roosevelt Avenue. We called from the parking lot, arriving about 15 minutes later because of light Memorial Day Weekend traffic.

Now, I've had much better curries, masalas and garlic naans than are offered at Spice Garden, but on the other hand there is a trade-off of larger quantities and cheaper prices than available at standard Hindi houses, although the online menu states that recent cost of ingredient increases necessitated higher prices. That's just reality given these harsh times, and we didn't object to absorbing a couple of more bucks. 

Of course, by the time we reached home the blush was off the rose. Reheating was required to reanimated each dish. We found each was tasty and very well spiced. The two chicken plates led the way, with the Kerala Chicken Curry in a dark thick sauce and the Chicken Pepper Fry bone in and the hottest of the lot. It was a finger food delight. The Channa Masala was lighter cream colored mildly sweet veggie dish that was a good sop for the Garlic Naan. The other diced mixed veggie bowl was a strong counterpoint to the rest of the tongue challenging heat packed into the two plastic take home bags.

The only real downside to the experience was the cleanliness of the small anteroom when I waited for the food. There were several insulated containers sitting on the floor, each more schmutzidick than the other. Clearly used for moving cooked food, there was no way they would pass a health department inspection. They left me wondering about the condition of the kitchen on the other side of that swinging door. 

I'll let you know if I experience any side effects from this meal, which appears to be enough for three dinners.

While KO Modern Korean Cuisine does a tasty new take on traditional dishes from the peninsula, you must keep in mind that they call themselves a fusion restaurant that covers Japanese, Thai and even a pinch of Chinese in their kitchen. If traditional is what you want, then this is not the place for you. Try Mirim or the cafe inside of H Mart on Woodbourne Road for the real McCoy. It is only fair to judge based on their stated intentions, not on what they do not claim to be. 

To my tongue they do a very good job on creative contemporary Korean food. I thoroughly enjoyed the small plate KFC (Korean Fried Chicken) and BBQ Pork Belly Bao. The extra spicy wings were just that. Messy and delicious. The Buns a tempting pile of belly and greens atop a soft round pinchable white rice bun. Had I stopped there I would have been seeing multi stars. 

The Sushi and Bento Dinner from the Japan side of the menu were a different matter. Our Rainbow Roll ordered for a sushi neophyte, was less than inspiring. It appeared lifeless on the platter, and tasted less than brand new. When sushi is truly fresh, it has an inner glow. This did not. Perhaps, the use of dyed pink ginger was a tell, but it was less than optimal. I would like to see what they do with Gimbap, the seaweed and rice street food that most closely resembles sushi. I suspect it would have been superior. 

The Bento options chosen were teriyaki salmon,  Dynamite Chicken and a similar shrimp offering (tiny deep fried crustaceans in a gloopy sticky sweet sauce). Again, this Japanese combo plate missed the mark. The salmon was good, but slightly overcooked. The chicken was barely above room temperature, and the shrimp was lost in the heavy batter shell and thick clingy sauce. Just not what we expected from this kitchen. 

We agreed we would try again, but focus only on the Korean possibilities. This night, fusion could only be interpreted as confusion.

TAKEOUT REVIEW 
Curious about this primarily take away Italian fast casual shop in Levittown, PA, I drove down late last week to pick up a light family dinner. I ordered three sandwiches; roast pork, chicken cheesesteak and sweet sausage, onions and peppers. 

They were packaged in white, rectangular cardboard boxes and each half wrapped in butcher paper before being placed in a plastic bag before handing to me through the drive thru window. About $17 for the three. Good deal. Problem was that the placement of the boxes in the bag was haphazard. Once home and removing them from the sack and putting them on our kitchen table, it was obvious the boxes were not bagged upright, but on their sides. As a result, their was leakage and the roast pork a sloppy mess. 

I did my best to reconstruct the sammy, and placed all three in the oven for a quick reheat. They were still tasty, although the rolls were damp and not first quality. The roast pork was juicy, the sausage had nice texture and plenty of flavor. The steak 'wich was only so-so. 

I try to avoid take out most of the time because so much is lost not eating food right after it is off the grill. Zio Gio was no different. If I lived nearby, it is good enough to be in the be in rotation for a pizza/sandwich stop. Given the distance, it is unlikely to happen. There are too many local restos deserving our business.

Decent enough small diner on York Road in Warminster, PA, where breakfast was had this morning. My third post-vaccine meal in a restaurant as the world crawls out of its collective cave to taste life again. 

The Vegetarian Omelet was a substantial plate load of 3 eggs, broccoli, onion, mushroom and spinach, with a shovel full of home fried potatoes for balance and good measure. Rye toast was a crunch and a half. Very filling, but required extra black pepper for taste on both the eggs and taters. 

I was surprised and concerned that the server was not masked, when we were required to be, and the owner was covered as well. Even with two jabs I would have felt more secure had she considered the reality that she was in contact with everyone in the dining room and kitchen and close proximity with every customers' food.  There is something to be said for keeping up appearances, especially in a food service business. 

Maybe management will see this review and reevaluate its policy on proper social distancing protocols even in the improving circumstance of an almost safe, nearly post Covid world.

Can't say I was impressed with this Iron Hill Brewery in Abington, PA. 

While the Pumpkin Ale was tasty and refreshing, our menu choices were fair to middling at best. We ordered their Calamari appetizer, Asian Salmon Burger and Country Schnitzel as main courses. The Calamari was all small rings (no tentacles) and overly oily from deep frying. Our guess was that these little things came from a large bag of frozen seafood. Nice to have slivers of hot peppers mixed in, but the ranch dressing dip really didn't contribute to the experience. 

My dining mate didn't offer a taste of the Asian Salmon after she took a bite and put it aside. "Too much garlic," she explained. Those fries were quite crisp and crunchified, however, and I had a free hand with them. 

The pork fillet Schnitzel was good; nice breading, pan fried with chunky Andouille Sausage white gravy over top. We ended up sharing that after she turned aside her salmon. I found the cutlets to be better without the gravy, and was able to push most of it off the entree. The sides (fresh spinach sautéed in garlic and oil, and the mashed sweet potato) were very colorful and also tasty strong contributors. Fair to say this plate was our dinner's salvation. 

The space felt somewhat worn out. I don't like carpeted dining rooms, as they tend to hide the accumulated dirt that collects in the fibers. This wall to wall definitely had been down too long. 

This was my third Iron Hill in the past month. Overall, unless very new, these breweries just don't seem to maintain high class facilities and appear worse for wear compared to their competition.

Three STARS is as far as I can go.

Hidden in the front corner of H Mart in Levittown, PA, lies Manna Kitchen, a tiny Korean restaurant serving cuisine from the homeland and China at reasonable prices. There are only four tables, so takeout is the primary focus. I stopped in yesterday to check out their Korean Fried Chicken, which comes six pieces to the container for nine bucks and change. 

To be transparent, we seemed to have a small miscommunication about exactly what I was getting. I asked for Korean Fried Chicken Wings, which I thought the friendly order taker agreed I could have. Instead, what I got were a few wings and a majority of thighs. Now, I like thighs, but they are not the same as wings in taste nor texture. So, when I arrived home my first impression was that I had received huge wings. First bite told the tale, and disappointed my taste buds. The crisp was there, as was the delicious ginger soy finish, but the taste of the dark meat chicken could not be mistaken. 

I am willing to chalk this confusion up to poor ordering on my part, rather than intentional misdirection by the staff. I did enjoy them once I realized what I had, it's just that my expectations were left unmet. This accounts for the loss of a star. After all, meeting expectations is what satisfaction is all about, and thus, reviews reflect that reality. 

Still, I will get back to Manna sooner or later to see what else is going on. I do hope for no more misunderstandings, and that the chef is wearing her mask at all times while handling food, which accounts for the second demerit.

This place is really two restaurants in one. 

First, Chester's Fried Chicken is something of an institution in this part of Trenton.  It has been frying up Chet's secret recipe for several decades.  Recently, the original chicken shack has been taken over by Pakistanis and added an identity of Shan Halal Pakistani, Indian & Bengali Cuisine.  The Southern Fried Chicken is still produced, but now there is a full South Asian menu complete from Masalas and Kormas, to Curry, Gosht and Naan.  

The owner and chef is a devout Muslim, meaning he is friendly, courteous, modest, and accommodating. He was patient with me as I figured out what was being offered in these otherwise widely desperate culinary approaches.  I had not experienced a Fried Chicken/Chicken Masala house before.  But, I was game.

I wasn't completely ready to mix the two in one meal, and did not want to siesta after eating, so opted to go with Chester's grub.  I ordered the Special that included a Breast, Wing, 2 Jo-Jos (potato wedges) and a Roll.  At $3.99, I thought I had stepped into a time warp.  Turned out that the Chicken was quite good.  The coating was light and pleasantly spiced, without the oiliness that so often comes as part of the dish.  It was crispy from the deep fryer, but the layer of breading was so thin compared to what is found in the name brand competitors, that I appreciated why Chester had been so successful.  The Jo-Jos were also coated and fried, but were still just a close variant to what everyone offers.  The Roll was wasted calories from a store bakery.  

Next visit I will explore the rest of the menu and file an update.  For the moment, Chester's Fried Chicken moves to the head of the class for a well designed and executed icon of country American dishes.  I would certainly pick some up for a family dinner.  To get the freshest and best tasting chicken, I will call ahead and ask for a fresh order to be prepared.

Phi Vietnamese opened its doors three weeks ago in the Crossroads Shopping Center off Rt. 313 in Doylestown.  It is the first shop to offer primarily Vietnamese food in the area, and for that they are worthy of appreciation.  Welcome to the hood.

The store is nicely appointed with black tables and chairs and burnt orange painted walls.  Looks good.  The staff is mostly indigenous to VN, and are quite attentive to their customers.  The menu offers what would be expected from this ethnic kitchen - Pho, Broken Rice, Summer Rolls, etc., at price points that while higher than in their siblings in less upscale environs, reflect the rent structure of the area.  $10 may be more than we are accustomed to paying for a large bowl of noodle soup, but it is a fact of life that things cost more in better communities.  

Son and I stopped in for Pho Ga (Chicken Pho) and Bun Bo Hue (Beef Noodle Soup from the former royal capital of Hue in Central VN).  Service was fast, although belied by slower delivery of the side plate of Thai Basil, Jalapeno Slices, Sprouts and Lime Wedges.  They also forget to bring the Hoisin and Sriracha Sauces for customization.  No biggie. I went to get them myself. 

The Chicken Pho was basic, but a solid presentation. It was steaming hot, with enough sliced white meat to keep son satisfied.  The Bun Bo Hue was another matter.  The spicing was off.  When right, it has a balance of Lemongrass, Fermented Shrimp Sauce, Chili Pepper and Sugar, to represent the major spice groups.  When joined with the amply simmered Beef Broth, and loads of thin sliced steak and brisket, it becomes a powerful combination that attacks the eyes, nose and mouth at the same time.  It can literally take your breath away until you adjust to its flavors and begin to taste how great they are together.  Phi's version was unbalanced with weak Lemongrass presence, and no sweet undertone.  Too, the table lacked the Vietnamese Coriander that adds to the complexity.  While it was hot and possessed some kick, it could not duplicate the burst of flavors a true BBH puts out.  

Phi Vietnamese is certainly good enough for a second visit and hopefully they will get their spice legs beneath them and start to BRING IT!  They shouldn't underestimate the sophistication of the local pallets, or they risk losing face to the suburban houses that can do it right, like House of Pho in Southampton and Pho Palace in Feasterville.

Jumbo's is the new business in the free standing building out in front of H Mart on Oxford Valley Road, Levittown, PA. It claims to fame are its fried chicken, wings, burgers and hot dogs. As I was a rookie there, and it was late lunch time, I decided to try a few things - Jumbo's fried chicken, two types of wings and my most secret curiosity, the hot dog. 

I ordered the 4 piece Fried Chicken (white meat, no sides), Spicy Sweet and Hot Fire Wings and the Elote Hot Dog. The exchange took place at the walk up drive thru window with the friendly woman I took to be an owner/manager. Everything was prepared in about 20 minutes, and she brought a neat package out to me as I waited in the car. 

In no particular order - 

The Elote Hot Dog was very good. The beef sausage was firm, fresh and loaded with garlicy flavor in a quality bun. The Mexican corn had plenty of spice and interesting taste, that although wet did not harm the strength of the bun. The Elote drizzle over the top was a bit salty, but not enough to be a distraction. Love me a great frankfurter, and this was almost that. 

The Fried Chicken had lost its crispness by the time it reached my kitchen table. Probably inevitable, but still not at its apex. The flavor of the fried surface was milder than I like, and it needed more zest. The chicken itself was tender, but the lack of spice in each chew made the overall experience less than hoped. It just wasn't memorable. 

The wings were a medium size. The Spicy Sweet was a decent sauce that was more sweet than spicy. The Fire Hot was a rub finish that had the right amount of burn. They compared favorably with the equivalents at Buffalo Wild Wings according to our sons.

Will have to return for the burgers and tots, but until then, 3 Stars is where it's at.

While Gay Street in downtown West Chester, PA, is way cool, with outdoor cafes, taverns and breweries competing with pedestrians for sidewalk space, this Iron Hill Brewery & Restaurant seems a bit out of sync with its very popular competition. Perhaps because it is older than many, the overall impression is drab and worn. 

We were a small group celebrating a new member of the firm. Staff put a few tables together for us, giving us complete command of the main dining room late in the afternoon. We ordered drinks and a few appetizers and smoozed for a couple of hours. We had good conversation as we consumed a plate of hummus/pita, sweet potato fries w dipping sauces and roasted Brussel sprouts in balsamic (?) dressing. 

The drinks were fine, if unimaginative; the same being true for the food. We consumed everything with a couple rounds of booze, and had no complaints, but it could have been so much more to keep us interested in their dark auburn atmosphere.

This Iron Hill just felt tired compared to other of their siblings I have visited and enjoyed. They occupy a key corner in town and it was easy to imagine how much more interesting and inviting it could be. How about an outdoor presence like everyone else? How about better marking of the main entrance door? How about better lighting around the bar to accentuate the back bar display?

Just saying...

The facility is very nice with dark wood tones and adequate spacing of tables.  The sushi area is to the side and kept very clean.  The service is adequate, if not overly warm or informative.  Definitely, a nice space to eat and socialize.

The Hibachi is not much to my liking, as whether beef, chicken, shrimp or lobster, they all taste almost the same coming off the grill due to the heavy dosing with soy sauce.  The flipping of food morsels from the spatula into the diners mouth is funny the first dozen or so times it is experienced, but gets old (and messy) after a while.  This is not the place I would chose to have a delicious steak, as it is far from a Ruth Chris, Capitol Grille, or Walensky's experience.  

The rest of the menu is diverse and generally decent, but not outstanding enough to want to return more than sporadically.  The presentation is done well, and the staff is prompt if not overly engaging with the customers.   I have tried the Udon/Soba Noodles with Chicken or Beef and enjoyed them, although they were less spicy that I generally prefer.  The Bento Boxes and lunch are a solid meal with Shumai, Tempura Veggies, and Haru Maki or other light roll as accompaniment. 

For me, Mt. Fuji is a good alternative place for local lunch or dinner, but I would not drive far out of my way for the opportunity.  Thus, 3 Stars.

Honey Baked Ham is the non-kosher name for a chain of primarily sandwich places where you can order a combination of sandwich, bread, drink, side and cookie for a prix fix.  You can also order a full ham. This one is in the Village of Newtown section anchored by the Pier 1 store. 

The few times I have been there I have gone with Turkey Breast, Swiss Cheese with lettuce and mustard, Cole Slaw side, Snapple Ice Tea and a Peanut Butter Cookie. It comes in a cute box.  They taste good, if not outstanding.  The service has been friendly, but when I am there it seems the owner is there alone and doing all the work.  This makes for a feeling that he is rushing around, for which he has my sympathy.  

I have also been a regular of another HBH in the Mercer Mall in Lawrenceville, New Jersey.  That shop seems better organized, and the food is somehow more enjoyable. 

Still, when I need to eat at my desk or want to be in Tyler Park for an hour of nature, HBH offers a great solution.
Big sign out front that the property is for sale/rent with restaurant fixtures.

Went in for a late lunch last Saturday after a grocery haul at 1st Oriental down the street.  The floor plan looked like many other Vietnamese houses, with an open space occupied by long tables for group dining.  Turns out that I.S. BBQ is run by Chinese folk with a large menu covering several Asian food groups, as well as their signature Hot Pot/Smokeless BBQ grill in the middle of every table.  I wasn't hungry enough for an AYCE meat meal, so went with a few of the small plates - Spring Rolls, BBQ Beef & Lemongrass with Rice, and a bowl of Pho with Lean Steak and Meatballs. 

Service was prompt, but made the mistake of bringing the main courses before the app.  No biggie, but knew someone wasn't being attentive. The Rolls were very good.  Crispy, mildly oily from cooking, but loaded with Pork, Shrimp and Cabbage filler. Nice side of White Radish. The accompanying thin sweet sauce was fine.  Likewise, the beef dish was plentiful and tasty.  The Rice was molded into a plateaued mound, and in great condition to absorb the mix of sauces on the plate. 

The only real shortcoming was with the Pho.  While the broth was decent, the beef was way overcooked and tough to chew.  It had been pre-cooked, and not left to simmer in the soup to reach the right doneness in the bowl. Given all the raw meat available for the Hot Pot, the failure to simply slip a few slices into the bowl was incomprehensible.  Too, the accoutrement lacked Jalapeno slices to bring up the burn.  Disappointing.

While I might consider a return for the Hot Pot or BBQ, the attractiveness of the overall joint was significantly dampened by the Pho Phail.

This was a first visit to Lee's Café and Bistro at the corner of 5th and Washington in South Philly.  The green awnings are inviting in this otherwise standalone renovated old house that sits in front of the 1st Oriental Super Market on that same block.  

It is not until you get to the front doors that you learn that the actual café is on the second floor, while the first is occupied by their café displays where you can get java and bakery goods to go, or bring upstairs.  The dining space is very clean for a restaurant in this area, and the furnishings a step above the utilitarian space found nearby in Pho Ha.  The walls are brightly painted and HDTVs hang from the walls.  The menu is fairly typical for a Saigon house, but the servers are definitely more friendly and engaging than in most other Vietnamese joints.  

We ordered Summer Rolls, Pho Tai and BBQ Pork Banh Mi, and recognized quickly that the prices were higher here than in the rest of the neighborhood.  It must reflect the cost of the recent renovations.  We hoped that the quality of the kitchen was likewise reflected in the pricing.  

This was not really the case.  The Summer Rolls were cool and fresh, with thin sliced shrimp attracting the most attention through the opaque skin, but also stuffed with Pork and Cabbage.  The Peanut Sauce was a bit on the thin side and lacked any ground peanuts to supplement the textural experience.  The Pho was only average in terms of the beef broth.  Plenty of Sprouts, Thai Basil, Jalapenos and Lime Wedges, and a veritable bird's nest of rice noodles beneath the surface, but lacking the subtleties of the finer pho venues.  In point of comparison, Pho Ha, right around the corner and visible from there has far superior slurp for the demanding consumer.  

The Banh Mi was fine - fresh and crunchy with ample BBQ Pork, Daikon, Carrot, Mayo and Cilantro.  But, the roll it came in was neither baguette, nor Italian, but some crumbly hybrid that although fresh, lacked the body of the real contender.  It wasn't fun to bite through and chew.  And, the cost at nearly $8. was far in excess of strong alternatives found nearby for under $5. 

So, net/net, Lee's is a nice place to hang out and grab a bite in relative comfort while looking out the second story windows, but if outstanding cuisine is what you came for, you might find yourself underwhelmed.  With so many exceptional Vietnamese shops in the immediate vicinity, I found myself thinking of them rather than enjoying where I was.

Olive Garden "Italian" Restaurant is one of those places designed for compromise.  In my case, it was a reasonable place to go with family given the limitations of each member.  My son loves cheese, but hates veggies, and said he was not very hungry.  His mother (my ex) is a vegetarian who loves the unlimited Salad and Breadstick deal offered by the chain.  Me?  I love Italian cuisine, but also want to keep the peace and make it through a Mother's Day dinner without stress.  Given all the variables, Olive Garden was the obvious choice.  

Surprisingly, the wait was not long when we arrived around 7:30.  We were seated within 10 minutes and our server was on us quickly for our drink and app requests. They arrived promptly, along with the first bowl of Salad without olives nor croutons, but with extra Red Onion, Tomato and Cheese.  I didn't know the salad could be special ordered, but it was a good idea.  The veggies were freshly cut and the Oil and Vinegar dressing was decent.  The Bread Sticks were hot and a little crispy on the bottom, which I liked.  

I was the only one having an actual dinner, having skipped lunch, and went with the new light Garlic Rosemary Chicken.  It arrived with two smallish chicken breasts well grilled, but without any grill marks, on a bed of Fresh Spinach, a few Caramelized Garlic Cloves (needed more), and a nice plop of Garlic Mashed Potatoes.  The Rosemary was not visible, but the chicken did taste of it.  

Overall, I was satisfied with the meal, although the sauce was thin and a bit salty.  For a "light" meal it was filling.  At $13.99 it seemed a reasonable value.  Would I order the same dish again?  Probably not, as the trade off in flavor for the lack of calories was not a winning hand.  It could be that I am comparing my experiences in many more authentic Italian restos, but I did not feel excited by the meal.  It was adequate.   

As no one complained and we were able to have a low key dinner, Olive Garden did its job, and met my decidedly selfish expectations.

I haven't tried the Wings here, but if they are anything like from their other locations, they are fine.

I stopped in for a Fried Fish Sandwich the other day for late lunch.  The Fish was light and flakey, the breading thin with a mild taste.  Most important, the oil was clean, so there was not unwanted taste from anything that had been fried before.  For comparison, the fish at JC's Fish and Soul Food  farther down Nottingham is better. 

The accompanying Fries were also okay.  

I wouldn't rush back to Chuck's, but I wouldn't avoid it, either.

It's hard to get excited about a car rental experience. Still, there are better and worse ones, and this interaction with Enterprise in Fairless Hills, Pa., was better than many.  

My vehicle was in the body shop for repairs after a rear ender than left the rear bumper of my car looking like the loser of a boxing match.  These folks picked me up at the shop, drove me to their store to complete the necessary forms and had me on the road in less than 20 minutes.  They worked seamlessly with my auto insurance to arrange for coverage, leaving me with a small balance to pay for the reality that most car rentals cost more than $16 a day.  

My Mazda 6 was decent, if not exceptional.  It was clean and handled well.  It was efficient on gas.  When I brought it back, they drove me to the body shop with a warm smile and interesting conversation.  

No hesitation to use them again.

Located in the Newtown Business Commons, Cosi offers breakfast, lunch and dinner for the businesses in the area, as well as the Homewood Suites Hotel down the street.The chain offers moderately upscale, fresh foods in a comfortable, modern environment.  We had two Cosis in Newtown, but one closed last year.  The food was consistent from both of them.
Breakfast meetings are my primary reason for being there.  Their oatmeal, square bagels (freshly made), muffins, and coffee are very good.  The lunch salads, sandwiches and pizzas are fresh, creative and tasty.  Try the Signature Salad with grapes, dried cranberries, walnuts and blue cheese.  Breakfast comes in at about $7., and lunch, $10.  Certainly, not outrageous. 
The staff is competent, if not always warm.
Overall, a very good place to enjoy a local breakfast or lunch with friends and associates.

CrisPanino is a small tapas/sandwich house in a mini strip center on Parkway Avenue in Ewing, NJ.  It is clean, utilitarian and somewhat stylish with a "lounge" along the front window for those who prefer to recline while eating.  The menu is posted high on the wall and takes a bit of scouting to figure out what is going on.  Luckily, I was the only customer when I arrived, and the good gentleman behind the counter came around to explain the system to me.  

I had read about the Flight of Empanadas - three delicately wrapped fillings surrounded by Argentine imported dough that fries up light, crisp, airy an very tasty.  The inside are Ham & Cheese, Pulled Pork, and fine textured Beef/Gravy thing; each in a distinctly shaped enclosure.  They were a curiosity and fun to eat, with interesting textures, but lacking in any signature flavors.  They were all bland, leaving the outer shell as the most memorable part of the dish.  Perhaps, that was the point. 

The Crispy Fried Chicken Panino was beautifully presented on oversized Sour Dough, with strips of Fried Chicken, an Aioli based Mayo, Tomato, Lettuce and American Cheese.  It was a handful.  I liked the bite, chew and taste of this sandwich, but later that night found myself suffering heartburn, possibly from the mayo or some aspect of the sauces within each empanada.  As it was the last meal of the day, this meal was the likely culprit. 

Nonetheless, the house is pleasantly open and airy, and the staff very helpful and friendly.  I appreciate its uniqueness.  

Still, I have no strong desire to return for another taste, and that implies that I am not yet a fan, and can't reach 4 stars.

Sometime last year the AMC Group sold this to Regal and now it has been renamed accordingly. Otherwise, it is the same as it ever was, except for the need to go to a different website to buy advance tickets.  

What has become obvious is that the cinema business has taken a page from the sports complex business model.  Your ticket may seem expensive, but only until you step up to the snack bar cashier to order the pop corn, candy, pizza, chicken fingers, soda pop, and other sundries.  Those prices quickly double or triple your price of admission.  Outrageous. 

So, most people find a way to bring in food and drink surreptitiously to avoid being gouged.  No wonder ticket sales are down annually and the movie theaters chains are shedding underperforming assets in an attempt to find a profit.  It would seem that the better way to go is to get a liquor license and set up a decent kitchen and make "dinner and a movie," into a unique one stop experience.  

Hopefully, a more creative approach will save this icon of American culture.  After all, there are some movies that just have to be enjoyed on a huge screen in a dark auditorium, with your arm around your babe's shoulders.

We walked in during a birthday party for a young child.  The store was loud with kiddos shouting and running around.  Not bad if you like that helter-skelter ambiance.  But, not the place to find a quiet corner and enjoy a fresh baked and salted mini pretzel or three.  So, we took advantage of their special of 12 minis for $5., and boogied out to the car to continue on to Philly and munch in the voiture. 

The pretzels were fresh and okay, but far short of spectacular.  Chewy.  Salty. Carb City. Definitely needed a washdown to keep the pipes clear.  

The hot dog pretzels did look interesting.

I've picked up food from JC Teriyaki two days in a row to try a few of their main dishes to see what was happening there.  I've eaten their Fried Chicken and Hibachi Chicken, along with sides of Lima Beans, Potato Salad, Corn Bread and the Cabbage/Carrots combo that comes with the Hibachi offerings.  

JCT sits on Parkside Avenue just north of Olden Avenue Extension in a somewhat rundown retail strip center which also has a Chinese takeout joint and an Italian pizzeria. Nice to have options. 

While I enjoyed the entertainment of watching these three guys preparing the food, the actual finished products were only average.  The Fried Chicken combo of breast and wing was nicely meaty and never frozen, however the coating did not have very much flavor compared to the standards we all know.  It lacked sufficient spices to really stand out.  The white meat was plump and juicy and would have really shined with the right flour mix.  The accompanying Potato Salad was nicely sweet, but the Lima Beans were supersized and mushy.  The Corn Bread was pretty good. 

The Hibachi Chicken order was large and with the Veggies really weighed down the container.  It was cut into small strips and doused well with Hibachi Sauce throughout grilling.  It was interesting to see the American short order grill used for a Japanese dish.  I had not thought of that before, but it was cool to put those two cultural icons together. The chicken was tender and had a nice flavor.  The veggies of Steamed Cabbage and Carrots were a little boring; lacking much taste.  

JC Teriyaki is a mixed bag.  I like the concept demonstrating the cross-cultural bonds between Southern American cooking and Japanese grilling, but had higher expectations for the actual results.  Perhaps, the pricing of the meals (quite low) interferes with the ability to really pull out the stops and make the meals memorable. 

3.5 Stars is probably the right place to be here, but I want to encourage an upgrade in performance quality which won't happen without a little mild criticism.

The same shop as the former Food Castle, this north Indian restaurant offers a menu of both Indian and Chinese cuisine.  They are on opposite sides of the take out menu, and no Chinese dishes were available in the luncheon buffet.  I have heard a lot about the Indo-Sino kitchens, but have yet to actually try it.  It is not clear that New Moghul cooks that way, but when I was there only Indian dishes were displayed.  

Arriving just before 2, there was only one other customer.  I perused the offerings and filled my large plate with Vegetable Samosa, Chicken Tandoori and Chicken Makhani, Paneer Makhani, Chana Masala, Vegetable Biriyani and Naan.  They were all good, but none outstanding.  Having two Makhani dishes seemed redundant, but the sauce was nice and creamy. The Tandoori Chicken was the freshest on the table, as a new tray of it was brought out while I was loading up.  It was tender and easily separated from the bone.  It was predominantly thighs and drums.  The Biriyani was a nice dark color and had a pleasant flavor.  

What I am discovering is that if you want to have Indian buffet for lunch, it is better to arrive early and eat when all the dishes are just out of the kitchen.  I am a late luncher, and it seems that many of the tureens are not heated, and left in the open for a few hours.  Many offerings are past their prime, and less enjoyable.  

I was satisfied with my meal at New Moghul, but I have had much better North or South Indian victuals recently, and this place is not up to that standard.  To be completely fair, I will have to return for dinner and see if that changes the story.  Still, if a resto is going to offer a buffet it should be a reflection of what is available if ordering off the menu.  

By that guide, this place is only A-OK.

I am in the minority on this one, but to me the name misrepresents the products and atmosphere of the 2 Paris Baguettes that I have visited.  

While the shop here is smallish and in the basement of the H Mart building, it is clean and has good service.  Yet, the selection here is not as varied as in the plant in Edison, New Jersey, and the seating arrangements not as comfortable.  

Most important is that while all the baked goods I have tried are fresh and soft, they bear no relation to the boulangerie found in its namesake, Paris, France.  There, the taste and texture of each of the pastries is unique, while here they are uniform and provide little differentiation.  Yes. They are all sweet and tender, but are not anything like a French bakery.  Perhaps, I was spoiled living in France and enjoying the pleasure of great croissant and other delights on a daily basis, but as "nice" as these offerings are, they do not approach the amazing flavors and surprises found on every corner in Paris.  

Paris Baguette?  C'est nes pas vrai.

I seem to be going to more movies now that my son is old enough to go with friends, but before he can drive himself there. I had not gone to many theaters until this year as it was easier to rent at home.  I am enjoying the big screen experience again. 

This United Artists Theaters @ Oxford Valley Mall is a freestanding building on the outer ring of the property with plenty of parking, and a short walk to the food court across the parking field.  It is one of the slightly older generation of modern cinema multiplexes, built about 20 years ago with some refurbishments.  It is a pleasant place to watch a movie; bigger theaters, decent sound, but without IMAX at this time.  

Saw Man of Steel last night with young son.  For a first week of a potential blockbuster on a Friday evening, the place was surprisingly underpopulated.  The seats are comfortable with drink holders, but not as spacious nor as comfy as @ Neshaminy Mall. The popcorn is not always fresh here, as they seem to only make it every few hours, rather than on a more ordered approach. That is a no-no as the popcorn available for home purchase these days is excellent, and this does not compare most of the time. I won't mention the prices.

My favorite movie venue is the old Newtown Theater, where I can easily imagine I am sitting in the dark sometime around 1960.  The seats are old and creaky, and the screen is not designed for HD, and the projection equipment is in need of replacement for 21st Century viewers; but it is still an awesome experience up in the balcony with girlfriend and chaperon.

Sport's Pizza is located at the end of Makefield Road, just before it reaches Woolston Avenue in Morrisville, Pa.  It is far off the street in a dated strip center behind a gas station. It is very easy to miss, as I did the first time through.  It is a small shop with 6 booths, and clearly deals primarily in take away.  They have a wall of pizza boxes at the ready.  

I was there for a light meal to replace the dinner I was too late to prepare at home.  I saw a handwritten sign that they had chicken noodle soup as a special, which piqued my interest on a chilly night.  Walking in and chatting with the woman at the register, I learned that the Brooklyn Pie was a new item.  There were a couple of squares left in the display, and I went for the corner slice to maximize the crunchy crust.  I also asked for a bowl of the soup.  Both were under $5.  

I like my tomato pie well done, and asked for that.  It arrived on paper plate before the soup (?), not as hot as it should have been, but still warm enough to satisfy my desire for a hot meal.  I don't understand why some places can't handle requests for well done (reheated) pizza, and insist that everyone wants it the same less than optimal temperature.  Still, I recognized that the crust was done decently, and the sauce/cheese ratio was fine.  Nice touch to see a sprig of basil.  I've had better. 

The soup was another matter.  It was very hot (microwave reheat), with lots of chicken, veggies and a few noodles, in a nice mild bird bouillon. A shake of black pepper and I was in business.  I liked it a lot. Enough to remember to order it again when in the vicinity. 

I enjoyed sitting down next to a poster of Allen Iverson.  I would love a real meal with him to talk about his election to the Basketball Hall of Fame and what an awesome basketball warrior he was.

Dominick's has been the pizza standard bearer in Washington Crossing for decades, but I had not stopped to sample their pies for a very long time.  After a dinner at their sister ship in Richboro a few weeks ago, I was tempted to return here to see if the magic was carried from oven to oven.  I went in for lunch earlier this week to find out.

First thing I noticed was that the once smallish primarily take out pizza parlor had expanded considerably.  It how had a dining room and a bar!  The rear area was dressed up a la a street scene in Napoli and the side barroom designed for those desirous of libations and wide screen TV with their Italian meal.  This room felt a little unfinished as things were stored in plain sight, and the quality of the furnishings did not match the richer feel of the wooden and mirrored bar.  

I ordered two slices of regular Tomato Pie and took my seat in the barroom to await the call to get them after reheating.  That call never came, so I walked back into the central area to inquire.  The slices in the oven had been forgotten and were now two charred triangles ready for dumping.  Honest apologies were forthcoming.  They put in two more slices and promptly called me when ready.  

They held their points when lifted, and had a pleasing crunch to the last bite.  The sauce was mildly sweet as I prefer, and the mozza still white after the furnace indicating it had begun that morning as a fresh cheese.  Nice.  Thin ribbons of basil lay on top of both, adding another texture and taste dimension.  

These were good slices, but far from the best I have had in the past year.  Yet, the price with a Snapple came to under $6., which was a good deal.  

To be a fan, I have to feel a desire to return for more in a short time.  Short of that, it is fairest to say that the pie is decent, but not memorable enough for me to put it on the short list of favorite places, let alone the pizza pantheon of great pies. 

By way of comparison, I found the Richboro location to be more comfortable, with better service and more compelling food.  This proved that carrying the same name and pedigree does not guarantee the same experience from place to place.

This place is the Penn Dot Driver's Service Center these days, although the signage may not have kept up with the its common parlance. Regardless, this is where you go in this part of Bucks County for all things driver's license and auto registration related.  It sits at the bottom of Neshaminy Boulevard, just behind the mall.  

It was time for my license renewal (with photo), and I also needed information about how to secure a license for someone from out of country applying for the first time.  The first was accomplished in less than 10 minutes just before 4:00 on a beautiful Spring afternoon.  The second took a bit longer, as I learned that in order to secure a license for a foreigner who is waiting for a Green Card, is to obtain a social security number first, and then have a doctor complete another form vouching that the applicant does not suffer from a seizure disorder.
