The coffee arrived in a thermos pitcher for unlimited refills, and the milk I requested, in a small stainless vessel.  It was decent java, but without pedigree. Nice to have all I wanted.

The main course was basically a thick cut cinnamon bread dipped in egg, and heated on the grill.  It was good, but because of its thickness, the egg did not penetrate deeply into the slices.  They were pretty dry, and the extra dose of their syrup (not maple) helped a bit, but, could not compensate for the lack of egg melding with the texture of the bread, which is what french toast is all about. So, it was okay, but not what it could have been given the excellent raw materials. 

Too bad, because the Dish could have been a real contender.

Difficult to find office complex cafe in Yardley (actually, Lower Makefield), off Stony Hill Road. It is in the 790 Building which is in the middle of this corporate center. Signage is minimal. The easiest path is to walk around the right end of the building, locate the outdoor patio dining area, and enter through that door. Otherwise, you will be walking down long hallways without assurance you will reach your destination. Obviously, The Weekday Cafe (nice alliteration), is meant primarily for the folk who work in the complex, but if I owned the business, I would want to cast a larger net. 

This is the third food operation at this location in about as many years, so they have their work cut out for them. Getting the word out beyond this small universe is critical. 

And, while the attractive shop is diminutive, it is worth discovering. They do a decent breakfast with a limited menu and good coffee. Service is friendly and efficient. My "Early Riser" sausage, egg and cheese on toasted English muffin was solid and cost only $2.95. The java flowed hot and strong. 

This morning, a few other office workers came in to pick up something to take to their desks, but not enough to make a success. Hopefully, their lunch trade carries them.  They do have two other similar locations in Ewing and Hamilton, NJ, that are larger and also require excellent tracking skills to find, but seem to be doing well. 

As this Weekday Cafe is closest to home, I wish them good luck and smart advertising.

La Casa di Lucia on the farthest end of Bustleton Avenue, in Northeast Philadelphia about a mile before reaching Bucks County, is another decent Italian restaurant slinging traditional dishes to the people of the nearby hoods. There is a big bar in the front of the house, and a small dining room behind it, with a larger banquet room to the side. It is clean and attractive. And, if you enjoy a cabaret feel with sultry smoky chanteuse, this house provides the entertainment several nights a week. 

We were there for a light supper after strong foot massage, and La Casa di Lucia fit the bill. Plenty of choices, solid service and reasonable prices. This is the case in many such restaurants in this neck of the woods. We ordered a Caesar salad and large pizza, half mushrooms, half plain.  Both arrived within ten minutes.  

It was a large salad with plenty of romaine, and good homemade dressing. We could even taste the anchovy paste. It was a strong accompaniment to the pizza. The pie was good, too, but not as crisp and balanced as I like, and as are available not very far away. Plenty of cheese (perhaps too much compared to the red sauce, garlic and basil elements).  The crust was still too moist making it impossible to pick up and hold its point. Had to fold it immediately to avoid a hot cheese slide onto the plate or lap. Taste was decent, but the texture needed a kick in the crotch to stiffen it up. Took half of it home for later consumption. 

I would try La Casa di Lucia again to see what their dinners were about, but would pass on the tomato pie.

Maybe it's the way I was introduced to BBQ that spoiled me for the suburban variant, but unless I can smell the meat in the smoker, and the piquant sauces bubbling in their vats, I feel somewhat deprived of the true experience. 

As a city kid, BBQ was something the family enjoyed as we drove south or west and came across a roadside shack along a two land blacktop with a hand painted wood sign that said, "BBQ," or just had a picture of a pig painted on the corrugated tin roof.  So, going into a modern shopping center and entering a store for this most American meal just does not feel quite right. The space was dressed up to remind of those places, but aside from the flies buzzing my sandwich, it lacked true authenticity.  The lack of proper context detracted from the moment. 

Still, my Pulled Pork Sammy was tasty and filling.  The Fries were too salty, but that is a matter of preference.  The meat was fully smoked; soft and pleasantly chewy.  The sauce was sweet and tart as I like it.  There were 3 table rockets with hot, hotter, and vinegar BBQ options.  They all were fine, if not unique. While the abundance of winged creatures at first annoyed as they Kamakazied my lunch, I soon began to find them amusing as the only commonality with my boyhood country experiences. 

Yes. Most everything was Okay, but not addictive enough to draw me back on their own.

Newly renovated Men's Warehouse opened recently in Lincoln Plaza, Langhorne, PA, close by Oxford Valley Mall. We stopped in looking for a suit for my stepson, who had secured a promotion at work and wanted to upgrade his wardrobe with new threads. 

Although the store is fairly large, the actual in store suit selection was meagre. Admittedly, the young man is tall and thin (6'3", 160 lbs.), but to have only two dark colored suits on the rack was disappointing to say the least. In fact, they had nothing in his size. Our salesperson did her best to make something work, by mixing and matching pants and jacket in one size larger to approximate his actual measurements. Ultimately, we were able to determine the right sizes, which then had to be ordered for shipping to our home. 

Luckily, I know a guy good with needle and thread. 

The shop seemed to have plenty of dress shirts and ties, as well as a reasonable supply of casual ware. Yet, they were bereft of more formal work clothes for the professionals in the crowd. Don't know if this is a decision by management based on actual marketing data, or just a supply chain issue, but given that this brand used to advertise to the well dressed male, it is hard to comprehend how far from that image Men's Warehouse has fallen. Perhaps, this is more evidence of new pandemic workplace realities, but some people still have to go to work and dress for success. 

It would appear Men's Warehouse has decided that those people are not enough to carry the business as it once did. It is hard to justify another visit. 

2.5 STARS

Nice Korean green grocery in the Morrisville Shopping Center on Old Trenton Road. Plenty to choose at prices better than the local supermarkets, but not as good as the true farmers' market at Tanners' Brothers in Richboro. Butcher and fishmonger, too. 

Interesting oddities, too, like Polish kielbasa and German Milka chocolates. 

Worth going to when a major veggie and fruit expedition is planned and you don't have time for Tanners' or the Bristol Amish Market.

Plenty to keep you curious, entertained and in the greens.

This DD franchise approximates the mean of all Dunkins.  

Decent Java, but too dependent on the water quality.  Bakery goods sweet and addicting. 

Biggest issue is the location in the Lalor Plaza down at the bottom of Lalor Street, just off Rt. 129.  No problem during the day, but a bit sketchy after dusk.  But, this strip houses one of my secret lunch houses, Perfetto Pizza; so I find myself in this hood at least once a month.  

Big plus - Bilingual staff!

"You can take the boy out of the city, but you can't take the city out of the boy " 

Very true. Perhaps this is why I always look forward to exploring Philly neighborhoods for cool places to eat. Today it was The New Olympia House on Castor Avenue that had my time and attention. A corner luncheonette that has been slinging hash for more than half a century, this little piece of Athens is well preserved, with long counter with about 10 spinners, booths behind that, and a large dining room behind the kitchen in this double wide row house neighborhood. The charm and cultural history were all in place, much as it has operated since 1960. I was very happy to have found the joint as I straddled the stool and was approached by the attractive server in black spandex pants.

The question at hand was - would the kitchen support the excited first impression, or no? 

The answer was discovered soon enough. For this breakfast at least, the rude awakening was in the negative - my anticipation was better than the reality this day. 

My french toast looked golden brown, and the old style syrup dispenser with slip down spring metal opening was way cool. However, the underside chassis had too much char, resulting in a burnt taste that required extra syrup to offset. That taste led me to think that the grill was not cleaned between orders, leaving burnt butter or other lubricant around to stick to the next food sizzling there. It also meant a lack of attention by the short order cook (not chef), and an attempt to hide the dark side from view. The three slices were ample, and had the decision been made to start afresh rather than hope I didn't notice, would have made me a true fan.

First impression dashed. 

The Cecilware drip coffee was fine. I love those old contraptions. Yet, despite all the help behind the counter, no one saw that my small cup was bereft of coffee and needed refilling, until I asked. Hard to understand such inattentiveness when I was the only customer sitting there. Chalk it up to my invisibility, sometimes not the best superpower to practice while dining. 

Still, I liked New Olympia House enough to regret this happenstance, and wish for a better experience. This could have been one of those true Philadelphia moments that only the city's profound indifference to perfection in the face of amazing potential, created the opportunity to transcend low expectations and truly hit the mark in miraculous laudation. 

That moment must await a more hopeful day.

A1 Japanese Steakhouse sits in the strip center anchored by IHOP at the intersection of RT. 1 and Oxford Valley Road, Fairless Hills. It is one of the older sushi/hibachi houses, run by Chinese ownership and because of location and age, one of the less expensive operations. While the quality of the experience is a step down from the more modern Mt. Fuji, Sakura, Oishi, Arirang, etc., joints found throughout lower Bucks County, the difference is not so great as to make it unworthy of your dining out dollar, but is noticeable. 

What do I mean? A1 is carpeted wall to wall. They doubtlessly hide the remains of years of food tossing by hibachi chefs entertaining customers with food flips aimed for your mouth. They would have to shampoo the floor weekly to keep the place with passing grade. They don't. With each grill housing its own grease trap, it is dubious that it is emptied and cleaned regularly. Yet, the health inspectors allow the business to remain open, so it is up to you to be vigilant.

Still, the food served looks and tastes good. Our salmon fillets (2 each) were fresh and presented well with sides of fried rice, mushroom soup (few in the small bowl) and grilled mixed veggies. Plenty to eat and even take home without ordering anything more. They even comp everyone 3 grilled shrimp. Nice touch. Their bar offers mostly national brand beers (Sam Adams Boston Lager) as well as some of those fancy ass fruity sweet things in hurricane glasses. So, if your policy on cleanliness is, "Don't ask, Don't Tell," you won't have a problem with A1. 

One suggestion, salt free soy sauce for the chefs as they squirt and cook. Standard soy sauce tends to make everything have a similar taste, detracting from the natural flavors that should predominate.

Old school Wawa in the center of Main Street, Yardley Boro. Small parking lot in front. Larger one in back, but you may not know its there unless your local. Small footprint that still manages to provide most of the products and services of the latest supersized versions. 

I was there to pick up a chicken salad hoagie before moving on to my next appointment. It had been a while since ordering with their touch screens and found the shear number of pages I had to endure to be somewhat daunting. How many screens just for mayo?! 

Still, the sandwich was good with fresh chicken salad, but perhaps less so for the torpedo roll. Enjoyable, nonetheless. 

Everyone there was well trained and friendly from front door welcome to cashier thank you for coming. Price was very appealing, with the customized sammy ten inch coming in at under $7. 

Little wonder why almost everyone wants a Wawa near their town.

I don't know what it is, but gambling doesn't appeal to me. I understand the enjoyment some seem to have risking and most often losing their hard earned money, but I don't share the feeling. I also see that most lose what they come with, and would have been better off going bowling. But, I am not adverse to observing the mostly self-destructive behavior close up by sitting at a Blackjack table for a while and playing a few hands. 

Some feel comfortable in a casino. I never have. Yet, Parx is very big and often so crowded that I feel invisible. That allows me to wander around close to the action, yet not be part of it. The occasional whoop from winning a big pot, or cry of angry frustration losing one are part of a tragi/comedy that plays out hundreds of times a day. The staff seems well trained to deal with the range of human emotions, and nothing gets out of control. 

The best things are the number of food choices at reasonable prices. Happy hours are extensive and often late at night. It is possible to grab a drink and decent snack or dinner without handing over a $20 without change. If your not losing too much, Parx can be a decent date night, with live entertainment and lots of people watching. 

Biggest negative - This is a smokers space. Anxiety increases the habit. The air system is not totally effective, so health is an issue. No doubt the employees are involved in risky behavior. Healthcare is not available to most workers unless they reached full time status, which is strictly formulated. You just can't afford to accept the exposure for very long. 

Once a year is more than enough. 

2,500 employees. That is a lot.

This is strictly a 2 slices and a drink review. 

Amato's on Trenton Road in Fairless Hills, is an attractive space for a neighborhood Italian meal.  On this Monday evening, it was bustling.  I found a deuce in the front window after looking at the pizza-on-display under glass at the front of the kitchen/cashier area.  It all looked good, but I was most attracted to the square cut Brooklyn and Amato Pies, and ordered one of each, "well done."  

The point about "well done" reheated pizza is my attempt to awaken the previously baked pie's essence by making the cheese and sauce bubble again to bring out the original flavors.  There is little worse than a pie that has been sitting around for a while, and is only partially reanimated by inadequate oven exposure the second time around. If the oven master understands me, he knows that I don't mind a scorched undercarriage in my search for more taste.  

A friendly server brought the hot squares to my table on a small aluminum pizza pan.  It looked good as the steam hit my glasses.  I asked for knife and fork because there was little crust to gasp and I didn't want to burn my digits. 

First bite I realized that the crust had not been reheated sufficiently, while the topside was significantly hotter. The taste was okay, but the platform was soft and far from the more rigid structure I prefer.  The Tomato Sauce was dark thick red, and was nicely spiced.  As I looked around at the tables with fresh baked pies, I saw that those folks were able to lift their triangles without wilting, nor spillage.  They seemed quite happy with their food.

My wish is that all pizza parlors selling warmed over slices understand that those of us who can't handle a whole pie desire the same sensory experience as everyone else, and take the time to bring the fresh pizza "zing" to the rest of us.  I know it's a loss leader for many shops, but regardless of the price, failure to provide full participation only means they have a less than satisfied customer.

If you are up and about very early, go to Cramer to get fresh donuts, muffins and scones.  Too, if you can order a cake for a special occasion, you will probably be quite satisfied. Otherwise, despite the charm of an old fashioned bakery, and the butternut aroma, the products are inconsistent, and pricey. The bread, bagels, rolls are not worth the trip. There are much stronger options for them only minutes away.
To be a worthwhile destination everything must be good, available, and reasonably priced compared to the competition. Cramer is not quite all that.

Cha's Seafood sits in on Pennington Avenue, Trenton, NJ, in a small "L" shaped shopping plaza where an old factory used to be.  It is very clean inside, with a large selection of breaded fillets and semi prepared shellfish, crabs and king crab legs in various sauces for purchase by the pound or in platters to take out.  The space is large enough for a few tables, but that is not their business model.  

I stopped in for lunch this week around 1:30 pm, and I was just about the only customer there. I ordered a whiting lunch (3 fillets, fries, 2 slices of whole wheat, small cup of macaroni salad and a bottle of water for about $7.50, including tax.  The price was definitely right. 

The fish was sliced thin and breaded in corn meal before bathing in the deep fryer.  I could only eat two of the fillets made into a sandwich, and left most of the fries behind.  They were okay, but far to many to eat in a balanced meal.   

Strangely, they did not offer any mayo, tarter sauce, nor even ketchup with the take away lunch. Any of those would have added to the flavor of the fish and taters, which was sort of  plain as it was.  Next time, I will be sure to ask for those accessories.  

Overall, just a decent, but unexciting monochromatic lunch.  Those pre-seasoned crabs and other shellfish did look pretty good.  

Octavia did a good job taking care of me.  She was friendly and informative.

Pho Washington is the latest restaurant at this shopping center location at 6th and Washington. The menu is fairly limited to traditional street food of Vietnam - pho (noodle soup), com (broken rice dishes) and vermicelli (rice noodles bowls with choice of meat and greens). They also have a long list of beverages on the back page. 

We stopped in before grocery shopping at 1st Asian Supermarket across 6th St. We ordered Pho Tai (beef broth w thin ribeye steak slices) and Vermicelli w Grilled Pork, Spring Roll and Shredded Lettuce (w thin sweet dipping sauce on the side). We started with Summer Rolls with thick ground peanut brown sauce.

Everything was good to very good, without any knockouts. The appetizer rolls were loaded with sliced shrimp and cabbage in a cool, sticky rice wrap. The sauce stuck to what it touched, so it really dominated the taste of the dish. The wrap was quite chewy. It was okay. The small bowl of pho was more than we could finish after adding all the sprouts, Thai basil, jalapeno and squeezed lime juice. The steak was plentiful and cooked well in the beef broth. While the beef stock was good, it needed more simmering with pot spices to attain the right degree of subtle richness. We squirted some sirracha from the table rocket to boost the flavor, which helped alot.

 I liked the vermicelli plate the most. The pork was delicious with or without dipping in the accompanying sweet vinegar dip. It was tender and fully exposed with a few chews. The noodles were both warm and cool depending on where it was in the bowl in proximity to hot or cool food. Both temps were fine, and I found that pouring some of the sauce over everything enhanced the flavor of each element, but wasn't essential. I would definitely get that again, but probably go to Pho Ha across the parking lot for quality well cured pho. 

Service was fine and prices reasonable for the overall experience. 
 
The bakery next door looked like the right place to hang out over Vietnamese coffee with condensed milk and pastries. Next time for that!

This was my first visit to a Sonic Drive-In.  This one has been around on North Olden Avenue in Ewing for only a few years. The place has two rows of drive-in slots where you can enjoy their rollerskating, eat in the car, gimmick. With an outside temperature over 90 degrees, the better choice was to go inside and enjoy the air conditioning and stop polluting for a while. 

The place was clean and bright with Sonic Radio playing background muzak, and LED HD displays showing their standard menu and specials. There was no one in there but me when I arrived at 1:30.  The young woman at the single cashier post was friendly and seemed to enjoy having a little customer contact rather than talking to people all day long through headphones. 

The Carhop Classic for $3.99 was an irresistible deal.  Single burger loaded with cheese, mayo, mustard, ketchup, lettuce and tomato, it was a nice size. It came with a choice of onion rings, fries or tater tots.  I went with the later. The actual burger experience was pretty much average. Far from the best fast food burger I've ever had, but far from the worst, too.  Not all that much flavor, but the overall bitechew was okay.  At least it did not arrive crushed like at 5 Guys, nor cold as so often happens at the Burger Kings of the world. The price/quality proposition was decent given the special available on this combo. 

Would I rush back? No. Would I avoid Sonic all together? No. Aside from the drive in cultural history, it is really no more than middle of the pack. If it was nearby when I was hungry, I would gladly chow down. Inside or out.

This update is strictly for the breakfast this morning.

Their deli does prepare a limited breakfast menu, but unless you like microwaved eggs and sausage grilled between the cheeks of a pannini press, this might not be the place for you.  Absent a genuine grill they did a fairly good job on my sausage, egg and cheese sandy.  I do wonder if they clean that press before putting other breaded sandwiches inside.  

While the taste and price were decent, I prefer the use of a grill to prepare my eggs and melt the cheese.  Although the coffee was okay and the ambiance very much "from the barn," I will likely not return for breakfast. 

It remains a good place to buy farm fresh produce and enjoy the seasonal outdoor events.

The Pa Turnpike Commission has done a good job renovating the old service plazas along the roadway.  The Valley Forge stop is one of the smaller ones on the eastbound side.  It has only Starbucks and an A Plus Mini Mart for everything else.  

It is clean and designed with high exposed beam ceilings and lots of glass to let in light.  Restrooms modern with waterless urinals and fast hand dry systems above the sinks.  It is certainly a big improvement over the old factory that was here.  But, it is still only a small oasis along a roadway that has had a difficult winter dealing with snow and vehicles trapped in bad conditions.  

Hard to be a fan of something like a turnpike rest stop.  But, it is certainly A-OK.

Tried the Korean BBQ Chicken Sandwich thinking it would have the crunchy skin of those excellent Korean wings in the form of a deep fried breast. Well, it wasn't that as it lacked the texture, but the chicken itself was plump and a big chew. Similarly, the family enjoyed the Chipotle Melt, Nashville Hot and Mike's Hot Honey. All substantial. All entertaining with their various sauces. 

But, it became obvious that despite the overall quality of the sandwiches, they were wildly overpriced at $10 apiece including tax. They were smaller that Popeye's at nearly twice the cost. Given the comparison, Popeye, or even Chick-fil-A, are better. 

Beyond the merits, I found myself in a situation with a small sign on the door that said they would be closing at 7 temporarily. That was fine, but their website didn't alert the public to that fact, nor did Yelp nor Google. Besides, it was only 6:40, so why were the grills shut off leaving no burgers, no fries and no salad? In fact, they were out of everything but chicken, so I ordered four different sandwiches hoping my peeps would understand why they weren't getting what they wanted. 

I guess if you're plum out of supplies it's time to stop the grill, but it doesn't do much for the disappointment in the belly.

By now, Isaac Newtown's is one of the old places in a very old town. It's gotta be at least twenty years sitting back in the parking lot along Newtown Creek.  

Go for the incredible beer on tap or bottles, burgers, Caesar salads, quiche and calzone, but most of the rest of the menu is not as good as what they do best. Prices are decent, if a $10. burger does not scandalize you. 

The facility has charm and worn ambiance and the floor plan is comfortable and uncrowded.  The upstairs dining area is where they generally seat families, but with booths you can only hear the kids, and it does not get unpleasant. The best seat in the house is at or near the bar, and that room gets crowded Friday - Sunday nights. Still, you will find many knowledgeable beer lovers hanging out, so you can have a seminar about hops along with your Belgian or local craft brew. 

The bathrooms are in the basement, down a steep flight of stairs.  They can be a challenge after a few, and I have never been able to escape the sensation of descending into Dante's lair.  

Still, a good local pub with a long beer list and decent bar food. The dinners, not so much.

A Little Dragon sits in the same part of the Makefield Shopping Center as India Garden, but casts a much smaller shadow.  It does a good job with its American Chinese menu, and the price range is competitive with its peers in the area.  The floor plan has about a dozen comfortable booths.  The TV hung high on the back wall was showing CCTV News, the English language station in the PRC, for those of us who wanted to catch up on what was happening there with a pronounced nationalistic accent. 

I had a basic lunch deal.  Wonton Soup, General's Chicken, Egg Roll and Fried Rice, which came in at $8.50 with tax.  The soup was based in chicken consume out of a can, and was a bit salty.  The wontons had a thicker skin, but the filling had a better taste and consistency than other places.  The egg roll was 95% cabbage, but there were traces of pork and shrimp.  The General was in full uniform and filled the oval plate completely with the fried rice covering most of it.  The sauce was nicely spiced, rather than the often overly-sweet variant often found in this dish.  The rice was loaded with pork and veggies.  

I was a little surprised that A Little Dragon made the effort to provided above average Americanized Chinois. While it will never be confused with authentic cuisine that can be found in Philly or The City, it at least knows what it is, and does a good job of it without apology.  

By now, Chinese/American is becoming its own distinct cuisine.  It may never be as purely satisfying as the real deal, but if you have a taste for it, this is a decent place to express it.

Jahan Kabob & Grill takes a bit of getting used to. 

As a first-timer, I approached the shop looking for a door to the restaurant, and realized that it really wasn't a separate dining room, but a part of the larger well endowed beer store.  The kitchen is on one wall, and the tables for eating are along the front sharing floor plan with the beer display aisles.  There is a small opening in the kitchen's partition for placing orders, and then the long wait for preparation and service.  On a post snow winter night it is not the most comfortable place to dine. Live and learn. 

The food, however, has promise.  Based on a Yelp suggestion we had the Spicy Chicken Cheesesteak, along with the Samosa app, the Banjan Eggplant side, and the Garden Salad. The Samosas were flat philo dough filled with very tasty Potato, Pea, Onion, and Pepper stuffing. They were very good.  The Spicy Chicken Cheesesteak came on a quality roll, and had an unusual taste that I thoroughly enjoyed. The spice was one that I did not recognize, and added the proper complement of heat. The accompanying fries were ordinary. If the meal had stopped there we would have been approaching a 5 star culinary experience. But, the Garden Salad was rather limited and bland, and we picked through it.  The Banjan Eggplant was sopping in its cooking oil, and although the taste with the Potato and Pepper was decent, the oiliness was too much and dominated the texture and overall experience. The Naan was cold, likely a misplacement of a heated bread, but tough and almost stale-tasting. 

The reality of having beer buyers roaming the premises in close proximity to our table was not a big deal, but was noticeable and constant.  The slow service was understandable because there were only 2 people working the kitchen, and one was taking orders, packing the take out, and serving our meal. She was very nice and was aware of the problems. A third pair of hands would have been helpful to them, but the beer side of the operation did not seem to have anything to do with the restaurant, and they were not assisting each other.  Management might want to consider hiring someone who can help out on both ends. 

Jahan is better utilized as a take out joint.  The custom beer operation is very interesting, and next time I would spend the time waiting for the food to go by selecting some exotic brews to bring home to accompany the Afghani victuals.  The Samosas and Cheesesteaks are worth another bite, and the menu may hide a few other worthy offerings. 

It is not the place to bring a date for a romantic evening, unless looking at beer while noshing on comfort food is your thing.

Another of the Super Wawa gas station/convenience stores that seem to have sprung up almost overnight in this part of South Jersey.  

The gasoline prices are competitive, but you never know who the real producer/distributor is for any of them.  So, it likely isn't wise to use it too often.  The convenience store takes its cues from the Sheetz, A Plus, Quik Cheks and turnpike service centers of the world. Every kind of sugar and quick energy drink is available.  In this case, the deli actually is capable to turning out decent sandwiches and soups.  

I am not a fan of these places, but understand their efficacy.  They serve their purpose, and even offer reasonably good java.

Cattycorner from Pete's Steakhouse Tavern, Jeppy's is as small as Pete's is big. 

It is primarily a take out joint with only a couple of tables in the closet sized space for guys like me who work near by, but don't want to eat at their desks.  I met the owner/manager who was friendly and had no problem fixing me up after 3:00 with their 2 Slice and a Drink Special at $4.95.  

The pie was okay, but could have been more if it had spent enough time back in the oven to totally reheat the triangles to the original temperature, rather than removing them when only lukewarm.  The flavor was right, but the crust texture was soft and doughy from failure to bring the crust to the near molten state required to make it firm and crunchy.  As this seems to be endemic to many places, it may be my job to ask for a "well done" slice so they are left to burn a bit longer.  

Otherwise, Jeppy's is a cool little place.  Much like the Little Engine That Could, Jeppy's sits across from Big Boy Pete's and with all its glare and attitude, repeating over and over, "I think I can. I think I can..." 

Until it becomes, "I know I can. I know I can...."

Hong Kong Pearl is a mixed bag.

The facility is dark and dreary at high noon, giving the sensation of being in a 1940's movie.  Yet, the service is prompt and attentive, somewhat anomalous for a Chinese house.  The main courses are well prepared, with some attention to detail, but it takes a few shortcuts that diminish the overall quality of the meal.  The broth for the Wonton Soup is chokingly salty and a brownish tint that suggests use of bouillon with prepackaged salt, dye and possibly MSG to cut costs.  In a similar manner, the Fried Rice arrives artificially colored a dark tawny cast from its mass production earlier in the day. Both soup and rice are vastly inferior to the prime attraction, but as they are served with practically every meal, the overall result is "mixed."  

On the other hand, the General Tso's Chicken was quite good in the context of a suburban Americanized Chinese shop.  It used chicken that had not been frozen long, if at all, a pleasant coating, and a sauce that used correct spices to attain the right sweet/hot spot that makes for a happy General. It even had whole chili peppers in the dish.  That was a big positive. 

While I would not rush back to Hong Kong Pearl, it was certainly a decent place for lunch.  If they would eliminate the problems with the soup and rice, and attempt to make them the right way - with a long simmering stock and just in time fried rice, it could be an exceptional experience for this part of the world.

I know it's just me. 

The folks at Berryssimo put a ton of money and effort into making their fro/yo shop unique from all the other build-your-own softee empororiums.  The back wall where the yogurt is dispensed in various flavors is made of gray slate stone. Very attractive.  The front of the space is a little sitting area overlooking State Street through wall to wall, ceiling to floor, windows.  Nice.  And, the staff is warm, pleasant and helpful (Thanks, Sophie).  

Yet, where the yogurt meets the mouth, I find the same experience as in the other less well appointed stores.  Regardless of the sign on the machine and the small picture attached to same designating the flavor that will extrude when the handle is lifted, the actual experience is the same - looks good, feels good, but does not taste so good.  I sampled the Tahitian Vanilla, Very Berry, and Cookies & Cream, and added some Blackberry and Reece Cup toppings.  

The texture was smooth and creamy and the toppings were rich and full, but the taste of the yogurt was practically non-existent.  I tried to sample them one at a time despite being in one cup.  A weak response to each of them, with the Berry being the strongest.  Just not worth the nearly $8 I paid for it.  Compared to the ice cream available very close by, the yogurt seems an empty vessel.  

For my decadent sweet tooth, I want to be overwhelmed with pleasure; luxuriate in the smooth creaminess, close my eyes when the aromatic sweetness assaults my tongue and shoots to the brain.  None of this happens with Berryssimo, nor most other fro/yo joints.  

I must be immune to that experience for some reason with super chilled yogurt.  I see that others are very satisfied.  I wish I was, too.

While I generally like Red Robin Gourmet Burgers for the consistency of the food in all locations, I find that this particular restaurant being very close to Sesame Place has a noise level just on the other side of comfortable.  Given the choice I prefer the newer facility close by Neshaminy Mall, which although smaller, is more modern and offers a cozier roadhouse feel.  Too, perhaps because of so many kids eating grilled cheese sandwiches, the signature burgers often are not finished to the desired degree, and present in less than tantalizing form.  Last time I was here my server did not ask how I wanted my burger done. I volunteered that I like it medium, but it came out well done anyway.  Maybe that was why I wasn't asked.  I also was not offered the endless fries that are so heavily advertised. 

The burgers are okay in both places and the fries still better than average. The shakes are a bit underwhelming compared to their competition at Cheeburger Cheeburger, Nifty Fifty, and Jakes Wayback. Better to stick with the alternatives like bottomless limeaid or iced tea, where you can hydrate without the sugar rush, and even share the drink if one of you gets water.  

It is likely better to come to this shop after Sesame Place is closed for the season, and some quality control is reasserted.  This place is a gold mine usually filled to capacity. Sometimes that success goes to the bottom line, but gets lost in the kitchen and on the floor. 

See you in the winter.

"...Pulled into Plumsteadville, I was feelin' about half passed dead.
Just need some place where I can lay my head.
Say, sister, can you tell me where a man might find a bed? 
She just grinned, shook her head. 'No,' was all she said..."
(With apologies to Bob Dylan)

It may have been the heat of a near-100 degree day, or maybe the high humidity that seemed to choke the breath out of every living being, but here I was in Plumsteadville feeling slightly desert crazed and in need of hydration and restoration.  The Inn materialized in front of me, a shimmering apparition.  Real or not, I was stopping in for a drink and lunch.  

Perhaps, it was my gaunt appearance when I walked into the barroom, but it seemed no one saw me as I sat down on a corner stool.  I allowed the dim coolness to resuscitate me.  Finally, a bartender saw me there and came over to see what, "...it'll be."  

"Summer Shandy and a Bison Burger, medium, please."

"I didn't see you come in, stranger.  How long you been sittin' there?" 

"Since breakfast, but I blend in."  My wink let her off the hook.  From then on the service was first rate from all the black & white servers, complete with sides of small talk and Potato Salad. 

The Summer Shandy hit my thirsty spot dead center.  It was difficult not to just gulp it down it felt/tasted so good.  That squirt of lemon in the beer was an elixir. 

My Bison Burger Special came out closer to medium rare, but I was pleased with it, as it was full on juicy and a deep rose color.  The pile of Shaved Onion, Cheese, and BBQ Sauce on Brioche Roll made for an excellent sandwich.  Knife and fork was the only way to go, and allowed me to pay attention to every morsel.  It was quite good.  The scoop of Potato Salad was a cool change from fries.  

If not for the fact that I had a ways to go before the day was over, I might have lingered over a second or third drink, and become friends with the attractive keepers.  I had to face the withering heat regardless of my wish to avoid it.  Luckily, there was an ice cream barn right in the parking lot that was about it receive my dessert business.  More on that in another review.  

The lunch had an epic feel to it due to the surrounding circumstance, but based on the food alone I feel no urgency to visit again.  It was a solid meal, but it would have attained higher rank if the bar folk had been initially more attentive as they busied themselves with prep work for the evening crowd.  The invisibility may have been part of the existential void I felt coming in, but they played their part in extending that sense longer than necessary.  

Still, a worthy stop on the stagecoach line between Easton and Philadelphia.

Pho 75 on Adams Avenue does only one thing, but it does it very well. Beef Pho in all its variations still makes for a fairly limited menu, but on the other hand makes for easy choices.  Round Eye, Tendon, Tripe, etc., are all there in either a regular or large size.  Their bowls are smaller than in other shops, but still big enough to completely fill your belly with very good beef broth, rice noodles, onion and a load of selected cow parts, to which you can add fresh Thai Basil, Sprouts, Jalapeno slices, and Lemon(not lime) Squeeze.  

If Beef Pho is your yen, then you will be quite content here, because the steaming bowls flow quickly from the kitchen, and are very tasty and filling.  Just be sure you are not looking for a full course meal, because that won't happen.  No apps. No com (rice). No Binh Mi. No sweets. No Pho Ga.  They do offer coffee and a few other drinks. 

So, what's the problem? The restaurant has little atmosphere; tables and heavy stackable chairs without the semblance of comfort.  The service is efficient with no effort to interact with the customers beyond perfunctory order taking and fast delivery. The place is a bit worn out and could use some TLC.  Most significantly, it is CASH ONLY, with a little ATM sitting near to the cashier.  For a business with five outlets in the region, that is another indication of lack of concern for the patron. Certainly they have the roots in the community and relationships with financial institutions to be able to offer a credit card option.  

Bottom Line - While the pho is quite good, if restricted in options, the surrounding elements within make Pho 75 a less than desirable destination for my Vietnamese fix.  There are too many nicer, friendlier, more comforting joints, to make this place "go to."

My first time back here since joining Yelp*.

New Plum Tree is a Chinese/Thai restaurant in name, but it is fundamentally Chinese American cuisine with a Thai menu thrown in for good measure.  Neither are really outstanding, but both are competently prepared for the local palate.  I tend toward the Thai side of the street and have tried several dishes from noodle (Pad Thai) through Curries (Like the Green Curry dishes better than the Red).  

Today I stopped in just after 12, which is early for me, but I was coming back from Philly, and decided to sit down rather than pick something up to eat at my office.  I had a veggie plate primarily of Eggplant mixed with Green and Red Pepper, Carrots, Peas, and Basil Leaves.  It had a mildly spicy brown sauce that also suggested some Ginger Root in the mélange.  It was good, and felt to be a healthier alternative without meat.  

What can I say?  It was Okay. I am not rushing back, but neither will I avoid it. 

My fortune: "If it seems fates are against you today, they probably are."  Thanks. I already knew that!

Learn Chinese:" A moment" = Yi hui er.  Yes. Time waits for no one. (Especially, bad fortune cookie makers.)

The outpatient radiology department works well. 
Can't speak to other departments or services, but there is no problem going to St. Mary for xrays, catscans, petscans or MRIs as an outpatient.

Tan May Chinese Restaurant sits in the Shop Rite center just off Pennington Road in Ewing, NJ. While primarily a take out joint, there are six tables for sitting in, and for the owner's kids to hang out on during summer vacation. Nice to see the family together. 
My lunch special was actually better than expected. The egg Foo Young was made with fresh ingredients and the ubiquitous brown sauce lighter and more flavorful than in most chop shops. Even the fried rice, though that prefab yellow cast, was at least tender and full of finely cut veggies. 
Prices were ridiculously low (under $7), and there was a choice of soup, egg roll or bottled drink included. No extra charge for my Snapple. 
While the place could be cleaner, and the mess in the hallway leading to the restroom organized and stored out of sight, the food makes it worthy of regular, if infrequent, visits.

Northern Liberties now has a fair share of interesting and comfortable places to eat, drink and hang out over cups of good coffee.  One of the earliest pioneers that continues to pump out java and decent bakery snacks is Higher Grounds on North 3rd Street.  This converted row house draws a local crowd, as well as longstriders from farther south in Center City, and the occasional visitor from farther afield.  It is attractive in a Salvation Army Store furniture kind of way, with a lot of art, crafts, and a vast variety of tchotchkes to catch your attention.  It is cozy and worn, like an old couch or settee should be.  

The caffeine options are decent, but by comparison to other jumpin' joe joints in the vicinity, not in the vanguard in terms of coffee quality, nor barista excellence. Our sampling of hot chai latte and cappuccino left us feeling like we had tasted better elsewhere recently.  Still, the lemon pound cake was tasty, and the ability to sit back and watch this part of the Universe go by was a pleasant timeout.  Just wish we were holding ceramic rather than paper cups to enhance to quality of the experience. 

There are ever more coffee outlets in the expanding urbansphere, and they all try to outdo each other with service, product, and atmospherics. Higher Grounds has the advantage of being an early provider in this neck of the woods, but also the disadvantage of staking its claim before cafes became more popular and the customers more demanding.  

If it was open to suggestion, a gentle makeover with heavy cleaning, fresh paint, and a competition to select the best available local roasted coffee, would raise the expectations here to better account for the changing java life in Philadelphia.

The old furniture is reminiscent of grandma's house, and should stay.

Enzo's Pizzeria on West Maple Avenue, Langhorne, PA, is in the same strip center as CVS and Hong Kong Cafe. It is a traditional American pizza parlor with full complement of pies, stromboli, steak sandwiches and standard pasta and chicken dinners. There are a half dozen booths in house, so most of their business is takeout. Service is friendly. 

I stopped in to check it out with an early supper. I took a booth toward the back and ordered their Enzo's Eggplant Bonanza sandwich, an amalgam of breaded fried eggplant, sauteed spinach, roasted red peppers, melted sharp provolone and very tasty pesto mayonnaise. 

It arrived on a paper plate is a puddle of oil and thin plastic utensils. Presentation is important, and these guys blew it royally. What would it take to serve a heavy leaky torpedo on something more substantial? That the mess wasn't noticed or they just didn't care shows lack of quality control and disrespect for customers. 

The ironic part is that the sandwich was actually very good. The combination of flavors and textures, and especially the pesto mayonnaise on the crusty loaf and the mix of the eggplant and peppers we're well worth the price of $7.95. 

If they had just thought about a better way of dealing with eat in customers they would have been starred up for creativity in the kitchen. 

2.5 Stars

I am a little confused by this new chicken shack on Race Street in Philly Chinatown. 

Yes. It is cool the way it is an up the stairs second story shop. Its utilitarian set up with basic tables and chairs with little comfort shouts that this is a fast food joint that doesn't invite hanging around, although the wings are prepped as ordered and take 20 minutes to come out of the fryer. I am okay with all that. Yet, although called, "bbq chicken," all lower case, in fact there is no BBQ chicken there. It is all Korean-type double fried chicken wings and cold drinks, bubble teas, smoothies, etc. The wall menu has about 50 drink options, yet just 7 flavor finishes for their wings. Bird choices are wings, boneless wings or chicken sandwich. If I didn't know better, I'd think this was really another over saturated bubble tea house offering wings on the side (By comparison, Vivi around the corner is all about interesting drinks, and offers deep fried wings as a nosh, for a lot less money.).

Go figure.

What about the wings? Well, they were crispy enough, and the soy garlic and secret spicy sauces were pretty good. As others have said, the secret in the spicy was that it was more sweet than hot, although there was some warmth behind the sugar. I liked the soy garlic better, but as I slowed down after the initial rush to dive into them, I began to taste the underlying oil they were cooked in. Not so nice. 

Soho has nothing to worry about from understated lower case 'bbq chicken'. It needs to decide what it really is and let everyone know.

Charming Garden is a typical Chinese American house that offers both Chinese and Sushi in the middle of a just-off-the-highway shopping plaza in Lower Makefield, Pa.  Calling this location Yardley is a marketing ploy, as it is not that riverside borough, but does have more name pizzazz that its actual address.  

Stopped in for lunch after a run to Home Depot last Saturday.  It is a bright, clean room, with efficient service.  The servers keep busy anticipating the needs of customers, while the sushi chef stands and waits for an order. 

My Hot & Sour Soup was good, and seemed freshly made without reliance on MSG.  The Veggie Chow Fun was a nice size plate for lunch.  The assortment of greens was not vast beyond carrots, onion, peas, broccoli and a few baby corns, but the brown sauce covered everything in a decent tasting goo.  The broad noodles held the flavors of everything around them well enough.  My bud asked for extra heat on his dish, but got it bland with a side dish of Szechuan Chili Sauce.  He said it was not as good that way and he preferred when the sauce was cooked with the other ingredients. 

No real reason to return to Charming Garden unless I find myself hungry again when in the vicinity.

Called ahead to pick up a large pie for dinner. Half plain. Half sausage. This was my first visit to Red Star Pizza 3, and my impression was that it was attractive inside, with room to sit for dinner, and had a friendly efficient staff. The pizza was ready when I arrived, and I was back on the road in under five minutes. 

Opening the box in my kitchen, it looked good and had a nice aroma. Pizza is always best eaten straight from the oven, and this one confirmed that axiom. Both slices had the right combo of sauce and cheese, but having cooled for a while, the crust was now weak and could not hold the topside weight. Still, the taste was there. The sausage crumble was strong. 

We had a decent dinner from Red Star, and will get back there to mange in house as soon as possible.

This is a mini-DD that shares the building with another business, yet it has a small outdoor seating area in front of the shop if you really feel like hanging out and smelling the exhaust of the cars parked right next to you. 

The coffee is what most of us expect from this ever expanding franchise.  Average coffee whose main attraction is its basic consistency across the nation.  

Service here is fast and efficient, if not overly friendly nor engaging.  

It is amazing how different each DD "makes the donuts," however, I did not have any here and cannot speak to their taste and quality.

Lambertville Trading Company on Bridge Street, Lambertville, NJ, is right next door to Sneddon's Luncheonette, so it is possible to have breakfast at the former, and a decent java jolt at the latter, and feel good about your exploration of this beautiful river city. 

The shop itself is quite small.  There are a few seats in the window alcoves, and a couple of stools in the rear, but otherwise, this place is mostly takeout. It is all wood and glass displays from floor to ceiling, and it is somewhat captivating in its downright cuteness. It was brewing coffee before there was a Starbucks, and certainly deserves your affection and appreciation for that.  They also do a small bakery product retail to go with the joe. 

Word is that they use Small World Coffee Roasters out of Princeton, but I could not vouch for that as there were plenty of other bags of beans behind the counter with other labels on them. My own decaf latte was a bit harsher than expected and slowly degraded to a bitter aftertaste by the time I reached the office. The chocolate chip cookie I scored for accompaniment was nearly as large as my hand and was nicely crisp.  The $1 Yelp discount upon checking in made it a pretty sweet deal. 

LTC is still the best place in L'ville to buy your coffee for your walkabout. It continues to fit right in with all the other antique shops in town.

This will be a review in several chapters. 

I just started looking for new wheels this weekend.  Three people in my family with new driving permits eager to be part of the great American right of passage. Where is the best place to see all the alternatives and drive a few of them on a private test track?  

Reedman Toll Auto World in Langhorne, Pa. 

They have a series of connected showrooms along Rt. 1, with everything from Chevy, Jaguar, and Ram to Subaru and almost everything in between. We were free to meander around without interference; get in and out of any car there, and generally kick the tires as much as we wanted; all without a single salesperson approaching us to push us toward business.  This atmosphere in the comfort of modern display was surprising and refreshing.  We were around so long that I began to think perhaps they accurately read us as people only at the beginning of their shopping adventure.  

We ended up at the Subaru end of the complex.  We sat for a while in a Outback Limited (very nicely appointed with Walnut inserts in the dash and door), and a Legacy, Sube's "full size" sedan (similar, but felt smallish in the cockpit).  Finally, the sales manager walked over with a casual air and inquired about what we were looking for.  They were busy, and promised someone would get to us soon.  

There was more inventory outside, so we exited and strolled along the two rows of Outbacks of various colors and accessories.  Mostly green and black, some leather/wood; some cloth/metal.  After about ten minutes, a young guy wearing a knit cap and sweatshirt came up to us.  He introduced himself as a "floater," who worked at their Chevy operation and who could sell any car on the lot.  He was relaxed and friendly and offered to get the key needed for a car we liked, so we could test drive it.  That accomplished, he drove us to the back lot where the test track was located.  We circled the quarter mile loop a few times.  Pleasant car to drive. Not exciting, but clearly solid and competent.

Turns out our salesguide was a long term employee of Reedman, but relatively new to sales.  He was a mellow fellow who made our time with him very light and easy.  We got into some more personal talk, and it turned out he was in the middle of a lawsuit, and I was able to answer some questions for him.  By the end of our hour or so together we had developed the beginning of trust in each other. Me, in his basic honesty and willingness to work to find the best deal possible on one or two cars I was interested in; and he, in my willingness to listen to his concerns about litigation anxiety with patience and advice.  

We will have to wait to find out how this story continues. I intend to buy new wheels by the end of the month, and will give this good man the first chance to close a deal.

DECEMBER 11, 2016 - UPDATE : This story ends quicky. Despite the new connection I imagined with our salesperson, I never heard from him again with the workup he promised. 

So be it. As with fish, there are many more cars around to shop, consider, test drive and purchase. It just won't be at Reedman-Toll. 

No hard feelings.

While I wouldn't wager on the last time the Department of Licenses and Inspections walked down the stairs into Asia Supermarket, I might take your bet that we could find a completely esoteric noodle sauce, cookie, or tea previously believed to be extinct anywhere outside of China.  This place seems to have all that stuff, and more. The prices are cheap, the aisles narrow, and the shopping carts from a bygone era.  

Still, if it is something you remember eating back home, or a cooking utensil unavailable in Sears, this is the place you may find it.  Go for that reason, or for the great sense of nostalgia emanating from every shelf and refrigeration unit.  

It is not every day that you can be both a consumer and an anthropologist at the same moment.  The museum-like quality of some of the dark corners makes this a multi-dimensional experience. Stock up on your packaged, canned and bottled goods at good prices as you explore its inner recesses. 

Don't forget to come up for air.

Yummy Sushi has moved to new quarters to be replaced by the literally translated, Fame Dish. At first blush the shop looks exactly the same with blond woods and small sushi bar in back. Staff wears light aquamarine and black. Service is efficient. The menu tips it's hat to Japanese (sushi), Thai (pad thai), and Singapore (noodles), but is operated in Mandarin and is primarily a Chinese house. It remains to be seen whether it can carry out it's multi cultural concept, but if the chef is serious about it, and the market demands it, it is possible. 

My General's Chicken lunch was a mixed bag. The wonton soup was pretty bad. Canned consume with two thick skinned dumplings with little core, nor taste. Disappointing. On the other hand, the chicken was better than expected after the soup. White meat with a very good freshly made sauce that included a fair amount of Chinese red peppers per my request for heat. I asked for brown rice, but got white. Oh, well...

At $12 with tip, it was more expensive than most other chop chop houses in the area, and it should have been more consistent from soup to nuts. Yet, it did show promise and is worth another look to explore other options.

The choice was between Jack & Jill hard ice cream and vanilla/chocolate/orange soft serve. I went with a cup of orange vanilla swirl in styro. While waiting at the window of this renovated former fast food shell, I watched all the families sitting around enjoying a cool moment on a humid sticky evening in June. 

I was more in the mood to drive home and spoon the melting combo in air conditioned comfort. Besides, I prefer drinking this elixer to licking it. I sampled it at red lights along the way. 

Have to admit to being disappointed. The vanilla had little flavor and the orange while tasty, was also grainy like the orange powder had not been mixed enough to reach the smooth silkiness desired for soft serve. 

There are many choices for ice cream in this part of the world, so I hope this was just a glitch in a normally high quality operation.

This Dunkin is located at the intersection of Parkway Avenue and Pennington Road in Trenton, NJ.  It is fairly new and is well maintained.  There is a drive thru option. Plenty of parking if you want to go inside. 

I walked in after lunch to grab an afternoon wakemeup.  The woman behind the counter was friendly and efficient. They had a surprisingly full rack of donut and muffin options for the time of day.  A few customers sat at one of the tables discussing business. Overall, the place was attractive, with everyone doing their job professionally.  

The coffee was what you expect from this franchise.  Consistent. Strong. Not overly acidic. Not particularly flavorful. Fully capable of keeping me awake for my afternoon surge toward the five o'clock world.  

Right down the middle.

Not much here unless you have a seat at one of the four tables on the patio or on the Septa train coming down the tracks. With a beautiful Saturday afternoon bringing out bikers from the nearby trail to rest and recharge, all the seats were occupied, so we could only take our latte and pour over back to the car and keep going. 

No doubt an interesting use of the backroom of the bicycle shop and an attractive old stone building. The lone barista was kept busy and did a good job. Bakery products were almost exhausted. Coffee okay. 

We had a nice drive home through a part of Conshohockon we had not seen before, but Riverbend is not a great place for a coffee stop under these circumstances. 

The Cafe is a takeout shop right now with potential to be a lot more.

Chinese/American Lunch Special Review - 

I didn't expect much reward when I stopped into King China on State Road, Croydon, PA, for lunch after getting new tires for my car a few days ago. Walking in, the shop appeared worn and in need of some TLC. The menu was a trifold handout and photos of their greatest hits high on the wall. I ordered egg foo young, which came with wonton soup and fried rice, for around $7. 

Surprisingly, the meal was pretty good (for Americanized Chinois). The chicken stock was not overly salted, nor did it taste past its prime. The wontons were fairly thick skinned, but the filling was decent. The rice was likewise recently made and still granular without being clumpy and with plenty of veggies and bits of pork. Finally, the egg pancakes were light and loaded with bbq pork, sprouts, carrot and peas. The brown sauce was well made and plainly  prepared just for my order. Although the soup was served in a plastic pint container, the solids arrived on a nice heavy gauge plate. It would have been great had they offered wooden disposable chopsticks, rather than flimsy plastic utensils. 

I enjoyed the lunch despite its expected shortcomings, but moreso for its small unexpected pleasures.

The first review I wrote for this burgerdom disappeared from Yelp a few years ago for reasons unknown. When I stopped in recently with my son, I realized I hadn't replaced it. Out of sight. Out of mind. 

This is the BK closest to Sesame Place in Middletown, Bucks County, PA. As such it draws heavily from family visits, and has attempted to make this operation a showplace. To a certain degree they have succeeded. There are inside/outside play areas for children, ordering stations that let you avoid human contact if you don't want to deal with high school students working their first jobs, and even partial table service where your tray it brought to you by the staff rather than waiting around in the lobby to be called. There is even a cozy fire pit zone that could be considered romantic by some. Mostly good things (except, my first job was in a burger joint and it was a great training experience, that I wish they continue). Given these amenities, you know that they have some good ideas, and makes you wonder why they don't do these tricks everywhere. 

Still, there are some things that don't change. Like the quality of the meal prepared in the kitchen. You still have to deal with thin, too salty burgers, that have little flavor, fries that chill quickly and become dry and lifeless, and sugar loaded drinks that just are not good for you. 

Bottom line - Comfort is a variable they are willing to enhance to impress the visiting public, but food service remains inferior to most of the new fast casual joints sprouting up across the country, with much better sandwiches and shakes for only a few bucks more. 

In the race for a better burger, BK only seems to be falling further behind.

As the name suggests, Peking Tokyo is a new Asian fusion house in the Pine Watson Shopping Center in the heart of downtown Langhorne, PA. In addition to Chinese and Japanese elements, Thai cuisine is given a nod with a few curry and noodle dishes. I was there for lunch, and as everyone working there were speaking Chinese only, I was most interested in that part of the menu. 

I asked for their lunch specials General Tso's Chicken, extra heat, which came with a cup of soup (Wonton), small ginger dressed salad, and fried rice. I also had a mug of green tea (an extra charge, although not disclosed until the bill appeared). 

Everything was okay, but the only thing that stood out was the quality fried rice. It was freshly made with a higher standard grain, veggies and no dye. The soup was beef consomme with thick skinned wontons and decent filling. The chicken was plentiful and encased in a thickish shell. The sauce was tart as requested, with a few Szechuan red peppers in the mix. Particularly tasty when the rice was tossed in. The salad was from their sushi offerings - a first for me for a Chinese lunch and a nice touch, although I am not a fan of that ubiquitous ginger dressing.

Service was fine, and the manager stopped by to check on my satisfaction. The sushi chef stood at his bar in uniform and at the ready. 

Peking Tokyo (Bangkok) is a step ahead of its predecessors in variety and quality from this vantage point, and as a new business it is still on its shakedown cruise. Hope it maintains high standards and is successful. Langhorne Borough certainly deserves that.

Second Street Pike Grill is a nicely laid out dining room with the look of gray marble on walls and table tops. The menu is oriented around fruit smoothies, breakfast and lunch. When I walked in the other day around 8:45 AM, I was the solitary customer and was told to sit anywhere. I did so at a table close to the front window after picking up their bifold menu at the counter. There was a large board on the back wall listing the smoothie possibilities. Not for nothing, I wondered why there were no fruit, nor blenders in sight. Maybe not the best way to market their signature product. 

So, I slid over to their more traditional breakfast options and Made My Own Sandwich of turkey bacon, cheddar and fried eggs on English muffin with side of home fries included. It arrived open faced about ten minutes later. 

It was okay, but could have been better @ $9. The bacon was thick, but lacked crispness. The eggs were fried to near dryness, where a bit of runny would have better integrated the elements. The potatoes were mealy and lacked the firmness of quality chunky morning spuds. On the other hand, the house coffee was very good. 

Service was friendly and informative. Access was fine throughout. 

2 Street Pike Grill - Attractive with good ideas that fall short in execution. A more deft hand at the hot steel would help.

Farnsworth Avenue was all dress up for the Sidewalk Sale going on Friday afternoon.  Looked great! 

I was in the mood to sample the Tomato Pie at Marcello's Restaurant & Tomato Pie, but as it was not offered by the slice, and the small pie was a glaring $16, I decided it would have to wait for another time when the cost was more in line with the occasion. It might be awesome, but it would have to knock my socks off. 

So, I ordered the Eggplant Parm Sandwich with a two buck Side Salad (total cost: $10. plus tip).  It took a while for it to arrive, and I had ample time to look around the barroom where I sat.  Very attractive cross between Colonial and contempo styles.  The room was mostly full with leisurely diners enjoying this mid August afternoon.  The side patio was temporarily closed for construction, but it looked like it would be a nice place for a cooler evening al fresco dinner.  

Maybe next time.  

My meal arrived.  It looked great on the plate with toasted Italian loaf seared to melt and seal the Mozza and thin sliced Eggplant within.  There was more bread than veggie, and the diameter made it necessary to eat with knife and fork.  The Eggplant was well cooked; pleasantly soft and mixed well with the cheese and Tomato Sauce.  It is a matter of personal preference, but I prefer the double sautéed approach to Eggplant and the use of a light coating of spiced bread crumbs to give it more texture and flavor.  This dish was done in a single cooking style, and without the crumbs; thus, somewhat light on taste and interest.  There could have been more sauce as well, perhaps on the side, to provide more oomph. 

Marcello's is a nicely appointed house, with attentive staff, and it clearly aspires to be a higher end Casa Italiana. In this it mostly succeeds.  But, I won't know for sure if it is all that until I take my first bite of its tomato pie.

COFFEE STOP REVIEW:

When the sign on the door of the nearby bagel shop said it was closed permanently, I looked for an alternative source for the caffeine fix I needed to account for my earlier than normal awakening to attend to a court matter in Mt. Holly, NJ. Luckily for me there was a Wawa right down the road. 

It was an old version convenience store, sans gas pumps and large food preparation area. Still, it had 6 types of java and a fixings island. All this boy needed. The Guatemalan medium roast caught my attention, and I poured it into a 16 oz container with a milk lightener to taste. 

I pulled in the first sip as I settled back in my car. Hot, strong and pleasantly robust, it was just what the doctor ordered. Had me humming and beating my fingers on the wheel in minutes. When I walked into the judge's Chambers I was fully equipped to handle whatever my adversary threw my way.

New China House down on Haines Road, Levittown, PA, is the successor to Zhang's, the mildly popular dine in/take out joint. The transfer of ownership took place three years ago, but this news wasn't shared with Yelp for some reason. Too bad, because it turns out that despite the divey appearance the Chinese American food is better than average. The place deserves some recognition. 

The House is family run with wife up front and hubs in apron beating the wok. Strictly take out, I was told I could not eat my lunch on the one table on the floor. Okay, I'll leave. I can stand the rejection, but if you had permitted me a few minutes to eat, you would have heard me compliment your rendition of General Tso's Chicken as not being too breaded, with decent sauce, and appreciation for throwing in a few Szechuan peppers for the extra heat I requested. 

Too, you would have heard me say that the wonton soup tasted fresh and that the wontons were fairly thin skinned and filled with decent ground beef/pork. Finally, that the pork fried rice had a natural color and good texture full of peas, carrots, onions and sprouts. Overall, a satisfactory lunch at a very reasonable price.

Just wish I had been there to let them know. Guess this review will have to do.

I have never seen a larger breakfast menu than at Cracker Barrel. It is all very traditional and Southern, with huge portions of everything. Prices reasonable, too. Yet, this is not the place to go if you want to avoid temptation to over indulge on very fattening dishes.  Simply unavoidable here.  Even the "healthy" oatmeal is loaded with sweet fruity things that sound good for you, but really are not. Too much sugar and processing with everything you eat. 

However, if you feel like chowing down with country fried steak, biscuits and gravy, fat bacon, sausage ground from various animals, and lots of eggs, there are few places that can fulfill your fantasies like Cracker Barrel.  That, and a cute-to-death country store up front that is Americana gone to seed.  Where to look first?! 

I was here for a business breakfast suggested by the other guy.  I was curious, because Cracker Barrel was new to me.  I've seen them around, but always thought it was more a gift shop than a restaurant. I was wrong. It is really both. I tried to order a simple breakfast sandwich on a biscuit, but was advised that was not on the menu because their biscuits were too small. Instead, I could have it on thick sourdough-like white bread, complete with eggs and cheese, but not with the meat on the bread.  It had to be a separate plated side.  Okay. Whatever. Do it your way. Surprise me. 

What arrived was a large plate with oversized toasted bread, two fried eggs (medium hard), and a large dose of melty yellow Colby.  Two medium sized pork sausage patties were on a separate dish. I had to cut and assemble each forkful bite.  I didn't mind, but it was hard to believe the kitchen could not do this so that the pieces had time to meld together.  It was all decent and tasty.  The homefries mound which they brag about was also okay, but perhaps a bit to mashed and not as chunky as preferred. 

The coffee was average, and flowed freely.  

Can't say that I fell in love with Cracker Barrel, but I understood how that would be possible for people who like big breakfasts loaded with meat, eggs, cheese and/or pancake mix.  For me, it was just overload.

COFFEE STOP REVIEW:

Driving south on Route 130 (perhaps the ugliest road in New Jersey) on the way to court in Camden, I knew I needed a caffeine boost to compensate for my early start to the day. Up ahead I spied the golden arches on my side of the road and pulled in. 

They had double drive thru lanes which seemed to be moving slowly for the cars in front of mine. When I reached the order kiosk I realized that the order taker was taking his time, repeating the order and asking if he had it right. Nothing wrong with that. I requested a small coffee with milk. 

He asked me if I wanted to buy the milk to put in the coffee. What?! Apparently, this store only offered complimentary mini-moos for java, but milk was a luxury extra charge item. This surprised and annoyed me, and I wondered whether this dude had it right. Would McDonald's be that dumb as to refuse to open a house bottle of milk for such orders, or was this an untrained part timer gone rogue? My decision; two creamers, please. I wasn't going to pay for this bizarre policy. 

Anyway, the coffee was a fine generic blend, hot and strong. It did its job, and I went about the rest of my day.

Kumo Asian Bistro is in reality a Chinese sushi joint in one of the many shopping centers along Bethlehem Pike in North Wales, Pa.  As such, they offer a nice facility with broad menu that is primarily rolls and cold fish, with minimum dishes from China and Thailand. Everything is decent, but nothing stands out as exceptional, requiring return visits, unless you are from the area.  It is very much a variation of the sushi theme, without high artistry. Still, service was fine, and I had no real quarrel with what we ate. 

Meeting friends we were able to order extra dishes and sample everything placed before us. We ordered several apps, and two rolls (sorry, didn't catch the names).  We began with their "Sushi Pizza," a good tasting, if poorly named, mix that reminded of its Italian namesake only in its shape.  It was just as much "taco."  Crisp tortilla-like base with a pleasant load topside. Fun and enjoyable.  Their calamari was tempura style, which was not as good as the original in that it lacked good texture, and once cooled, returned to a too-chewy amorphousness.  The beef negiyaki was more interesting as a semi-spicy veggie combo wrapped in beef.  In truth, would not get either of those again. The two rolls ordered by our friends were fine offerings, one topped with eel. 

This experience was more about our conversation than our meal, so the food was comparatively less important than what we were talking about. Still, the room and the platters were a good backdrop for us. We had room, space and time to relax and enjoy the moment. We never felt rushed, and our server engaged with us when appropriate. 

Prices were reasonable given everything involved.  There are no doubt better sushi houses around, but this one was right for the occasion.

Two Slices & a Drink Review

The first thing you notice when approaching Mannino's Pizza is the pollution coming from the tobacco shop next door.  Heavy cigar smoke hangs in the air, making it an unpleasant challenge to go inside.  Public officials should not permit such uses near food establishments as is a negative and so unhealthy. 

But, after getting inside, this Italian house is fairly typical of the genre.  Booths up front. Kitchen counter in the rear.  Dining room to one side.  Clean and pleasant.  I ordered a slice of Tomato Pie and another Regular with a soft drink.  The pizzaman behind the counter was friendly and understood with a nod when I asked for the reheat to be "well done."  

That is what I received.  The slices were placed on a large plate (so much nicer than using paper), and were steaming nicely as I carried them to my table.  A peak at the undercarriage showed nice scorch marks from the oven, and the aroma of tomato, garlic and basil wafted pleasantly in my face.  The Tomato Pie was very good.  The crust held firm when picked up, and released a loud crunch when bitten.  In addition to the above ingredients, the sauce was mildly sweet, which I prefer.  A nice slice from beginning to end.  The Regular Slice was not quite as athletic.  Its point wilted when lifted from the crusty rim due to an excess of cheese that was too heavy for the underside to endure.  Folding the slice was a help, but it also provided a crease for the extra oil to run off onto the plate.  The sauce was okay, but overwhelmed by the cheese.  I prefer more balance between the two topsides.  

Still, I was satisfied, if not ecstatic with my evening snack.  The place is comfortable and the staff is friendly and capable.  

Just wish the dudes next door had better ventilation that didn't leave a cloud of Perdomo exhaust where non-smokers must inhale.

Take out only Chinese American shop on Lincoln Highway (Rt. 1), Levittown, PA. All the usual suspects, including General Tso's Chicken, my choice. The place needs a thorough cleaning, especially around the floor to near ceiling stack of soda cases around the cooler. 

My combo included a heavy load of fried rice dyed dark brown from the bouillion in which it was cooked,  and a smallish egg roll that while crisp was 95% cabbage. The actual chicken was pretty good with the extra heat from a few Szechuan chilies I requested. The portion was impressive. I couldn't finish all that was stuffed into the plastic container. 

Overall, if the main course is what matters most, 21 Chinese Kitchen did chicken well, with  respectable sauce. The rest of the meal was mostly empty filler, not worth consuming. If you figure out how to get just what you want without the other stuff, a satisfying meal is within your grasp.

What for decades had been a dilapidated ramshackle old corner at Langhorne-Yardley Road and Stony Hill Road has been nicely renovated into a small commercial complex with Edgewood Café anchoring the intersection.  The architect and builder did a very good job.  The property is now very attractive. 

The Café feels both old and new.  Narrow plank wood floor and exposed beam high ceiling provide a light airiness, while the dark tones of the booths offer a sense of colonial times.  I sat at the counter with several other guys and had a nice overview of the operation.  The breakfast menu is two pages with an adequate variety of options and flexibility.  My wait person suggested that the fancy egg dishes were very good, but I opted for a full stack of French Toast and a mug of coffee.  A note said the toast could be made, "crunchy," so I asked about that.  Breading with crushed Captain Krunch. Maybe next time. 

My breakfast arrived a few minutes later on a large oval plate, dusted with powdered sugar, and a small dish of butter on the side.  The syrup was brought up from under the counter, and had a thick pour.  Not maple, but decent.  The menu describes the dish as a "Texas" slice of bread.  Not sure as I did not measure it, but perhaps the extra width required more time in the egg bowl to assure full saturation, as the middle was slightly dry.  Not a serious shortcoming and easily corrected. My coffee mug was refilled thrice, and it was a good commercial blend from a Bunn drip. 

One piece of advice I would offer is that the servers smile more.  They are helpful and efficient, but they put off a vibe that they are not comfortable in their jobs.  Perhaps, they are naturally shy young women, but learning to act like a wait person will improve their job approval, and tips. That is something management can talk to them about, and tell them to act more relaxed and try to have some fun while being professional. 

PS. A sign at the back door/main entrance would be a big help for newcomers, as it is not obvious where the café is, nor how to enter from the parking lot.
