Service is young, friendly and accommodating. The order taker was kind enough to point out that as I was there before 2, their $5 and $6 lunch specials were still in play. Cheeseburger, fries, soft drink and small sundae for a fin was good deal, so I went for it, except I knew I couldn't handle the dessert, so he gave me a coupon for a free one instead. Much appreciated. He even permitted me to swap the carbonated beverage for a small blizzard without upcharge. 

The package was okay when delivered to my booth, but not really inspiring. Fries were hot and crisp. The bun was not grilled, nor heated and could have used something to improve its plain white bread texture and taste. The 3 oz. burger was decent with onion, lettuce and tomato topping. The shake was a shallow imitation of the thick, rich and creamy 'Zzard of my childhood. Too watery. Not much flavor. A disappointment. Maybe something was missed in the downsizing for lunch. The whipped cream on top was more dominant that the mix beneath. 

So, while I might return, I would skip the cheap deal and go for their full bore burgers and blizzards to see if those were true to the DQ Brazier creed.

 Life is too short for boring burgers.

The Langhorne Hotel has anchored the corner of Maple and Bellevue for a couple of centuries.  The world around it may have changed, but this establishment has not, except for a few architectural modifications to accommodate the uses to which it was being put.  

This is both good and not so. Walking into the tavern area throws you into the Eighteenth Century, where the local Sons of Liberty gathered to plot the Revolution. Downside, the beer selection is from the same era.  The dining area is also dated to about 1890.  The menu is solid for a 1960's kitchen.  Everything is well prepared and tasty, but if you want something in the way of vegetarian, vegan, or even contemporary cuisine, it will be hard to find. The burgers, traditional Italian, and usual suspects are present.  As long as that is what you want, you will be satisfied.  

Today I tried the Italian Sausage with Peppers and Onions in red sauce over Linguini for a lunch special. At $7.99 the price was right.  I enjoyed the meal, but there was nothing memorable about it. We turned lunch into a work meeting and remained for  more than an hour after we finished eating. The room was practically deserted on a August Friday afternoon.  We were not rushed, and the room was comfortable, if somewhat brown in tone. 

A new menu, broader beer options, fresh coat of paint and new carpets would go a long way to bring the Langhorne Hotel a new clientele. But, if they did that, the Sons of Liberty in the tavern might go elsewhere to plot our way to independence. 

Maybe we are wise to leave well enough alone.

As chain Italian restaurants go, Macaroni Grill is a step above Olive Garden when it comes to atmosphere, and about equal in terms of food taste and quality.  It isn't bad, but just can't compare with the local mom and pop kitchens anywhere in eastern Pennsylvania, that give you cuisine right from momma's oven.  

I like the Tuscany-esque high ceiling and heavy timber, as well as the open kitchen.  Service was excellent from "Big Sean." He was on top of all our needs.  

My lunch special Chicken Parm Sandwich was pretty good, with fresh bird and enjoyable variation of an Italian loaf.  The chicken tasted deep fried rather than pan fried, but the sauce was okay and there was the right proportion of mozza/sauce.  My partner's Italian Pulled Pork was more unusual, but had a mildly sweet taste, and a lot of greens on top as a substitute for the American cole slaw.  I had never heard of BBQ on an Italian menu, and this was no doubt an attempt to capture more diners looking for something not strictly from the Boot.  

The price for these lunches @ $7, was very good, and allowed us to eat a full and tasty meal at a reasonable price, rather than jumping to the dinner options.  

Bottom Line - Not a bad choice for a road stop if you don't know the local haunts with genuine home cooking.

The Newtown Farmer's Market is not really a farmers' market at all.  It is a space where various food vendors sell their homemade (or not) products from Thursday thru Saturday.  The overall gestalt is Amish, but many of the retailers are local people selling non-Pa. Dutch things.  Go if you like fresh food options in meat, produce, dairy, bread, and Middle Eastern/Mediterranean food,  or Amish-style pickled stuff, sushi, fresh fish, or my favorite BBQ'd everything.  There is a small eating area if you love to snack or have a noisy meal, but otherwise take out is the name of the game. 

The prices are more or LESS competitive with local grocers, but the freshness is what they score with. Also, the Pa Dutch folks who are there, provide a quaintness that makes the exploration a pleasant experience.  

Overall, whether you like it or not depends on your expectations.  Don't think: Reading Terminal, because it is not even close to that in scope.  Think: small time alternative to megamarkets with some local color and fresh food.  With a little creativity and space, it could be so much more. 

If you have the time and enjoy this kind of thing, the Trenton Farmers' Market is much larger and more diverse.  Worth a hungry visit.

The Korean double fried chicken wings were excellent with their Secret Spice Sauce. Crisp, hot spicy and a little sweet. Made from scratch upon ordering so it took 20 minutes for them to be prepared. Next time I'll call ahead to save time. Great to have these near best of breed wings so close at hand, rather than having to travel to another county to get a fix.

Yet, that "Homemade Hamburger" needs to be reconsidered and hopefully reinvented. It was awful. The ground beef was a poor quality with pieces of fat and other nasties that fell apart upon biting into the sandwich. The slice of red onion was tough and bitter. Their signature burger sauce was okay, but really added nothing positive to the taste. A Sriracha mayo would have been a better option, or something like Russian dressing. The potato wedges were quite good, but it would take alot of convincing to get me to try that thing again. 

So, it was the best of times and the worst of times at CHKN & BBQ. Stick with what you do well and move away from what you don't if you want to succeed.

B-Uno's still has its, "Grand Opening" sign up on the window, and it seems it has not been discovered on this out of the way corner of Jacksonville Road, just off Rt. 130 North, in Burlington, NJ.  It is really a Latino Casa that does breakfast and lunch.  The menu is on a large blackboard on the wall.  The gist is mostly burgers named after the automotive universe, with burritos a strong option.  

I was there for a late breakfast around 10:30 am, and went with a Sausage, Egg & Cheese Sandwich on a Kaiser Roll.  At $6 for the sandwich with a small side of Tator Tots and a large Coffee, I thought the price proposition to be very attractive.  I sat at one of the 4 small tables along the front window, facing the wall menu, with the counter to my left and the short order grill just on the other side.  

Standing up to look for the coffee (it was being fresh brewed for me in the back of the kitchen), I observed the cook putting my meal together.  Link sausage was being deep fried before slicing and grilling and lay the groundwork on the base of the roll.  I didn't need the extra oil from using that approach to preparation, but it did not affect the taste.  The same was true for the Tator Tots.  Deep fried and crunchy.  The eggs were fresh and folded flat on the hot steel before being slipped into place on top of the meat.  The cheese went on last and helped seal the fresh roll top to the contents of the creation.  

All in all, a pretty good sandwich, and better cup of brewed java.  

Next time, I will ask for one of their well-named burgers, as that seems to be their sweet spot.  

These guys should make it.  They are friendly and play good music with a strong nod to Carlos Santana. 

Oye Como Va!

Pat's King of Steaks reminds of the fable, The Emperor's New Clothes. 
After picking up my California friend at 30th Street Station, we wove our way down to  South 9th Street for a taste of Philadelphia - the renowned, Pat's.  My 12 year old son came along when he heard we would go for cheesesteaks.  

The environment around Pat's is terrific.  People all over the place.  The queue to order.  The Rules for Ordering.  The smack in the puss aroma of burning grease and onions.  The whole migila.  I felt my own excitement rise the closer I came to the ordering window.  I felt the vicarious thrill as my son ordered his first Cheesesteak Witout and Provolone, and a Birch Beer.  Truly, a right of passage. 

Yet, when we sat down at a red metal grate table and began to devour our sandwiches, I noted my son's displeasure with the amount of fat and gristle he had to  spit out.  I, too, was surprised to find red meat in my tumultuous pile of steak, onions, mushrooms and cheese.  Uncooked.  It felt careless. I did not mind that each time I picked up the load to have a bite, and equal amount fell out the back end of the 'wich. That was to be expected from an unfortunate roll incapable of holding its load.  Still, I did not feel like picking up the canned shrooms  and steak pieces to eat them.  

5 Stars for the institution and historic icon that is Pat's King of Steaks. 
2 Stars for the actual product generated from this amazing operation.  

3 Stars for the King who needs to look in the mirror and realize he may be wearing only his reputation.

Walking over to Viet Tofu to check out their Banh Mi and Spicy Tofu, I found the storefront empty. 

The sign on the front door said they were temporarily closed for renovations and would reopen soon. 

I'll try again in a few months.

I seem to remember this prefab diner being delivered and installed a few years ago.  Nice job making new look retro. It is not as big as I was expecting, but well maintained and definitely creates its own unique carnival-like atmospherics.  

Stopped in for breakfast recently and took a seat at the counter.  Big breakfast menu, and a cup of coffee were placed in front of me before I had a chance to squirm to a comfortable position on the spinner.  Impressive attentiveness.  The servers wore smiles and were warmly engaging.  

I opted for a breakfast sandwich on a Kaiser roll.  I thought that was all I would get for the reasonable price.  However, my waitperson then asked if I wanted Home Fries or Fresh Fruit with it.  Potatoes or fruit on top of what was already a big bite.  Thinking quickly for that time of day, I suppressed my surprise and inquired if it was possible to have half of each.  I wanted to sample more.  She nodded in appreciation.  

Now, most Sausage, Egg and Cheese 'wiches come with a single sausage patty, one fried egg, and a slice or two of American cheese.  Not this baby.  It came with two patties, one egg, and a load of melted cheese that had to be three or four slices.  The Home Fries took up a third of the large plate, and the Fruit Cup was a nice mix of Cantelope, Watermelon, Pineapple, Grapes, Blackberries and Strawberries.  

Needless to say, this was more than a single meal, and much more than I wanted to consume early in the morning, so I tasted a bit of everything, but could not finish anything.  I had a momentary qualm about the over the top quantity of food, the obesity epidemic in the US, and starvation elsewhere.  It felt excessive and indulgent.  

While everything tasted good, if I return I will make a conscious effort to ask them to give me less.

If I had to guess, I would think that Chalfont Family Restaurant/Diner had changed hands somewhere in the not too distant past, and been taken over by Spanish speaking owners who were trying hard to duplicate traditional American cuisine, but not quite there yet. Nothing wrong with that, and I wish them success. 

I found the large dining room clean, but somewhat dreary in worn yellow and brown tones. The menu hadn't been modernized in some time. Only one server handled the several parties there for breakfast, keeping him extremely busy and unable to check up on everyone often enough to keep coffee mugs full and timely remove old plates. He kept his smile and aplomb, but always running to catch up. 

My County Style Omelet (onion, green pepper, potato mixed inside the egg shell), was ample, but a tad too dried out from over cooking. Too, I splashed on Tabasco to liven up the flavor when black pepper wasn't enough. It would have been so much better had a choice of cheese been part of the deal, rather than a steep upcharge. A little feta would have been a great place to start. Coffee was industrial; Rye Toast, standard. 

Overall, it was an acceptable breakfast, but could have been a contender with more attention to detail, and perhaps another set of hands in the kitchen.

Lunch Review

Bamboo Kitchen (Why do I want to say, "Bamboo Curtain?"), Sits in the space of the former Peng Yuan Chinese house. New owners. New look. Very similar menu. 

I went down Buck Road to the Pleasant Valley Center to pick up my order for General Tso Chicken from their lunch list. It came with choice of rice (fried), but without soup or egg roll. Although I hadn't asked for it in advance, they were happy to add a Hot & Sour Soup for another $1. 

Good decision.

Turned out that the soup was very good and the best part of the meal.  It had fresh mushrooms, lots of sprouts and tofu, and  strong tart vinegar base. Liked it alot. 

The rest was pretty much forgettable. The chicken was okay, but somewhat dried out, and the sauce sweet, but not the least bit spicy. The rice was dyed yellow from the bouillon it was cooked in, but did have a fair share of veggies and small pieces of pork. Given the quality of the soup compared to the rest, it would seem that lunch is a loss leader for them, priced too low to justify a really satisfying meal.

The dinner menu is likely better.

Old Navy in Fairless Hills, Pa., is an accurate representation of the bottom rung of the Gap Empire.  Not quite the quality of Gap stores.  Not quite the attractiveness of the consumer experience.  Yet, certainly not the price range, either.  So, if you generally like Gap's line of clothing, but prefer it at steep discounts to the going price upstream, then Old Navy will float your boat. 

Of course, there is a price to pay for shopping in an outlet world where the products are made to be inferior to those of the mothership.  More shlock.  More returns.  More unkempt piles of clothing that don't get put back on the right shelves or racks by the understaffed, overworked employees.  

Patience and a keen eye will uncover a few gems worth finding, and the rotating discounts that perpetually run through the store make each visit potentially rewarding.  There is always a line waiting to use the dressing rooms, and a longer queue for the cashiers.  It is all part of the gestalt imbued in Old Navy.  

If you like TJ Maxx, Ross or Marshall's, you probably already know that Old Navy sails the same seas.  Some days I can enjoy the lost hour spent in this rummage sale. Other days, my mood resists.  

Take Old Navy for what it is worth, and for how much coin you can save, if not how much time you may waste.

Asian Chopsticks is now just a takeout joint dispensing primarily Chinese American fare to the masses in lower Bucks County. There are two tables in the house, but they don't turn the heat on in the shop on cold days, so the message of inhospitality is evident. The staff behind the plexiglass are bundled up, too. So order, wait, pay and go, is the true order of business.

I only go with basics at a new place for me like this. After all, I might get lucky and have hit on a kitchen that can really cook despite the apparent slovenliness of the operation, but in all likelihood this is a poor to middling' wok room that is in it to survive and save enough dough to maybe launch a second store somewhere. So, I ordered roast pork egg foo young and wonton soup to size up the potential. 

The soup was about average with a few more wontons than expected, and the three pancakes were also in the middle of the pack, although the brown sauce was better than most (just made, not lumpy and decent flavor). 
Service through the glass was cordial but remote, with no effort at interaction. 

Bottom line - You could do worse that Asian Chopsticks, but unless you are otherwise in the area, it doesn't pay to go out of your way to buy your Chinese victuals here. There are far better choices not very far away.

Happy China is the third in a series of Asian takeout at this location in Levittown, PA. The previous tenants lasted as long as their leases and succumbed to the poor location at the ass end of a run down strip, it's nearly invisible from the main roads and a tiny floor space that had little room for dining in. 

Still, this iteration has a chance, if they maintain reasonable standards of taste and cleanliness and do a little advertising. I found the interaction with the woman owner to be pleasant. She took my phone order of Crispy Orange Chicken (extra spicy, with fried rice and Wonton Soup) graciously and had it ready moments after my arrival as discussed. 

Here's my rundown of the this lunch special -

Crispy Orange Chicken had a pretty good sauce, and the cut chicken was plentiful, as was the rice. Problem was that the crispiness was gone by the time I opened the plastic container because both were mixed together, rather than keeping bird and sauce separate until consumed at final destination. Too, but for this premature exposure, the chicken could have been left dry with a little ventilation to allow excess moisture to escape as the food cooled. Still a tasty dish, but could have been so much better without the soggies. 

Wonton Soup was less redeeming. The wontons were thick skinned and filled with mystery meat. The beef stock in which they swam was aging rapidly and lacked much to applaud. It was hot, so I'll give it that. 

Fried Rice was the largest part of the combo. It was okay, with enough pork and veggies to warrant some merit, but I left most of it behind as unwanted starch. 

There was nothing unusual about the meal, although the price was inexpensive. Happy China falls into the overall Average range of Chinese American takeout. It would be hard to find much better in similar joints, and much easier to find worse.

COVID-19 TAKEOUT REVIEW

Out on York Road just before it enters Montgomery County from Bucks, sits Rey Azteca (King of the Aztecs), a decent Casa Mexicana located in what looks to have been formerly a Pizza Hut. Adequate parking and nicely remodeled interior with those colorful carved chair backs and murals depicting the bright life made famous in all the pastel paintings sold on the streets of almost every small villa in Mexico.  Looking for a place to pick up a good meal, I picked this one because of strong reviews and relative proximity. 

Bottom line - It lost something in-between house and store, as many carry-outs do. Sitting in aluminum containers and covered to keep in all the moisture, it was no longer as fresh and crisp as they would have been if eaten right there. 

The Steak Fajitas were plentiful, but overcooked and too chewy when eaten at our kitchen table. Far too well-done and dried out. The side salad, guac and crema tasted good, but couldn't revive what was already deceased. Luckily, the Los Coco's Special (two beef/chicken quesadillas with red rice) was much better, especially with salsa roja generously applied over top. Very satisfied. 

Neither dish came with the promised side tortillas. 

The Chip & Salsa was a hefty bag of corn crunchies and fresh tomato, jalapeno, cilantro in a large plastic bowl. They were a strong compliment. 

No doubt this meal would have been better if we had spoken with a server about how to finish the steak (medium), and done without the grillman scorch them to well done. It's hard to get it right when the only dialogue is over the phone, and all you see is a packed up brown paper sack with your name on it upon arrival. The dining room, though closed, looked inviting.

It's convenient to have a local parcel place to take care of shipping issues. 

The shop is big for its purpose, and seems a bit sparsely inventoried.  When I worked for a big firm, our mail room looked more stacked and ready to wage a mailing barrage around the world. Still, everything here is computerized. Give them your phone number to find your account (or make one), and give them a name and city where you want to send your package, and in a second they have all the known names/addresses there, and you select the right one.  

Small world and getting smaller by the minute. 

The only real downside is the expense of using their services.  I just spend $70 to send a very small package to California overnight.  Makes me think I should set up an account directly with FedEx or UPS. 

 This charge felt like I had just been held up on the stage coach from Bisbee to Tombstone. These robbers didn't even bother to wear masks.  But, I sure felt someone's hand in my pocket.

Massimo's Café sits at the point where Hamilton Ave. and Liberty Street merge in Hamilton Township.  Sitting in this primo location, Massimo's is a solid Italian lunch and dinner restaurant where you can sit down, fill up, and depart sated on a fairly small budget.  The food is what you would expect from one of the better Italian-influenced cities - Trenton, which sits a few blocks away.  The facility was recently renovated and the inside is attractive is a basic sort of way.  This is not a tablecloth joint, but the tables and chairs are spread sufficiently, and the atmosphere is casual. Nonna sits by the register most days, and adds to the Mange mentality here. 

My lunch this week with a friend consisted of Eggplant Parm sandwich, fries, and ice tea.  My lunch mate had the Chicken Parm variant.  The torpedo rolls were fresh and crusty, made crunchy by a turn in the oven before serving.  The Eggplant was plentiful and tasty.  The gravy slightly sweet, which I prefer.  We were both happy with our choices.  The fries were...fries.

Service was good, but I did feel sorry for our wait person who had to cover the floor by herself with more than 8 tables occupied. Still, she provided service with a smile. Tipped her well for her effort. 

When in the area I would certainly consider dinner here, but until I do and have a few more things on the menu, Massimo's gets Three Stars with a bullet.

Ray's Deli Café is a throw back kind of place. 

It sits at the bottom of High Street where it butts into Mill Street in Mount Holly, NJ.  Ray is the chief cook and bottle washer, and his better half runs the front of the house.  She is a stitch, with a load of funnies to crack, followed by a horse (hoarse) laugh that is infectious.  

The house itself feels rather dark, with a small counter toward the back where I settled in earlier this week for breakfast.  Perhaps more lighting would dispel the sense that the back area needs a thorough cleaning. Still, the coffee was strong and plentiful, and the French Toast available as a Short Stack, which was all I wanted.  Ray came out to the grill to prepare the meal.  The dish was decent, if a little "eggy," around the edges. My compliment to the chef was met with a smile before he retreated back to his enclave.  

Ray's is a place with some old world charm, but a bit disheveled.  The prices are in line with the atmosphere, so there is definitely a deal to be made on an inexpensive meal.  Still, Mt. Holly is a happening place this century, and there are more than a few better stops for a memorable morning meal. 

I would return, but not anytime soon.

Broad Street Diner (formerly Manetas) is aptly named for the street where it is located. Of course, there are other diners on Broad Street, so don't be confused.

This place has been well renovated to match its new moniker, and although smaller than the better known places like Mastoris and Town and County a few miles away, it is still comfortable, although the tables are fairly close together. 

I was there for a late lunch last week, and the floor was mostly empty.  I was greeted with a smile by a waitress and the cashier, and led to a deuce in the side dining room. A second waitress brought me a menu and informed me where to look for specials. She promptly brought water and lemon, and returned again moments later to take my order of Greek Turkey Burger on Pita.  The platter came out with the grilled pita on the bottom of the plate, and the burger on top of it. It was up to me to make it a sandwich, which I opted not to do.  There was a small plastic cup of fresh feta cheese, and tachini sauce in another, so I could use what I wanted. Lettuce and Jersey Tomato sat on the edge of the plate.  At first, I was a little put off that the finished product was not constructed in the kitchen, but as I got into my own preparation I began to appreciate leaving the raw materials for me to combine.  That way I had it just the way I wanted it. There were also a side of fries, but aside from being hot and crisp, I don't recall the taste two days later. 

My server was very friendly and efficient, and obviously well trained.  She appeared to offer more water or ask if I needed anything, and I knew she really meant it, as opposed to the monotone I often get when the job is just routine.  I tipped her well for her pleasant professionalism. 

The meal was good. Everything fresh, quality ingredients.  While I would not rush back for another meal, I certainly will remember I enjoyed my lunch and not hesitate to return to the Broad Street Diner when in the area.

January 4, 2016 - Stopped in for a late night dessert, coffee and conversation.  All three played their part well in making an enjoyable evening.  The Rice Pudding was excellent.

Originals Pizza sits to the side of the Giant Shopping Center on West Trenton Avenue in Morrisville, Pa.  It is in a small commercial strip next to a Wells Fargo office and a Dominos Pizza.  It has been here for a long time and has settled into its space nicely.  Although long and narrow, the furnishings create the sense of sitting on picnic tables under a striped awning along the outside walls of the building.  Nice, if gitchy, touch. 

The moustachioed men behind the counter look like brothers, but they assured me they were not.  They were both friendly and ready to serve.  As I came in after 7 pm on a midweek evening, the pizza offerings were not vast for a guy in need of only a slice.  That is always the risk taken late in the day of any pizza shop.  You never know how long the pies on display have been waiting for your attention.  Their "Tomato Pie" seemed to have the most energy as it sat there, so I asked for it to be reheated to "well done" for me.  

It was that.  When it arrived I could see that the heavy tomato pasty topping had been reawakened.  Picking it up gingerly, it held its point well with only the slightest quiver from the weight above.  The scorch marks on the chassis were well established from the oven.  That is what I wanted.  First bite revealed a thicker than expected crust that resisted my clenching incisors just enough to let me know it would not yield its secrets willingly.  Solid chew.  

The slice was more than enough for an evening snack.  Two slices would have been way too much.  The top sauce was thicker and saltier than I prefer, and the few chunks of garlic not enough to demand serious attention.  I overheard the chef say to a customer that this was "Brooklyn Style" Tomato Pie.  Not sure what he meant, as it surely wasn't the T.Pie created and made famous across the Delaware in Jersey.  There, the mozza goes on before the sauce, and the tomato mix is applied more sparingly to achieve balance in texture and taste between the two main food groups.  Originals had little or no cheese that I could discern, but just the overpowering sauce.  

It was okay for what it was, but not close to what I was accustomed to in a Tomato Pie.

When a hotel/bed & breakfast/restaurant has been around as long as The Brick, it gets some cred from its history and deep roots in the community.  While George Washington may not have slept here, he certainly ate here - and that is amazing. Through the centuries The Brick has seen its share of historic moments, as well as its share of scandal.  It has prospered and suffered at the hands of various owners, some of whom took great pride in the establishment, while others did not.  

It went through such a change a few years ago, and the trail of reviews shows this plainly.  Through it all, the first floor bar and dining areas have retained their charm and well accented colonial airs.  For that alone, The Brick is worthy of Fandom.  The cuisine may not always keep pace with the aura of the old stone, brick and wood.  

Today, I attended a special function for a community group honoring (and roasting) some of the more ancient sportspeople in town.  For the first time in the long history of the organization, the silver cup was engraved with the name of a woman.  Very happy to be part of the moment.  Buffet dinner was served before the award ceremony.  It was spread out in the bar room; a perfect setting.  Spring Mix Salad, Chicken Piccata, Penne Vodka, Roasted Potatoes sat waiting for our walk through.  The salad dressing was a pale yellow cheesy creamy Italian and the croutons from a box.  The Chicken was slightly above room temperature with the lemony gravy semi-solid on top.  The Roasted Potatoes somewhere between well done and dry.  The pasta was good, but also not hot enough.  It wasn't that the ingredients were lacking, but that the preparation and presentation were not quite right. 

If not for the great camaraderie in a grand old room, the food would have been a near fail.  We were not there for the food, so to some extent I can overlook the issues.  I was happy to be there today, and it was very cool to be part of this small piece of history being made.  

Go for the atmosphere, and perhaps a drink.  Go for a brunch when you can sit on the glassed-in porch and view downtown Newtown. Don't go for more, or risk disappointment.

Upon approaching the front door of Wrightstown Country Store there is a large sign advertising their Homemade Chicken Salad and recommending their Bacon Hoagie. Sad for me, they were out of the former, and I would never consider the later, when I arrived shortly after 1:00 on Wednesday afternoon.  Still, there were other choices.

I asked the women behind the counter in the rear of the store what was the best thing they made and was told that aside from the Chicken Salad and Breakfast Sandwiches, the Cheesesteak was high on the list.  They were cordial and chatty, so I ordered a Chicken Cheesesteak with Sautéed Onions and Mushrooms while I continued to question them about the Store and menu.  One lady retreated to the back room where the grill was located to made my lunch, and the other told me that her father had worked there 40 years ago, and she was creating a family tradition. Cool. 

While waiting I took a stroll around the small shop that had been standing on this site for at least 80 years.  The front half shelves were mostly empty, except for an ATM machine and small groupings of soft drinks.  The rest of the space was sparsely inventories with cookies, chips, snacks and other lunch accessories.  It was all rather Spartan. The refrigeration unit had the best provisions with the meats and cheeses for lunch making. While I normally enjoy the historical/cultural ethos that permeates an old commercial building that has withstood the passage of time, I found myself in a more somber mood within this building.  I don't know what it was but I felt a pall that made the air feel heavy and brooding.  Perhaps, it was just my low blood sugar crying out for something to eat.  On reflection, I think that somehow the depression era around 1930 was trapped inside the building. 

Only take out here, so I went back to my office to eat at my desk.  The Chicken Cheesesteak was presented in white wrapping paper only.  It was still warm, but no longer hot when I sat down 10 minutes later.  The Chicken, Onions and Mushrooms had been chopped and mixed well.  The roll was fresh, but had a soft exterior without any appreciable crustiness.  The overall taste was decent, but not really satisfying.  It was a bit too salty.  Given the nearby alternatives, I would not get it again.  

Wrightstown Country Store has seen better days.  If walls could talk, they would certainly have tales to tell about life in these parts in the first half of the 20th Century, when Route 413 was still only Route 113.  But, the story for the second decade of the 21st Century is that the walls need a fresh coat of paint, and more imagination in the kitchen if it is going to attract business and continue to operate prosperously. 

I will return soon for a breakfast sandwich and provide an update.  I want to see if the vibe is more upbeat in the morning. 

Stay tuned.

Paige H. from Morrisville has it right.  This place is a mixed bag (of bagels). 
When Bagel Junction in Newtown closed its doors unexpectedly a few months ago I was heartsick.  My favorite bagel joint for many years was gone. What was I going to do?
I checked on Google and Yelp for a substitute for my addiction.  I tried several places in the area before going to Bagel Train. Their bagels are almost as good as Bagel Junction, and I found they satisfied my craving better than the others. 
Many of us are bagel experts, and I consider myself one, being raised in New York, and having strong opinions about such important things. 
So, this is now my local bagel place.  But, there is a reason for only 3 stars.  The bagels are 4 star (everything is relative), but the interaction with the owner is stiff and unwelcoming (1.5 stars).
 The coffee is so-so.  The help is very good, and compensate in part for their boss's personality, and the lack of physical comfort as I stand in a long line waiting my turn.  Even that has its benefits, as there are many nice people to talk with.
Cash or check only.

Saw the movie, About Time, last night.

This isn't a movie review site, but if you are looking for theaters it does not hurt to get an idea about what is playing. 

This was a feel good movie with enough suspension of disbelief required to last for weeks.  If you enjoy time travel (who doesn't like going back in time), then this one is for you.  It is light, funny, and endearingly idiosyncratic.  Yes, it leaves many questions unanswered, but that is not the point of romantic comedies.  

The acting is believable, and the London and Cornwall locales attractive.  

Looking for something to do next Sunday night, check this one out if you want a movie that leaves you with a smile, rather than a grimace.  If you want dinner with that, do what we did and go to Misto Diner for an above average Chinese meal first.

I don't quite get the Bubble Tea craze, but I did stop in to this one tonight to pick up something warm and stimulating for the drive north. 

I took out a Bubble Green Tea, and discovered from the friendlies that the shop was under new ownership and had changed its name to, "Tea Chat."

The joint was a narrow corner store, but clean and inviting.  The prices for the various teas and smoothies were quite reasonable at between $3 and $5.  

Good luck to the new enterprise.  May your Boba always snap when you chew them!

American menu with a Mexican twist, B-Unos sits where an old mom and pop luncheonette once filled the belly and entertained the troops in downtown Mt. Holly, NJ. They've done a nice redo of the place, with new furniture, walls and floors. The original six spinner lunch counter still sits in back for those who prefer taking a load off in the 60s, before returning to the teen years of the twenty first. 

The menu offers BYO omelets, quesadillas and loaded french toast in equal measure, but it pays to keep it simple because each additional item has an upcharge that quickly runs over $10 for even a basic sounding plate. Clever, but not exactly consumer friendly. I chose the naked Frenchie with three slices of thick white bread, melted butter and table syrup. 

It looked great with all the caramelized edges, but was a bit dry as the profile showed the egg mix had barely penetrated the wider bread and the middle remained uninvolved in the cooking process. It wasn't all bad, but could have been so much more. The java was hot and strong, as was the service by the young woman who also worked as the cashier and busser. 

Maybe staying south of the Rio Grande is the way to happiness at B-Unos.

Most Applebee's, like almost any national restaurant chain, are interchangeable. Eaten in one, eaten in them all. That reliability is a good thing if the basic experience is positive anywhere in the Applebee's Universe. While not a favorite, I find that when it comes to dining with family, this name can normally be counted on to deliver a reasonably good quality/value proposition, that satisfies the greatest number for a decent price. 

To be precise, my sons like their BBQ ribs, burgers and sides, while we adults can nicely make due with house salads as well as the beef offerings. 

Usually.

But, not the other night. 

For some reason, things started going sideways as soon as we sat down. First, my plastic water glass sprang a leak and left a pond on the table before we could catch anyone's attention for a towel. Then, when we did, a towel seemed beyond their ability to produce, and they brought a pile of napkins instead. Lacking much absorbency, they were quickly soaked to the max, leaving a large pile of sopping paper and smaller puddles on the table. At least the water was no longer spilling onto our laps, but the wet naps remained on our table through ordering and food delivery, untiI I asked for them to be removed. 

My son enjoyed the ribs/chicken breast platter. Devoured all of it. My Whiskey Bacon burger was okay, but beyond the medium finish requested by a few time zones, and crumbly. Not their best effort. 

Perhaps it was the exception that proves the rule, but this Applebee's night was all wet. 

2.5 Stars

A business lunch brought 7 of us to Miller's late last week. 
The house looks a lot better in daylight. Plenty of room, and large windows that open wide on beautiful days to give the feel of eating out on the spring porch. 
Small choice of draft beers, but enough to keep most people happy. Service was fine, especially the fact that they have some extra large booths that fit all of us comfortably. 
Most of us chose from the salad menu, but there was a burger in the group, too. 
When served, although 5 different names, they all looked basically the same with each having been accessorized slightly differently. It was funny, and they were okay, but not particularly memorable. We talked more than we ate, so it didn't make much difference. 
If we end up working a project together it will be all worthwhile.

Jake's Eatery on Cambridge Lane replaces several Indian Restaurants that occupied this tiny strip mall about a quarter mile west of Sycamore Street in Newtown.  
I have had lunch there several times, often choosing to sit at the bar rather than wait for a table. As I am usually eating alone, the stool is a good option, however, there always seems to be some confusion in the staff as to who will provide service to me. 
Everyone is friendly, but as with many wait people, they avoid eye contact as much as possible and thus are not always attentive to their customers.  This happens repeatedly at Jake's, and thus the time until my order is taken, served, and the bill arrives, adds unnecessarily to the time in-house.  
The food is all decent to good.  Most is fresh and tasty.  I enjoy their burgers, which are simple and can be customized to taste (sauteed onions, mushrooms, and jalapeno chilies, please).  The fish sandwich is also good. 
The place is clean and bright, and always has a nice crowd.  Many business meals, and post-workout meet ups.  
I do miss the Chicken Tikka Masala and Garlic Naan, but it has not turned up on the menu yet.

It is hard to get too excited about a multiplex cinema unless the IMAX seats vibrate and massage me during the show.  Otherwise, "seen one ya seen 'em all." 

While IMAX is an improvement over the standard movie experience, I find the 3-D versions of movies to offer little beyond the regular mode.  After a few minutes my mind adjusts to the distorted perception that things are flying at me, and I forget that I am supposed to be having a different reaction.  Too, the cockamamie glasses are always dirty, requiring me to clean them, or suffer through  smudgy vision.  Just not worth the extra couple of bucks for me. 

Otherwise, Neshaminy AMC has comfortable seats and convenient drink holders, which is a plus, but aside from the old Newtown Theater, almost all movie houses have similar conveniences.  

Parking is fairly good, but a short walk is needed, and the snack bar is loaded with everything a movie goer generally wants, unless something healthy is what they seek.

While Aya Kitchen in the Oxford Valley Mall broadens the selection of food available in their somewhat bereft food court, it has had to make concessions to the reality of the market at the cost of faithfulness to its identity as a "Mediterranean" fast food dispensary.  Can't blame them for offering Afghani dishes (Kofta), Indian options (Samosas, Tikkas) and Central American snacks (Empanadas), in addition to the expected gyros and falafels in pita, but to say they fit into the geographic culture of the Mediterranean is inaccurate. 

Still, even lacking the grill and spit for real lamb/beef gyro preparation, they do a decent job with what they have.  My lamb gyro in pita was overflowing with meat, tomato, onion, cucumber, yogurt and tahini sauce inside their somewhat thick skinned pita. It wasn't wrapped properly inside the aluminum foil, and was impossible to eat handheld once the paper and foil were opened enough to permit a big bite, thus making the use of a fork mandatory. The lamb was in small chunks rather than being carved in slivers from the mother as it slowly spun vertically on a grill. I found it tasty and filling despite missing the traditional cooking method.

No one will mistake Aya Kitchen for the real deal in Mediterranean dining, but it wasn't bad overall for a mall food court. I would easily chose it again if I found myself hungry and alone in Oxford Valley Mall.

Victoria's Bagel Bistro is really more of a tie dye T-shirt, hippie dippy kind of place out on Rt. 38 in Mt. Laurel, NJ.  The place has a nice sized room with about a dozen tables, Rock & Roll Classic Hits for sound, and photos/sketches of Presley, Marley and a few other music heavyweights on the walls.  Definitely, a chill place.  

Victoria, herself, served me.  Very friendly and accommodating owner that puts herself into the environment she created.  She gave me the two bit tour of what was available for breakfast, and I opted for an Onion Bagel with a smear of Butter and a few slices of Swiss, not toasted. I took a seat at the table nearest the front window, and settled down to check in on Yelp.  

The bagel arrived looking quite good.  There weren't a lot of toasted onion flakes on the surface, but enough to hold the flavor.  In profile, the transection was a nice layering of bread and cheese.  First bite announced that the surface of the bagel was not crisp, nor crunchy, but rather more like the regular crust of a bread loaf.  I really prefer a more distinct outer texture with a softer airy middle.  So, while the taste was decent, it was not an optimal bagel for me. We all have our own opinions about bagels, and this must be what the strong enthusiasts here like most.  For me, is was really only Okay.  

Still, the java was hot and strong, the price very competitive, and the overall experience, positive.  I liked what Victoria was doing there. 

And, wish her continued success.

Stewart's is part of the small food court in Neshaminy Mall, Bensalem, PA. What it can't duplicate due to lack of being a stand alone drive up roadside dog, burger and root beer joint, it tries to make up for with friendly service and a menu straight from 1975. 

A hot dog lover, when the mood strikes and there aren't many local frankfurter havens nearby, even this neutered version of the iconic Stewart's Root Beer emporium, will do. Although there are a few better dog shops around (Cheese Dogs on Bustleton being an excellent alternative). I ordered their special with fries and black cherry beverage and a skinny beefer buried under chili, relish, onions, mustard and ketchup. It came in a plain white bread bun that had a hard time holding up under the damp weight of all the condiments.  Lucky I grabbed a handful of napkins. 

It was okay, but the doggie was lost in all the flavors above. The texture came through, but not much of the taste. The fries were decent because freshly made, and the carbonated drink stronger in flavor than the original root beer. 

Stewart's would do well to investigate the competition, especially the more creative houses like Tower Dogs and Destination Dogs, that produce a far superior product and gastronomic experience. They should up their game to capture a more discerning crowd, while holding on to their simpler pleasures as well.

 Why not appeal to everyone?

This International House of Pancakes on Mt. Holly Road, Burlington, NJ, sits in a renovated former fast food structure, and is small compared to the more recent versions of this franchise around the country. All the cues are there to prepare you for a hearty breakfast. 

I walked in before court last week for a light bite and coffee, and to kill some time before my workday began. I took a seat at the 5 stool counter and was served by Tim, a young dude who seemed diligent and engaging. After a short look at the long menu, I opted for their traditional french toast and strong java. All the other choices seemed like they would be way too sweet with berries and whipped cream. Didn't want those calories. 

My plate arrived ten minutes later looking attractive and tempting. I spread the cup of butter across the egg pocked surface, and poured on the old fashioned syrup (maple not on the counter).  First bite was very good, but a realized that their signature approach to this dish was to add pancake mix to the beaten eggs.  This was visible in the unusual shine on the surface of the toast, as well as the distinct mild taste of buttermilk with each forkful. I had not tasted this before, but I enjoyed this take on a historic platter.  Nice for a change of pace, but not something I would specifically request, as I prefer the traditional approach to french toast. 

The carafe of hot coffee in front of me is another thing they do well. They realize that coffee is an inexpensive way to appear generous. 

I have never been a IHOP regular, as I normally prefer a mom and pop shop to a chain or franchise for breakfast, or any meal. Still, I appreciate what they do, and their effort to find a new approach to their business. They even are doing burgers now. Haven't tried them, but they do look good on the menu.

The Bowl inspired Grill (sic) is a relatively new entry in the luncheon wars in beautiful downtown Trenton, NJ. It is located on South Warren Street, the cobblestoned lane that manages to look good despite all the degradation around it. It is an Americanized Mexi house that does it's best to imitate Chipotle, with bowls, burritos or wraps made to order as you select the rice, beans, meat, salsa and drink of choice being constructed behind the counter. All this for around ten bucks.

We walked down last week. The room was empty, but for one table when we arrived at 1:00. The two women working the assembly line were friendly and knew their craft. I ordered a bowl with brown rice, red beans, shredded beef, corn salsa and cilantro. It felt hefty on the plastic tray. 

The result was tasty and filling, but far from special. Then again, I don't frequent Chipotle for the same reason. I prefer the authentic version of Central American cuisine so prevalent and delicious around this capital city. Yet, for a downtown foodery it certainly carries it's weight and contributes some variety to the lunch scene in these parts.

Las Margaritas on 2nd Street Pike, Southampton, PA, isn't bad for a casa Mexicana that serves mainly an American audience not necessarily familiar with the deep choices available in a kitchen that caters to its own nationals. The space is large and dimly lit, with plenty of colorful cues of its South of the Border cultural heritage. It is very popular as witnessed by the long wait for people walking in looking for a table. Luckily, as a solo diner, I was able to grab a barstool and take my liquid and solid choices right there.

I have been somewhat spoiled by the wide variety and authenticity of all the casas Latinas in and around Trenton, which has become a very ciudad Centro Americano. All those formerly Italian corner restaurants now speak Espanol, and they put out amazing cuisine. 

Still, Las Margaritas is a good place for a reasonably priced cocktail by the same name, and the well known dishes found in most Mexican houses catering to gringos. Lots to choose from in terms of nachos, tacos, burritos, chimis, and tortas, and even a few decent dinner platters, like the chili rellenos ordered by me.  I found the two large breaded and fried poblano peppers to be nicely loaded with melted cheese and queso fresco, and topped with a thin, but well spiced, ranchero sauce. I tossed on the salsa from the chips to add texture and heat, and enjoyed the refried beans and dirty rice accompaniments. 

Not a bad meal at all. Bartender service was fine and muy amable. The only hiccup was being tendered the wrong cuenta for a couple of bucks more than what I ordered. El hombre tried to tell me it was the same price as what I got, but I knew that was not the case. Still, it wasn't worth a challenge to his manhood, so I let it roll, and adjusted the tip accordingly. 

Honesty is always the best policy when it comes to restaurant tabs.

It seems that Café con Leche has been in Newtown forever.  It is a place I used to go to with some frequency, but over the years it fell off my radar as a "go to" place for good Latin/Italian styled cuisine.  When a friend recommended it for lunch I jumped at the chance to revisit an old friend. 

Daniel Lucci is the owner/chef in this walkout basement of a restaurant on the Newtown Creek side of State Street.  It is best approached from the parking lot next to Isaac Newtown's, where it must compete for parking.  It is accurate to describe the dining area as small and dark, but for some that adds to the ambiance and charm.  The menu seemed smaller than I remembered it, but it still had Mexican, Italian, and Continental flourishes.  

Lunch was from the Sandwiches Menu.  All are prepared on French Bread with a side salad.  The bread is fresh with a moderately crunchy crusty ingratiating bite, and my accompanying salad was potato with celery and a mayo-mustard creamy connector.  The Yellow Fin Tuna Salad was good, layered with lettuce and tomato slices.  It was satisfying and filling.  The Cajun Salmon was nicely blackened with a Pesto Mayo dressing and side garden salad with Daniel's special Balsamic Vinegrette, he calls, "Balsamico." I tasted this and thought it was better than the tuna.  

I could not escape the thought that perhaps, Café con Leche had remained too long in the same space, and thus cramped its growth in both tables and adventurous gourmet meals.  A little more sunshine might open this accomplished chef to brand new and exciting possibilities.  In some way it seemed that the rest of the local restaurant world had caught up to CCL, and even passed it by.

The anti-Starbucks. In sight of its backdoor. Pour your own and no waiting. Decent coffee and snacks. Inferior view, but no seating required.
I'm not saying 7/11 is a true alternative to the Green Mermaid, but if you strip away the atmospherics and even the pretension, and the antisocial, illegal, parking in front so some can get their daily grind going without the trouble of finding a safe place to stash their wheels, what you are left with are taste and price.  On both counts, the Lucky Numbers win - with parking to spare.

I returned this morning for a breakfast sandwich after the mild disappointment from the Chicken Cheesesteak of the other day. To be honest, had this meal been at the same level as lunch, I would have lowered the ranking down to 2 Stars. 

But, it wasn't the same.  The Sausage, Egg and Cheese sandwich was a totally different animal.  It was loaded and it exploded.  Where the run of the mill sandwich has one sausage patty, this one had two.  When most put in a single sunny side up egg on top, WCS cooked up two flat omelet style huevos and wrapped the sausage within it.  Most will not cut the sandwich before packing it up to go, but these folks cut the Kaiser Roll before enclosing it in white paper with a heavy tape sealer.  The only weak link was the roll, which was fresh, but lifeless.  

The first bite released the mix of meat and cheese flavors strongly.  The textures worked well, especially the double patty which required more chewing, and thus more release of the undertones.  It was an imperfect pleasure to eat. 

I would certainly go back to the Store to pick up breakfast on occasion. If we were just talking about breakfast sandwiches, 4 Stars might be attainable, but given the condition of the facility and the sadness it evokes, and the less than satisfactory lunch sandwich, 3 Stars is where the ranking belongs.  

Breakfast saved the bacon.

There are more reviews for this PennDot Licensing Center to be found on a separate page labeled, PennDot.  

Not sure why two pages are needed, but perhaps it adds to the chances of being found here.  

The Commonwealth is really making an effort to make these places more consumer friendly.  I was able to renew my driver's license in less than ten minutes.  However, their interworking with other agencies remains problematic.  When Social Security and Homeland Security are required to be involved in securing a new license, the process is awkward, delayed, and guaranteed to frustrate. 

Can't blame the Governor for the issues raised by the Feds, but there ought to be an easier way.

Newtown Book & Record Exchange has a prime location on State Street, Newtown, right next door to Starbucks.  If this isn't a gold mine just based on overflow from the S.$$$, I don't know what is.  

First impressions walking through the front door is one of narrow aisles and stacks of used books and Cd's (also some tapes, etc), with hand written labels to direct you and creaky wooden floors that have been tread on for more than a century.  Yes, there is also a dustiness and slight scent of decaying paper, as would be expected where thousands of old books are stored.  It all adds to the overall gestalt of entering a literary and musical time warp.  It is quite enjoyable if you like this sort of thing.  I do.

Likely due to the rent paid for this location, the prices on the books and music are higher than seems reasonable, and the trade in policy is not designed to provide value to the trader.  Over the years, I have purchased a few things here on impulse, but overall aside from wanting the old place to survive, the selection is generally not what I am looking for, and the cost offsets the cultural and historic imperatives. 

Definitely worth a long browse while sipping caffeine from next door, but if you have visited the Princeton Record Exchange you know what a dedicated used music emporium is all about.  This one is not that.  As to the books, you might find something you like, but if you don't, the Newtown Library Company is about 2 blocks away.  You can join and likely find what you seek and be able to return it after reading. Recycling at its earliest and best.

While down in this neck of the woods we decided to check out this Home Depot's garden department to pick up a few more bags of mulch. It is basically the same layout as every other HAD, with their planting inventory primarily outside, and the soil, fertilizer and mulch stacked high in the adjacent parking lot. 

I went over to the cashier to pay for what we wanted, and picked up a tray of petunas on sale nearby. Receipt in hand I went back to the wagon and drove it over to the mulch. The dude with the weight lifting vest met me there and helped load the bags in back. At $3 per bag, it was the regular price. (Note: It is on sale now for $2.)

The home garden is looking good with this dress up. Will go back this afternoon for another load at the discount price. Maybe look at more annual color on the borders. 

I'm still not a HD lover, but do admit that they are hard to beat on many things.

Although this pizza shop calls itself, "The Original Dominick's," there is nothing of the that organization here beyond the name. The only Dom's these days are in Richboro and Washington Crossing, Pa. The family sold off the other locations several years ago, allowing the buyers to keep the name. 

The space has seen better days when it was a convenience store, "Mr. Milk." Yes. I used to live on Riverside Drive on the Delaware and this was my local shop. Still, it is a survivor, and puts out decent pies at reasonable prices, as long as you are willing to overlook the worn out feel of a now run down store.  

I am about the pizza and can ignore almost anything when in the presence of good T Pie. Pizza is at its apex right from the oven (even when reheated), so I prefer to mange right at its peak, and damn the torpedoes. We took a table and settled in.

The slices were served on the metal pans used for personal size pies. Nice touch that helps keep them warm,. Much better than the paper plates used by so many joints. I did not mind going to the high counter to retrieve them. 

Although I seldom order a "fancy" slice, she asked for a chicken parm wedge. It came loaded with chunks of clucker, sauce and cheese. The chassis held the heavy topside with minimal assistance. My sample bite was okay. She devoured it. Mine were sausage and traditional Trenton tomato pie. They had a firm thin crunchy crust that held up well. Not too oily. The gravy was a little salty, but nice and thick with clumps of Tomato on top of the mozza on the TP. They used sliced sausage rather than free form which exuded less flavor than preferred. 

They weren't perfect, nor even exceptional, but still pretty good. Clearly, they were given the recipes by Dominick, but had taken some creative liberties over the years.

A little elbow grease and TLC could bring this pizza parlor up a notch.

Fireside Smokehouse is the current incarnation of this old tavern down on Elmwood Avenue in Trevose, Pa. It has been run by one family since 1978, and they certainly know what they are doing adapting to changing tastes and fads to remain a solid choice for a hearty meal and a load of suds options. 

First impressions are that Fireside has three personalities - a front room dive bar full of locals enjoying the broad beer list and a few eating something meaty from the grill; a simple dining room with a dozen tables, and outside patio enclosed in canvas and plastic for cold weather, with a few picnic tables and service bar. The front bar was the most crowded  and with the most attitude.

Our server told us to sit anywhere and came back to us quickly for drink orders. Menus were already on every table.  Two pages of beer options took a few, but we settled on Limbo IPA and Weyerbacher Imperial Pumpkin Ale drafts. Cool and smooth going down. 

Son opted for a pulled pork sandwich with chips. He liked it, but has had better flavor. Too, there was no sauce on the table for added moisture and taste. The grilled salmon was a small steak, but fresh and nicely done. The spinach and slaw sides were forgettable.  My chicken & rib combo put a heavy plate with 6 ribs and quarter bird before me. They were both covered with the house BBQ sauce, a deep amber red.  The meat easily pulled from the bone and tasted of a good rub, long smoke and twangy sauce. Really liked it, and they were so loaded that I ate three, gave two away and brought one home along with the untouched clucker. The baked beanz were great and the mashed would have been too with a spoon of gravy or sauce on top. 

Fireside is a solid choice for basic BBQ in a down home environment.  It's nothing fancy, just serious meat overload and strong fermentation possibilities. Put a few table rockets of Memphis, St.Louis, Carolina,  along with the house slather in front of me, bring the ribs out dry for me to doctor the way I want, polish up the sides a bit, and this smokehouse would be seeing stars.

Two Slices and a Drink Review

Stopped into Peppi's Pizza & Pasta after shopping at the Giant Supermarket in the same Shoppes at Flowers Mill commercial center.  Narrow in front, with dining room in back, this is a typical pizza parlor with booths, and a vast array of pies for examination, temptation and ordering.  I asked that my two regulars be "well done," in order to reawaken the taste slumbering within after extended time under hot lamps and hungry eyes.  

The slices were as requested and picking each aloft showed the crust to be firm and able to supports its load.  The tomato sauce was on the salty side, as was the mozza.  Would have preferred a sweeter bite. Still, that's just a matter of taste, and many people like it that way. 

Service was friendly and prompt, and the free refill of the soft drink, a nice touch. 

Certainly worthy of a pizza snack when out and about.

We originally came to Kohl's to visit their Lee's Jeans collection. It was on the first floor in the back with large signs on the walls. Yet, it was frustrating to explore because of disorganization and a complete absence of smaller sizes. With Levis mixed in and Black Friday hordes making it impossible to maintain any order to the displays, we soon tired of the effort. 

On our way out we did find a nice leather jacket sitting in a small group on a rack with outerwear sweaters. There was only one in the right size, and the price was very good with all the discounts applied.  We went for it, but quickly discovered that the queue to the cashiers wound through the store like a hungry giant Python. 

Man! I dislike this insanity. But, there I was knee deep in this Big Muddy. I rode it out, and the line actually moved quickly with the help of a few workers who directed people to the next available register. All in all, we survived, but I will leave this shopping mania to those with a more accepting constitution. 

Couldn't do a thing with the jeans, but the leather jacket was a nice consolation prize.

When I arrived around 2 for a late lunch there was one other table occupied and conducting business over lunch.  They left about 30 minutes later, and I was the only patron there. I don't know what it is like when crowded, but on a quiet late April afternoon it was quite peaceful, especially sitting in what seems to have been a porch, now enclosed.  Plenty of windows and the sunlight was pleasantly warming.  

The overall impression is that it feels small inside, perhaps because of the dark wood and cut up design.  The bar has 9 or 10 stools on two levels, and the rest of the barroom seconds as the main dining area.  It feels somewhat rustic.  

I ordered the Patty Melt, and it was quite good.  It was tasty and the combination of Sautéed Onions, Cheese, and Thousand Island Dressing had carmelized into a dark brown oozy sauce that was unusual and enjoyable.  This was a knife and fork job as my attempt to bite into it resulted in a Newtonian Principle being demonstrated - the equal and opposite reaction, as the backend began jetting out.  The rest of the menu seemed to offer plenty of comfort food that would be worth a try.  

I remember when this was the Wycombe Inn back in the day.  It had a feel of faded elegance and charm that seems missing now.  Publick House is more of a frontier space, a bit rough and ready.  I will have to see it full of people to overcome the sense that it has seen better days.

As circumstances would have it, a single visit to a nearby Home Depot in West Windsor, NJ, has become a series of trips to three (possibly four) of their warehouse distribution stores in and around Mercer and Bucks Counties, NJ and PA.  I picked up a bag of black mulch while buying sand last week just to see how it would look in the flowerbeds and under trees.  At $3 per large 50 pound bag, it was worth the investment.  Turned out that the quality and coverage was very good, so I went to the location nearest where we were having dinner the other night, and purchased six more bags.  

Can't have enough of a good thing, so I stopped in to the HD on Oxford Valley Road in Langhorne, PA, last night to haul away eight more sacks of the black moist blanket to spread this weekend.  What is obvious is that I'm not the only one getting this stuff, because the pile of bags in their nursery was depleted when I arrived last night.  Plenty of brown and red available, but the black was almost exhausted.  Too, I realized that if I am to attempt all my garden beds, I am going to need a lot more mulch!  The fifteen already stacked around my beds will likely double or triple before I am done. 

So, while checking out, I inquired of the gardening lady cashier whether more would be brought out.  She assured me they had many more pallets where that came from, which would be moved into place before the store opened today.  Further, taking pity on my dirty work in lifting, stacking, hand trucking and car loading while in my suit, she informed me that they had people around who could do all that for me, and all I had to do was drive up and open the back gate of the wagon.  

Nice to know I won't have to include a dry cleaning bill in the expense of freshening up my garden. Too late for these slacks, but I can deal with that.

PS. I'm now at 25 bags and no where near done. Luckily, they started a sale @ $2 per bag! I'm going to need a bigger truck!

This US Post Office in Morrisville, PA is about par for the course for an aging government facility. Parking in front. PO boxes to the right and services to the left upon entry. Queue of patrons longer than it should be at 1:30 in the afternoon, but only one guy working the counter until another co-worker got off lunch, an no postmaster in sight to address the service shortage. 

Still, when my turn, the dude was friendly and attentive. He helped me out with the request for commemorative stamps for the office mail. Even made suggestions to be sure I saw everything. All the stamps were the forever variety; a big plus. Purple Heart, military service metals, team sport balls and Janis Joplin peaked my fancy. Janis?! Somebody in the institution really appreciates rock history. Thinking of framing those.

The place needs better lighting and a way to bring help to bear when it is busy, yet no major complaints given I was in and out in under 10 minutes.

It is hard to believe that prior to 1926 there were no bridges across the Delaware River south of Trenton, NJ. Despite the growing American love affair with the automobile, the only way to get across that body of water anywhere near Philadelphia was to swim or take one of the two ferries that operated from bank to bank at Camden and Burlington. There wasn't a car ferry until 1922, when a private business started a service that was wildly successful, but not nearly capable of meeting the growing demand. 

So, the same entrepreneurs seeing the success of the new Benjamin Franklin Bridge just to the south that opened in 1926 as the longest suspension bridge in the world, organized their consortium to construct a span between Palmyra, NJ and the Tacony river ward in Philadelphia. Eighteen months and $4 million later, they had their toll bridge open for business. Rudolph Modjeski, the designer of the Ben Franklin and Manhattan Bridge in New York, did the work. 

The first year the average volume was 3,500 cars per day. These days it is over 70,000. The original $.35 toll has gone up to match inflation and is now four bucks. Keeping things local, the steel components were fabricated by the American Bridge Company of Trenton, NJ, an offshoot of the older Roebling Steel Works, where the Brooklyn Bridge was cast. 

This isn't a particularly efficient bridge these days, as it remains a drawbridge that raises up to allow ships to pass beneath, causing traffic to stop for 20 minutes with each opening. Too, the access on the Philly side it a problem as it has not been redesigned in nearly 100 years, except for modest improvement recently. Of course, it still is useful if your reliance on the trolley service hasn't changed since your great grandparents used them. 

Otherwise, better to plan for the nearby Betsy Ross or Ben Franklin, both of which are easier to use than the venerable but outdated TPB.

I'm not sure what to make of the fact that there were no Indians in the kitchen of Cross Culture Indian Restaurant in Buckingham, PA. The menu was more limited than many I've seen, and the dishes themselves while decent, lacked some of the dynamism I associate with quality curry and other colorfully spiced South Asian cuisine.

We ordered their Veggie Samosa and Tomato Soup appetizers, Chicken Cashmere, Veggie Navaratan Korma as entrees and Garlic Naan for sopping up the anticipated creamy reductions. They were a mixed bag. 

The Tomato Soup was disappointingly bland, and we decided to bring it all home to doctor it to a better place. The Samosas had a good crunchy shell, but the potato/pea contents was dry with little tongue tickle. The Cashmere was the best of the bunch - pleasantly creamy sauce sweetened by the cashew and raisins and tender dark chicken. The Korma was also quite good, but the sauce was too similar to the Cashmere and needed a bit more curry heat to make it distinguishable from its sibling. Where was the tumeric and chili? Finally, the Naan was hot and oily as it should be, and quickly gone as we enjoyed spooning up the sauces as our dessert. 

Service was warm and efficient by one of the owners. She seemed to appreciate our presence in the days before restaurants were closed to protect from the COVID-19 crisis. We all suspected that moment to arrive soon, so in some ways we expected and acknowledged that this might well be our last meal out for the foreseeable future. Just wish the entire meal was as memorable as the societal moment we all were enduring. 

Be safe everyone.

I have a love/hate relationship with Wawa. It applies more or less equally to all of them, but especially the super hyper Wawas that are currently being developed on the East Coast. 

I certainly see the value buying their gasoline which is always a few cents cheaper than the regular gas stations in the area. Yet, I hesitate to buy it because I don't know who refines it for them, and thus can't trust its quality and ingredients. Too, I will sometimes stop in for coffee or a hoagie, but know that by doing so I am helping weaken the older mom and pop shops that rely on passing drivers for their survival. So, I usually feel conflicted visiting these 21st Century phenomena and avoid them more often than not.

It's not about whether they present a real monetary value to customers, nor offer the convenience of being able to fill up both your tank and stomach in the same place. Obviously, there are benefits in time and money being able to do so. But, do we want this to become normative behavior if the cost is really enforced conformity, universal standardization of our diets, and the end of all the variety that existed earlier in our cultural evolution? 

I have concerns about this piece of progress, and wonder (perhaps, too often outloud) whether we would be better off if we spent more time doing little things like buying gas or eating lunch. Ultimately, I have no problem if I end up at a charging station to power my vehicle rather than slaving to the internal combustion engine, because that's good for the environment. But, on actions where convenience and not ecology is as stake, I vote for a little less time saving, and much more consideration of the existential quality of our lives. 

It may not be fair to make Wawa the symbol of that degradation, rather than just another symptom of something bigger, but I came to that realization naturally, and it seems to capture my internal conflict as well as anything else. 

Feel free to ignore these rantings of a peaceful lunatic, but sometimes you just have to ask the questions.

Decent enough bagel and friendly service, but it is somewhat amazing that there is so much disparity between one Manhattan Bagel shop and another; this one on Bustleton Avenue in the Russian part of Northeast Philly landing on the lower end of the spectrum. 

Crust not as firm/crisp as others nearby, and far fewer roasted onion flakes attached. Still, more than adequate veggie cream cheese coverage within to help offset the shortcomings. 

Their coffee is strong and holds its own for a breakfast blend. Been sipping it for several hours and it hasn't turned bitter. 

Will certainly do until a real bakery shows up and turns out a Real McCoy bagel, that knows how to bathe well before baking.

Nino's Trattoria & Pizzeria sits just off the Brunswick Circle in Trenton, NJ.  It is easy to see how it is a pizzeria, but it does not look nor feel like a trattoria. Rather, there is a long narrow area to the left of the restaurant with the ovens and prep zone, and a larger dining room to the left as you enter.  There are a dozen or so tables and booths in this typical Italian shop.  It would look a lot nicer if the chairs had been taken down off the tables during business hours. It felt like they weren't quite ready for prime time. 

However, my lunch was of considerably higher quality than the atmosphere.  My eggplant parm sandwich was made of thin sliced nightshade, dipped in breadcrumbs, and pan fried in olive oil before being placed in a submarine roll, topped with red sauce and slices of mozza cheese and thrown in the oven to melt the cheese and toast the bread.  The coating was thin enough to allow the flavor of the veggie to come through loud and clear.  Not too much gravy nor cheese to obscure the main ingredient, but enough to enhance it.  

My companion went with penne with their house red gravy, in a child size portion. Just right for lunch.  I sampled the pencil points and found their sauce to be very good.  It had lots of minced garlic, salt, pepper and a touch of basil; creating a lightly chunky tasty crushed tomato texture and rich taste.  Although I usually eat the eggplant without the roll, I found myself sopping up the delicious mash with pieces of the hoagie roll, it was so good. When I asked for the second half of the sandwich to be packed up for home, the server put in two extra small containers of the sauce, because she had seen me going after it with gusto at the table. Gratitude! 

Nino's has some strong kitchen skills with their pasta and baked specialties. Can't speak to their pizza.  A little attention to the impression created in their customers would allow them to make the dining room more presentable, and create the sense of a polished dining facility.

Lai Lai Garden on Dekalb Pike, Blue Bell, PA, is one of the most attractive Asian houses I have seen in the Commonwealth. It is richly appointed with dark mahogany and fabrics, tables & chairs, and soft gold and amber tones. The male staff is in shirts and ties. The entire ambiance is of an upscale restaurant, with a menu that generally covers the broad range of Chinese cuisine and a more limited Japanese list of sushi, and popular offerings. Ownership is Chinese and I was there for a lunch of their American/Chinese dishes. Expectedly, prices were also significantly higher for their afternoon specials, which came with cups of soup and white rice. 

It was Friday after court in Norristown, so I didn't mind spending more to send me serenely into the weekend. I opted for their Orange Beef and Wonton Soup @ $11. 

The soup was excellent. Fresh, flavorful consomme with two goldfish wontons and small slices of scallion for extra taste. Enjoyed every hot steaming slurp. The beef platter was not as good. Rather than using lean beef textured to hold a crisp finish out of the wok, they appeared to use a different cut of beef more akin to beef for stew or roast. It was stringy on the inside and far more chewy than it should have been. With mastication pieces of each morsel became lodged in my teeth; not a pleasant sensation. The sauce was well designed, and mildly tart, which helped convince me that completing the meal was worthwhile, although a floss challenge thereafter. 

Given that a much better version of this dish costs $2.50 less at my local dragon den, I see no point to spending more for lesser satisfaction, nor to exploring more of the menu when I have seen they don't handle the basics any better than less pretentious kitchens.

Hunan Wok (identified as only, "Hunan" on the sign above the shop), is a fairly typical Chinese/American suburban restaurant in the Fairgrounds Shopping Plaza just outside downtown Mt. Holly.  The menu is what you expect to find in such places.  It is set up primarily for takeout, but offers a few tables for those who prefer to eat in, as I did.  

My lunch consisted of Sesame Chicken, Fried Rice, & Wonton Soup.  It was served to me in the takeout containers, with plastic utensils.  The soup was straight up chicken bouillon and the wontons were thick skinned and of average quality.  The Chicken itself was plentiful with a mix of white and dark meat, breaded, and drowned in dark amber goopy sauce, with sesame seeds sprinkled on top.  It was not bad, but undistinguishable from most other such joints.  The rice had been prepared in the same soup mix as the wonton, and carried the same yellow color.  More than enough, but not worth carbing out on. 

Service was fine.  The proprietress was engaged and efficient.  The price was under $7 with a soft drink.

Asian House sits in the Mallard Shopping Centre on northbound Route 130.  It is pretty far south of Bordentown, so don't give up hope if you don't see it right way if you are travelling south.  

The space is very nicely appointed for a Chinese/American shop trying to be all things Asian for the hungry public.  There are Sushi, Thai and Chinese options on the menu.  I went Chinese for my first visit as I knew it was owned/operated by Fujianese folks from the Mainland. 

I opted for Szechuan Chicken (extra spicy), which came with Wonton Soup and Pork Fried Rice.  The soup was not good.  It was a mass produced beef stock tinted brown from the dye in the can it came from.  The wontons were thick and not very tasty.  The Chicken dish was better.  The meat was fresh and the veggies colorful.  The sauce lacked much in the way of red Szechuan chilies, and was not hot enough despite asking for extra heat.  I think the kitchen was on autopilot and just turned out what they normally do and ignored my request.  At least it was decent, even lacking the spice.
